story:
Our History

Twinhead Theatre is a lean, mean, volunteer-run machine! We believe that great art is worth paying for, but we also believe in keeping ticket prices low ($15 and under) to expose more audiences to theatre. 

We've given Atlanta more than 30 theatrical productions, a web series, a full-length film; we've fostered artistic development through our guest artist program; and 6 years ago, we took on our most ambitious endeavor: producing the Atlanta Fringe Festival, a platform for self-producing artists across the city, state and country. 

Through Twinhead’s  sketch comedy shows, we develop individual performers by welcoming them into our guest artist program. Guest artists have opportunities to write their own comedic sketches, perform, tech, and direct, while building both confidence and skills. 

Break it down for me.

We have a goal of $3,000 with a "stretch goal" of $5,000. 

Here's what we can do with $3,000:

  • Fund all expenses for a full-length production (including costumes, props, venue rental, advertising and printing)
  • Fund all expenses for a sketch comedy production (including costumes, props, venue rental, advertising and printing)

Here's what we can do if we surpass our goal and reach $5,000:

  • Fund all expenses for 4 karaoke video contest parties
  • Fund 3 video sketches
  • Create a float and participate in the Little 5 Points Halloween Parade

Other Ways You Can Help

As always, sharing is caring. If you have a person or company in your network that cares about the fabric of Atlanta's artists culture, share this campaign with them. Share our website (www.twinheadtheatre.org), our facebook page, and our vision for Atlanta. 

 

*”It’s your party!” perk details: Let us know two weeks in advance that you are attending a Twinhead Theatre original and we’ll celebrate you in front of our audience and all your friends with a pizza party just before curtain call or intermission. A large pizza, funny hats, and an insanely loud celebration ritual is on us - you just bring your appetite!

story:
POPESICAL is now SOLD OUT for its run at FringeNYC. Ticket perks are no longer available. Please donate and help us get to FringeEncores!


About:

The Pope is dead. The Cardinals gather in the Sistine Chapel to choose a new Pope. No one has ever seen what happens – until now. The backbiting. The sacrilege. The hilarious song-and-dance.

They will compete in top secret “Papal Challenges” to prove their worthiness.  Masks, courtesy and piety are stripped away as the Cardinals discover who they really are—and what it really takes to be Pope.

The Fringe is the first step in the development of the show, and future plans include full-scale productions of POPESICAL. ​Maybe the Pope will request a command performance at the Vatican! (Though we're not holding our breath.)

Cast & Crew:

The Tony Award winning producers of FringeNYC hits Silence! the Musical, Yeast Nation, and 5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche are proud to bring together this stellar team:

Writer/Composer Adam Overett is the author of MY LIFE IS A MUSICAL, which the NY Times called "inspired."

Director/Choreographer Drew Geraci, Music Director Jesse Kissel, Sound Designer Janie Bullard, Costume Designer DW Withrow, Lighting Designer Weston Wetzel, Scenic Designer Clifton Chadick, Orchestrator Oran Eldor, Illustrator Or Gotham, Production Manager Zac Spitzer. Casting Director Jay Binder. Social Media Maven Christopher Ketner.

Our extraordinary cast from Broadway, film and television includes: Stephen Christopher Anthony (Book of Mormon), Alexa Green (Wicked), Jason Veasey (Lion King), Lucas Thompson (Cats), Rachel Coloff (Urinetown), David Perlman (Baby, It's You!), and Susan Jacks (Forbidden Broadway).

We are primed for success, but we need your help in order to mount this production. 


Production Budget Breakdown:

We are engaging a remarkable cast with major credits in order to best serve the material. 

These actors are generously working for a minimal fee, but they still need to be paid for their time and talent, and we need to hire a staff to manage the production, marketing and promotion of the show, as well as interfacing with producers, promoters and the press.


About the Fringe:


 

Thank You

POPESICAL is an over-the-top comedy, but it also offers the message that love can be the most powerful form of faith. Thank you for helping us to spread the Good News! 



Other Ways You Can Help
Make a joyful noise about POPESICAL! Share and like, follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. #BlessPopesical

story:
Born in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, Lydia Shiferaw came to the United States at a young age. After high school, she made the big move to New York City. She received her B.F.A. in communication arts. At the same time she began modeling for fashion shows in Manhattan. She moved to France and worked as a model throughout Europe. After returning to New York, she decided to head west to pursue a career in the film industry. In the past 30 years, she has worked as an actress, costumer and costume designer.

Lydia’s aunt, Askale Amenshaewa was one of the early actresses to play on the stage at the Ethiopian National Theatre. Askale is now 92 years of age. Lydia decided to record her visit to her aunt’s home. Getachew Debalke, a fellow actor and theatre historian joined them for a great conversation. One conversation led to more introductions and a documentary project began to blossom.

Ms. Shiferaw decided it was time to take a break from Hollywood, and give back to her beloved Ethiopia. Together with Richard Newton, she is producing a documentary exploring the theatre in Ethiopia that will be an inspiration for future generations of Ethiopian thespians and a gift to all lovers of theatre.

How we will use the funding:

One fourth will be used to upgrade equipment.
Audio recording, batteries and lights

One fourth will be used for lodging and ground transportation.
Many days are spent keeping in touch and waiting for bureaucratic approval. Because of insurance and driving laws, we’ve found it best to use drivers or take taxis around Addis Ababa.

One fourth will be used for meals and artist honorariums.
When we visit artists in their homes, we cater a meal for everyone in the household. These artists never made much income when working, and they have very little retirement income. We believe it is necessary and right to provide an honorarium for the time and experiences they share with us.

One fourth will be used to cover unexpected circumstances.

If we do not reach our funding goal, the monies will still be divided in the four ways described above. If we exceed our funding goal, the extra money will be used to upgrade our production to 4K, purchase a camera gimbal for walking interviews, purchase 2 roundtrips flights to make another visit to Ethiopia and continue the documentary process. And, we’ll use any extra funding to support the subsequent parts in the documentary.

This crowdfunding will give us the resources to produce the first in a five part series. We envision the following five parts to complete our documentary: One. The Women of Ethiopian Theatre. Focusing on the first women to act in theatrical productions. Two. The roots of Ethiopian Theatre. Music and dance from the diverse ethnic groups that make up Ethiopia. Three. A survey of dramatic productions. Four. Comedy. Five. The future of Ethiopian Theatre. Looking forward to new productions and youth theatre.

We hope you will join us. We have learned that it takes a lot of patience to piece together a documentary. We are committed. We just need your help. If you are unable to provide financial assistance, please share this project with your friends and on social media. Thank you.

story:
Contributor Claim Your Perk

Click this link and please fill out the form to claim your perk. Thank you so much for your contribution. http://goo.gl/forms/lT9D22ivHb5zqyaR2

Chimera Productions Is Back for our 11th Year!

This year's production marks Jeffrey Alan Davis's long awaited return to the Chimera stage! 

On An Average Day by John Klovenbach is a tight psychological drama that is both black comedy and emotional duel between two brothers as they deal with the mystery of the past. 

Robert is a man clearly in trouble with a life on the fringes of society when his brother, Jack, arrives for an impromptu visit that sets them on a collision course with the past where even getting a beer from the fridge is a task that comes with way too much baggage. 

Directed by Jeffrey Alan Davis & Drew Griffiths

Starring: 
Jeffrey Alan Davis and David Sullivan

July 14, 15, 16 
Curtain 8pm (Doors 7:30pm)
The Arts Council of Princeton 
102 Witherspoon Street
Princeton NJ 08542

About Chimera Productions

 

 

Chimera Productions was founded by a group of artists who produce plays solely for their artistic merit. Why Chimera Productions? A Chimera is an imaginary monster comprised of incongruous parts; an illusion or fabrication of the mind; something that is fantastically visionary, improbable or the product of an unchecked imagination. 

 

 

The company’s goal is to only produce work that is interesting, enlightening, and not often seen; to explore the power of theatre, and the bond between artist and live audience. On An Average Day is our 11th consecutive production at the Arts Council of Princeton.

What Your Money Will Be Used For

It's simple: 100% of your money winds up directly on the stage. Your donations help to cover the expense of renting theater space, building sets, transportation and lights. What is even more amazing, is our entire cast and crew donates their time to help craft our production. Plus our theater space is also a non profit community arts home so your funds will continue to give back to the community after the show.

Plus every ticket helps us keep ticket prices affordable to everyone. That way everyone has the opportunity to experience the power of theater for less than a night out at the movies!

What's In It For You

Perks. Perks. Perks. 
Every perk comes with a special thank you in our program. Most perks also have PREFERRED SEATING for one of the three performances. This guarantees you get one of the best seats for your selected performance.  We also have goodie bags, date night perks, drinks and dinner packages, plus if you or your friends are big spenders, your own private performance!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can afford to help financially but there are other ways you can help spread the word and share our campaign.

  • You can share this campaign with your friends, family and theater lovers.
  • Like us on Facebook and tell your friends
  • Hand out postcards or posters in your area. We will send them to you!
  • You can come to the show!

Thank You, Thank You

We just want to thank everyone for their love and continued support of Chimera Productions. It is your passion that keeps us coming back year after year.

Thank you so much and see you at the show!!

story:
Tales in Crux: A Festival of Original Plays

Written by members of Quimera Theatre Collective

A new play festival that you can help build!

Quimera Theatrein partnership with Now! Theatre is excited to announce its next production, TALES IN CRUX, which will be performed at CBC Studios in Vancouver from May 23-28th, 2014.

WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE’RE DOING:

In Tales in Crux, the audience is greeted by two characters, half-MCs, half-characters, who guide you through their personal collection of stories as they unfold. Travelling across five different brand new plays, this is a festival that weaves a ‘framing’ story in and out and between four ‘inner stories’, pulling the audience from world to world, past and future,through the happiness and horrors of 20-something life, right into in an immersive and surprising theatrical experience. Borrowing from the multi-layered narrative style of 1001 Arabian Nights, the festival is designed to lift audiences into a different world, giving them a reason to turn off their televisions and come out to see live theatre. This multi-layered, multi-genre, multi-narrative production is created, produced, written, directed, acted and designed by over 15 emerging theatre artists that need your help to bring this project to life!

Quimera Theatre is a Vancouver-based company formed by a group of UBC, SFU, and Studio 58 students and recent alumni and has produced three shows, including Pirates? (2012) andDeath of a Playwright (2013) at the Vancouver Fringe Festival."Quimera" is the Spanish word for the Chimaera, a mythical beast made up of the body and head of a lioness, the head of a goat and a tail with a snake head at the end. The "glare-eyed lion", gentle goat, and "powerful snake" - all are united in the body of a fire-breathing creature that reflects our company's interest in collective dramaturgy with several heads working in harmony and conflict to make exciting new performances of Canadian theatre.

HOW IT STARTED:

Quimera was formed out of a need to provide opportunities for new work by emerging artists to be produced: we started with devised and site specific theatre, then tried our hand at more traditional scriptwriting and dramaturgical development, and now we are mixing everything we know! Involving as many of our peers as possible, creating our own work, producing independently and finding new ways to make live theatre that is really alive, is just what we think theatre should be.


What We Need & What You Get:

Thanks to previous box office revenue and the producers’ investments, Quimera has raised enough money to cover the rental deposit and insurance for the performance space at CBC Studio 700, a great space dedicated to non-for-profit organizations. In order to make the five shows take off and shine, we need a workable production budget, funds for our promotional campaign, an compensation for the cast and crew. $600 will make up the difference to have budgets equal to those like past productions. We will begrateful of any money we raise; with more than $600 or less, contributions will significantly expand our production capabilities to enable the festival and our emerging artists to have artistic and commercial success during their run.

Your donations will go towards

-Printing materials (50 posters, 500 handouts, five scripts worth of paper)

-Promotional ads (print, online and social media pushes)

-Stipends for the cast, stage management, crew and directors

-Reimbursing the out-of-pocket investments of the producers

-Costumes, set design and other production design

-Everything else it costs to do theatre!

THE IMPACT

We are continuing our company’s focus in making our own work from scratch. All five plays are written, produced, designed and acted by emerging artists who love theatre in all its forms. Contributing to our cause means supporting emerging artists who think that the theatre is not a dying medium, but a unique place where audiences and performers allow themselves to feel, react and think in ways our busy lives often won’t allow.

Tales in Crux also follows Now! Theatre’s sustainability mandate: our props are made out of recycled materials and our costumes are borrowed or salvaged from thrift stores. By supporting us, you are supporting theatre that is committed to the environment!

Quimera has always been self-funded and fundraised with members of our community and audiences who have continue to show their support by attending our shows. Now we are looking to expand our community virtually and bring more awareness to our work.

All of our prizes involve some interaction with the company and some of our higher-tiered incentives even give you a chance to collaborate with us!


HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

Come to the show! Email quimerafestival@gmail.com for ticket ordering and reservation information. Tales in Crux is on from May 23-27 at 7:30pm at CBC Studios 700 in Vancouver.

Help us get the word out to as many people as possible! Word of mouth and social media are our favourite promotional tools—share this campaign with two or three of yours friends who are interested in live theatre. If you can’t make the show or contribute financially, find us on Twitter and Facebook and like, share, and comment on our posts! Every little bit counts towards something greater, and our hearts are filled with thanks for each and every one of our supporters!

story:
Short Summary

**UPDATE**

We have reached our goal, but can still use additional support.  About 10% of the show budget remains uncovered by our anticipated funding, so anything above and beyond our original $2500 goal will be put to good use!

*****

The Yellow Wallpaper is a classic American short story written in 1892.  Semi-autobiographical, it describes the experience of a woman living in confinement as a cure for what we now know of as postpartum depression.  Overwhelmed with loneliness and boredom, she becomes obsessed with the wallpaper in the room and gradually loses touch with reality.  It sheds light on issues that still have relevance today and is filled with beautiful images and language.  The stage piece will be movement based and experimental in style allowing for a heightened theatrical expressiveness that hooks into the heart of the story.

 

Performances will begin August 24 and run through September 14 at Chicago’s Chopin Theatre. Visit The Mill Theatre website for more details, or Brown Paper Tickets to purchase tickets to the show.

What We Need & What You Get

The biggest expense of producing a show like this is the venue.  Even small theatre spaces in Chicago cost around $1000 per week.  Other expenses include scenic elements, props, and costumes.  I feel strongly about paying my personnel, which includes two additional actors, scenic designer, lighting designer, sound designer, stage manager, and a director who will be travelling from New York to direct the show.  The overall budget comes in at around $10,000.

I know, $10,000 sounds like a LOT of money, but comparatively speaking:

Can you even see the little sliver of yellow representing our budget?

Needless to say, it's doable!  And here's the good news:

Every dollar you pledge through Indiegogo, up to the first $1500 of the funding goal, will be matched by an outside grant made possible by the generosity of Joe Lehman IV, Thomas and Adrienne Sturm, Joyce Saxon, and Joe and Jane Lehman.

Also, Yellow Wallpaper has been accepted into residency at the University of Chicago, where we will be able to rehearse and use their technical facilities as we continue to develop the show this summer!

The Impact

Every dollar helps!

I know people always say that, and of course, it'd be amazing if everyone could just give $1000, but here's the reality:

Our $10,000 budget is made up of a list of small expenses, just as our funding will be made up of a list of small donations.

Sure, if you can contribute $400, you can pay for an actor.  If you can give $250, you can cover one night of performance in the venue.  But if you can pledge $50, you can pay for a costume!  If you can only afford $5, there will be a box of cereal on stage every night because of your contribution.  And if you only give $1, know that when an apple, or banana gets eaten on stage, you helped to make that possible!

So think about what you can give.  $5?  What's $5 really...

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, if you really want to help, but just don't have the funds, I get it!  You've read this far, thank you so much for your interest!

Here's what you can do:

Like us on Facebook.  Follow us on Twitter.  It's a free gesture, but we will take it!

LET OTHERS KNOW ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN.

Contributions to this project are tax deductible because of The Mill Theatre's 501C3 Status.  If you know anyone who likes supporting the arts, or who needs another charitable deduction for their tax return, send them our way!

We want people to come and see this show, so if you can talk up The Yellow Wallpaper, or create buzz by mentioning us on Facebook or Twitter, wow, that would be awesome!

Finally, we may need volunteers for things like running the box office on a show night.  If you have more time than money and would like to offer a gift of your time, let us know and we'll see where we can work you in.
story_txt:
Short Summary**UPDATE**We have reached our goal, but can still use additional support.  About 10% of the show budget remains uncovered by our anticipated funding, so anything above and beyond our original $2500 goal will be put to good use!*****The Yellow Wallpaper is a classic American short story
written in 1892.  Semi-autobiographical,
it describes the experience of a woman living in confinement as a cure for what
we now know of as postpartum depression. 
Overwhelmed with loneliness and boredom, she becomes obsessed with the
wallpaper in the room and gradually loses touch with reality.  It sheds light on issues that still have
relevance today and is filled with beautiful images and language.  The stage piece will be movement based and
experimental in style allowing for a heightened theatrical expressiveness that
hooks into the heart of the story. Performances will begin
August 24 and run through September 14 at Chicago’s Chopin Theatre. Visit The Mill Theatre website for more details, or Brown Paper Tickets to purchase tickets to the show.
What We Need & What You Get
The biggest expense of producing a show like this is the
venue.  Even small theatre spaces in
Chicago cost around $1000 per week.  Other expenses include scenic elements,
props, and costumes.  I feel
strongly about paying my personnel, which includes two additional actors, scenic
designer, lighting designer, sound designer, stage manager, and a director who
will be travelling from New York to direct the show.  The overall budget comes in at around
$10,000.I know, $10,000 sounds like a LOT of money, but comparatively speaking:Can you even see the little sliver of yellow representing our budget?Needless to say, it's doable!  And here's the good story:
OUR STORY AND INSPIRATION!

In September 2010, six CalArts students joined together to embark on a collaborative adventure that would grow to become "Inflated Ego!" and send them to the Prague Quadrennial.   

 

The Prague Quadrennial is an international exhibition of performance and design that occurs only every four years. Once selected to perform as one of the Street Stories in the exhibition, the members of Inflated Ego! were thrilled to take this unique opportunity to represent CalArts in this community of artists. (check it out: http://www.pq.cz/en/)

 

Our initial idea stemmed from this context of being American students in an international exhibition. After various incarnations we engaged in a surprising but illuminating play with cardboard boxes. Our performance begins with one large Power Box, which is alive revealing only feet beneath the imposing angular structure. This character defines the performance space in a busy public square where unassuming audience members then curiously investigate and are pressured to become Boxed Citizens in the world of the Power Box. This iconic and simple object allowed us to create a universal language to illustrate the challenging perception of America by both ourselves and the international media. 

 

THE IMPACT!

It is our hope to explore the concept of a national identity as two different entities- a standard to live by and a manufactured perception. While the media and international community hold many valid and truthful opinions about the actions and values of American people, we as Americans have often felt misrepresented in our giant fishbowl. In this tricky tug of war we are hoping not to identify a specific power through our Power Box character, bur rather to discuss the manipulation of individuals by way of packaging, ritual and persuasion. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP!

As both co-creators and performers for this piece all six of us must travel to Prague, which is our largest and most important expense. At about $1400.00 each, this totals to at least a whopping $8400.00. 

 

Our materials are another cost to be considered, including shipping overseas. In addition to our boxes we have manufactured personalized harnesses and rigs for each device, a pregnant belly, umbilical cording, masks and varying costume elements. These materials that were used in rehearsal and those for our performance add up to the remaining cost of $1200.00. 

 

CalArts has generously funded our housing fees, but that is a small part of our larger expenses at hand.

 

Since our performance will be abroad and most of you, our friends, peers and fellow artists will not be able to join us we ask you for your support here! Any amount of donation from you, your friends, your pets is one step closer to us funding our project now.  

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Come see us perform if you are in Prague on June 17, 2011!!  

 

Spreading the word and the link to this website! 

Just a lil' copy and paste!! ---> http://www.indiegogo.com/InflatedEgo

story:
Short Summary

My name is Lacey Byrne and I am the Artistic Director of Salix Productions. In addition to my work in creating movement I am passionate about social justic issues. I have studied and worked in the field of women's rights and became fascinated with work that has been, and continues to be done, around masculinity. Until we come to an understanding of how and why men are defined in certain terms and guises, we will remain at an impasse.

Maskulinity - Unfolding Codes of Gender is a peformance based project that is created and produced by F.I.V.E. Worldwide and Salix Productions. Ras Mikey C, Director of Education for F.I.V.E. joined the project in the fall of 2011 to work with Dance Artists in Connecticut and created intriguing and fascinating choreography that will inspire and evoke passion for the audience.

 

FUNDING GOAL - $3,500

Our Goal is to raise $3,500 to complete this project. This will cover the cost of rehearsal space, stipends for the dancers, costuming and promotional materials.  Maskulinity is a process oriented project that involves investigation, research and multiple conversations.

 

The Impact

Maskulinity is about posing questions to the audience to reveal their perceptions of gender and to encourage alternative thinking. It is essential to shift archaic notions of gender because of our ever evolving culture.

Your contribution will allow this project to come to its complete fruition, will reach more people through extensive marketing and will truly inspire an audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to financial support, folks can help by spreading the word through Social Networking, hanging up posters, volunteering at the performance, and bringing their friends and family to the show!

story:
FINAL OPPORTUNITY IN 2011 TO DONATE TO

 PRIVATE LIVES! 

 

What if Carrie and Mr. Big traveled back in time to 1930s and ? Theyâ€™d be starring in NoÃ«l Cowardâ€™s PRIVATE LIVES!

Yes, PRIVATE LIVES is as fun and timely as ever. Much like Shakespeareâ€™s Taming of the Shrew, PRIVATE LIVES is a classic â€œ of the Sexesâ€ about the people we canâ€™t live withâ€¦or without.

A production of PRIVATE LIVES featuring â€œSex and the Cityâ€ star Kim Cattrall is currently running on Broadway, but you donâ€™t have to travel to the Big Apple to enjoy this play.

Our theatrical company, Table for Two Productions, has the rights to produce PRIVATE LIVES at GTC Burbank, an intimate 98 seat theatre where NoÃ«l Cowardâ€™s witty wordplay and scintillating humor will be on full display.

This is the first time in 10 years that PRIVATE LIVES will be produced in the Los Angeles/Burbank area. Weâ€™re assembling a team of professional actors, designers and other creative talents to help bring Cowardâ€™s clever comedy from the page to the stage. Award-winning director Jules Aaron has signed on to direct, the cast will be announced in mid January.

And hereâ€™s where you come in...

Your generous contribution will go directly towards the production costs, including: theatre rental, royalties, director, set design, light design, sound design, costume design, stage management, marketing, publicity, and advertising.

We have set a goal of $10,000 for this campaign, but even that does not cover all of the expenses weâ€™ll incur by opening day. Ticket sales will help contribute to our bottom line once the play opens, but like most live theater productions, theyâ€™ll only cover about 50 percent of our total cost.

So, letâ€™s see how much we can raise above and beyond the $10,000 goal!

Donations of every amount are welcomed. No amount is too smallâ€”or too large!

So why PRIVATE LIVES?

â€œDevastatingly funny.â€ â€œAn iridescent bubble of a play.â€ â€œSomething to go silly over.â€ â€œAll but continuous laughter.â€

Those are just a few of the accolades heaped upon the original 1930 production of PRIVATE LIVES, which follows the saga of perpetually dueling lovers Amanda and Elyot, two divorcees who unwittingly book adjoining rooms while honeymooning with their new spouses. They soon realize the folly of their new marriages and impulsively flee together to , only to be caught days later by their jilted spouses.

This stylish, savvy and still-timely comedy is loaded with pointed barbs about modern romance that anyone can relate to.

Written in 1930, the original production of Private Lives starred NoÃ«l Coward, Gertrude Lawrence, Adrianne Allen and Laurence Olivier. The play has been revived many times on Broadway (including a memorable 1983 production that starred Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton), and has been produced in theaters throughout the world.

Now, with your help, PRIVATE LIVES will be coming to GTC Burbank.

Who is Table for Two Productions?

Table for Two Productions was founded by Stasha Surdyke and Christopher Trela to create and host theatrical & culinary fundraising events for arts organizations, as well as present professionally produced plays in venues throughout . Christopher and Stasha co-write the Table for Two dining column in the Newport Beach Independent, and they are the co-editors of Coastal Food and Wine, a website devoted to covering epicurean experiences along the coast of So Cal.

Nominated for a 2011 Women in Business Award from the Orange County Business Journal, Stasha Surdyke is an Ovation nominated actress and vocalist who has appeared in numerous commercials, films, television shows and theatrical productions throughout , including a starring role in An Empty Plate in the CafÃ© du Grand Boeuf at The Laguna Playhouse. A graduate of University of Washingtonâ€™s School of Drama, she was one of eighteen students accepted into the schoolâ€™s prestigious two-year Suzuki program and received her BA in Drama and a minor in Communications from UW. Stasha is a proud member of Actorâ€™s Equity and Screen Actors Guild.

In addition to her performing credits, Stasha oversees media relations and other creative services for the boutique PR agency, ArtsPR. Stasha designed the award-winning press kit for Laguna Playhouseâ€™s production of The : Can You Be More Pacific? which won the 2011 PROTOS Award of Excellence this year. She is a member of the Southern California Restaurant Writers Association, Orange County Press Club, and the NoÃ«l Coward Society.

Twice nominated for Entrepreneur of the Year by the Orange County Business Journal, Christopher Trela is the owner and president of ArtsPR, a boutique PR agency that specializes in public relations services for arts organizations. Current clients include The Laguna Playhouse, Irvine Barclay Theatre, Long Beach Symphony Orchestra, Festival Ballet Theatre, Chance Theater, The Queenâ€™s Gallery/MUZEO, Costa Mesa Playhouse, Young Singers of OC, and Classical Mystery Tour (a Beatles tribute band that performs with orchestras around the world).

He is also the founder of New Voices Playwrights Workshop, and has written plays that have been produced at venues throughout , , and . Christopher is President of the Orange County Press Club, serves as an Arts Commissioner for the City of , and is an Adjunct Professor of Public Relations at . Christopher is a member of the Public Relations Society of America.

Stasha and Christopher thank you for your support!

For more information on Table for Two Productions and PRIVATE LIVES, visit our website: www.Table4Two-PrivateLives.com.

story:
The Lowdown

Hello all and welcome to my page!

 

 What we have here is an opportunity to uplift individuals and their communities, strengthen the bonds in those communities, give youth a positive outlet, inspire folks to strive for what they love, and to share the knowledge that we here in the US are surrounded by and may take for granted, with those less privileged. Through what medium you ask is all this possible? Through the medium of dance!

 

 Since 2007 New Image Productions has been holding tours throughout the different provinces of the Philippines, hosting dance events and free workshops, to promote and share the culture of hip hop, with bboying being a main focus. This coming May will mark their six year anniversary and the biggest tour to date, LEGACY 6. With your help, I will be able to be a part of this trip and will be documenting the whole tour!

 

 This past January, I was fortunate enough to be able to embark on a similar journey to Vietnam and the Philippines, with an organization called All The Way Live (ATWL). We focused on teaching underprivileged, at risk youth, reaching out to their local communities, as well as helping to build their dance communities and scenes. I dance myself but for that trip, documentation was my main focus, which is what I will be doing for this upcoming trip in May, LEGACY 6 if I'm able to meet my goals. 

 

 

The Impact

 The reach of hip hop has touched the globe. You can see its effects in varying degrees, wherever you go. Often times when it travels outside immediate circles, let alone worldwide, gets snatched up by the corporate world or exploited in any way for profit, it becomes watered down and its true principles become lost. This unfortunately happens with many things. My goal for this trip is to document the stories of these dancers of the Philippines, to see how dance affects them and in what way it adds to their life. The Philippines are rich in song and dance but not many people know that of many countries outside of the US, it's hip hop roots, though young, are strong as well. I want to put this out in the open. People need to know and understand the effects that such an outlet can have in a place like the Philippines.

 

 More than dance though, this trip is about uniting and uplifting people and their communities. Hip Hop is the vehicle. Dance is the specific tool. A very large amount of the population of the Philippines still live lives rampant with problems that would be considered intolerable in the "first world." This is their reality and their day to day. Life goes on but when the opportunity arises for change towards a better, more comfortable life or something pops up that aleviates the struggles day in and day out, no doubt folks are drawn to that. Dance is something positive that has that pull. It can give people something to be passionate about and once that passion is ignited, it can translate into all areas of a persons life. For some of these kids it may be something that they eventually grow out of. There's no denying the lasting effect and friendship's it will build though. For other's, this dance, this culture may be the spark that ignites and pushes them to do something great. The important thing is to foster that ability of belief in one's self. 

 

 As someone who enjoyes dancing and who has loved the culture of hip hop for almost all my years, it feels as if it's the duty of myself and all the other individuals that will be on this trip, to nurture this development and spread this knowledge.

 

 I'm no historian or expert on the topic but I know that from its beginnings, Hip Hop has been a grassroots movement, at first uniting small communities and moving outwards from there. It has been a way for people to express themselves who previously had no voice and this in turn gave them a platform to rise up. Dance is a part of this culture. You might not realize it but dance can be much more than something fun to do or something entertaining to watch. It has the power to bring people together.

What We Need & What You Get

  All together, my goal is to raise 2200. A large chunk of this will go towards airfare, about 1500 (SFO-Manilla + interisland flights). Other costs consist of the basics, such as food, lodging, and transportation. If I'm able to meet this goal, my plan was to also purchase roughly 50 Know Your Rank t shirts (approx. 400), which is a popular brand of clothing in the bboy scene and give these away at the workshops and events that we will be going to.

 For donation of clothes (shirts, pants, shorts, shoes, hats, etc.), depending on the amount and how much I can fit in my suitcase(s) without going over the weight limit, I will send them to the PI using Balikbayan Boxes, which are about 65 for the large size (24x18x18), via LBC Express. This may not be a factor though. I'll keep everyone updated on this.

I will also be trying to raise money outside of this Indiegogo campaign and will keep you all updated on this as well.

Other Ways You Can Help

 All kinds of help are appreciated! Many of us right now are stretching our paychecks to the limit and if financial help is out of reach at this moment, no worries! Positive thoughts, good vibes, and the like are graciously accepted. If you have any old clothes (shirts, shoes, pants, hats, etc.), hand me downs are also greatly appreciated and will be donated to the different communities that we visit. Balikbayan boxes! :) If this is something you're passionate about as well, please feel free to share this page with your social networks via Twitter or Facebook. If you made it this far, thank you for taking the time to read and check out this cause.

Best always,

Chris

Through what medium you ask is all this possible? Through the medium of dance!
 
 Since 2007 New Image Productions has been holding tours throughout the different provinces of the Philippines, hosting dance events and free workshops, to promote and share the culture of hip hop, with bboying being a main focus. This coming May will mark their six year anniversary and the biggest tour to date, LEGACY 6. With your help, I will be able to be a part of this trip and will be documenting the whole tour!
 
 This past January, I was fortunate enough to be able to embark on a similar journey to Vietnam and the Philippines, with an organization called All The Way Live (ATWL). We focused on teaching underprivileged, at risk youth, reaching out to their local communities, as well as helping to build their dance communities and scenes. I dance myself but for that trip, documentation was my main focus, which is what I will be doing for this upcoming trip in May, LEGACY 6 if I'm able to meet my goals. 
 
 


The Impact
 The reach of hip hop has touched the globe. You can see its effects in varying degrees, wherever you go. Often times when it travels outside immediate circles, let alone worldwide, gets snatched up by the corporate world or exploited in any way for profit, it becomes watered down and its true principles become lost. This unfortunately happens with many things. My goal for this trip is to document the stories of these dancers of the Philippines, to see how dance affects them and in what way it adds to their life. The Philippines are rich in song and dance but not many people know that of many countries outside of the US, it's hip hop roots, though young, are strong as well. I want to put this out in the open. People need to know and understand the effects that such an outlet can have in a place like the Philippines.
 
 More than dance though, this trip is about uniting and uplifting people and their communities. Hip Hop is the vehicle. Dance is the specific tool. A very large amount of the population of the Philippines still live lives rampant with problems that would be considered intolerable in the "first world." This is their reality and their day to day. Life goes on but when the opportunity arises for change towards a better, more comfortable life or something pops up that aleviates the struggles day in and day out, no doubt folks are drawn to that. Dance is something positive that has that pull. It can give people something to be passionate about and once that passion is ignited, it can translate into all areas of a persons life. For some of these kids it may be something that they eventually grow out of. There's no denying the lasting effect and friendship's it will build though. For other's, this dance, this culture may be the spark that ignites and pushes them to do something great. The important thing is to foster that ability of belief in one's self. 
 
 As someone who enjoyes dancing and who has loved the culture of hip hop for almost all my years, it feels as if it's the duty of myself and all the other individuals that will be on this trip, to nurture this development and spread this knowledge.
 
 I'm no historian or expert on the topic but I know that from its beginnings, Hip Hop has been a grassroots movement, at first uniting small communities and moving outwards from there. It has been a way for people to express themselves who previously had no voice and this in turn gave them a platform to rise up. Dance is a part of this culture. You might not realize it but dance can be much more than something fun to do or something entertaining to watch. It has the power to bring people together.


What We Need & What You Get
  All together, my goal is to raise 2200. A large chunk of this will go towards airfare, about 1500 (SFO-Manilla + interisland flights). Other costs consist of the basics, such as food, lodging, and transportation. If I'm able to meet this goal, my plan was to also purchase roughly 50 Know Your Rank t shirts (approx. 400), which is a popular brand of clothing in the bboy scene and give these away at the workshops and events that we will be going to.
 For donation of clothes (shirts, pants, shorts, shoes, hats, etc.), depending on the amount and how much I can fit in my suitcase(s) without going over the weight limit, I will send them to the PI using Balikbayan Boxes, which are about 65 for the large size (24x18x18), via LBC Express. This may not be a factor though. I'll keep everyone updated on this.
I will also be trying to raise money outside of this Indiegogo campaign and will keep you all updated on this as well.


Other Ways You Can Help
 All kinds of help are appreciated! Many of us right now are stretching our paychecks to the limit and if financial help is out of reach at this moment, no worries! Positive thoughts, good vibes, and the like are graciously accepted. If you have any old clothes (shirts, shoes, pants, hats, etc.), hand me downs are also greatly appreciated and will be donated to the different communities that we visit. Balikbayan boxes! :) If this is something you're passionate about as well, please feel free to share this page with your social networks via Twitter or Facebook. If you made it this far, thank you for taking the time to read and check out this cause.
Best always,
Chris

story:
Who is Thou Art Here Theatre?

Founded in 2011 by Andrew Ritchie and Neil Kuefler, Thou Art Here is Alberta’s alternative Shakespeare company, bringing the Bard’s work and adaptations to the most unexpected places. The company strives to create site-sympathetic productions, which explore relevant and exciting stories that highlight notable venues. Site-sympathetic work is developed in collaboration with the space. It is an interactive relationship between the space and play; we immerse the audience and performer in a brand new experience that allows them to appreciate our art and the venue being featured.

The Thou Art Here team now consists of Neil Kuefler, Andrew Ritchie, Melanie Bye, Alyson Dicey, Ben Stevens, and Mark Vetsch.

Find out more at www.thouartheretheatre.com 

What is, But Hark, A Voice!?

But Hark, A Voice! is a brand-new play written and adapted by Thou Art Here Artistic Associate Ben Stevens. It follows Shakespeare's "Mechanicals" from A Midsummer Night's Dream, as they attempt to perform their play Pyramus and Thisby at the Freewill Shakespeare Festival... Unfortunately, they have no idea what they're doing. They'll need the audience's help to impress the festival director before the fairies of Hawrelak park ruin the show!

What's so special about this show?

  • For the first time ever, Thou Art Here is taking a show from a workshop presentation (2017), to a world premiere! (Premiering June and July 2018  at the Freewill Shakespeare Festival).
  • It is adapted from Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream using a combination of  original Shakespearean scenes, found-text, and original material written by the playwright. 
  • But Hark, A Voice! is a fully immersive experience where audience members get to see behind the scenes of the Freewill Shakespeare Festival and even join in on the action.
  • With the support of the Freewill Shakespeare Festival (and YOU), But Hark, A Voice! will be able to reach more people than any Thou Art Here production ever!
  • This show is funny, smart, and heartfelt. It speaks to the power and joy of theatre, and shows us all how to find our own voice!

What am I paying for?

When you choose to support But Hark, A Voice! you get to support artists, while helping yourself:

  • We've guaranteed each artist involved with But Hark, A Voice! a minimum of $500, coming directly from Thou Art Here Theatre... but we think hard-working artists deserve a living wage, don't you?
  • We're trying to raise at least $2,000, and every penny of raised will go directly to artists' pockets.
  • And for you? Every donation gets you something in return! Including tickets, T-Shirts, sponsorship opportunities, and special gifts!
  • Coming to the show? Let us know! You can pre-purchase your ticket to But Hark, A Voice! for the same price, but with added appreciation in our program!
  • Have a company or a product to advertise? There are plenty of opportunities to stand out in our program!
  • Want to feel special? Thou Art Here's brand of audience interaction allows you, or an unsuspecting friend, to have a special spot in our show. 
  • Throwing a party? Buy a full performance for a private experience for you and your friends!

What's the point?

Producing independent theatre can be hard, but the outcome is always a unique and valuable experience for the artists and audiences alike. But Hark, A Voice! will:

  • Provide audiences a new and intimate experience with Shakespeare.
  • Help Thou Art Here enhance their craft of site-sympathetic theatre.
  • Employ between 10 and 12 local artists, aiding in their artistic growth.
  • Be an engaging, entertaining, and innovative performance!

What if I can't afford it?

No worries! We know that contributing financially isn't possible for everyone. There are definitely other ways to help out:

  • Share this campaign! Let people know that we could use a helping hand. IndieGoGo has lots of handy ways to share campaigns.
  • Spread the word about the show! We hope to see you and your friends this June and July.
  • Volunteer! Check our website to see how you can help out and get free tickets to upcoming shows.
  • Sign up for our newsletter! Right here.
  • Be a test audience! If you can't afford a ticket, get in contact with us and we'll let you know when we need test audience members.

Thanks for supporting But Hark, A Voice! and Thou Art Here Theatre.

story:
Compagnia de' Colombari presents: MORE OR LESS I AM

“A small, fortunate audience assembled on the steps of Grant’s Tomb last night for Compagnia de’ Colombari’s penultimate performance of “More Or Less I Am,” an hour of spoken word, song, dance, and music based on Walt Whitman’s 1855 poem “Song of Myself”… For an hour… it felt as though we’d created, audience and performers together, a real community. To risk sounding trite, we’d become Whitman’s Americans living in his America.” – Ian Crouch, The New Yorker (click for more)

Conceived and directed by Karin Coonrod, with original music by Colin Jacobsen, Kyle Sanna, and Eric Jacobsen. 


Cast members include: Dietrice Bolden, Ayeje Feamster, David Patrick Kelly, Nicole Mitchell, Giovanni Pucci, Michael Rogers, Jorge Rubio, Leigh Wade, Cheyanne Young, Colin and Eric Jacobsen, Alex Sopp and Kyle Sanna.

 

Commemorating the 10th anniversary of 9/11 around New York City and Brooklyn:


Thursday, September 8th, 7PM: Pier 46 in Hudson River Park 

(at Charles Street, Manhattan)

Friday, September 9th, 7PM: Calhoun School (433 West End Avenue at 81st Street, Manhattan) 

Saturday, September 10th, 2PM: Brooklyn Historical Society (128 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn) 

Saturday, September 10th, 8PM: Park Avenue Christian Church (1010 Park Avenue, Manhattan) 

Sunday, September 11th, 3PM: Old Stone House (336 3rd Street, Brooklyn) 

 

ALL SHOWS PRESENTED FREE OF CHARGE, RECEPTIONS following every performance FRIDAY-SUNDAY.


Who We Are

Compagnia de' Colombari is an non-profit, international theatre company dedicated to celebrating the kinship of humankind alongside its diversity. Our shows literally bring theatre to the streets of the city, with site-specific performances in unconventional venues, all presented to the public free of charge-- Colombari believes that every place is a space for the sacred architecture of theatre, and that every audience member brings a unique and important perspective to the communal experience of theatre.


Our name Colombari—referring to the dovecotes etched high into the cliffs near Orvieto, Italy—speaks to our mission. The dovecotes, networked one to another against the brutal elements, demonstrate a synergy between the individual and the collective, a synergy that we aim to explore, draw upon, and strengthen through our artistry.

 

What We're Doing

MORE OR LESS I AM is a music-theater piece drawn entirely from Walt Whitman’s 1855 Song of Myself.  Conceived and directed by Karin Coonrod with original music by Colin Jacobsen, Kyle Sanna and Eric Jacobsen, the piece involves 16 performers from the Americas: six instrumentalists, six actor/singers (including David Patrick Kelly, Dietrice Bolden, Michael Rogers and Jorge Rubio), one mezzo soprano, one gospel singer, one child and several members of the audience. The piece is played in site-specific locations free of charge to its public. 

MORE OR LESS I AM speaks, sings aloud, and embodies the voice of Walt Whitman, calling on audience members and performers alike to experience our individual greatness and our great commonality.

Why We're Doing It

MORE OR LESS I AM puts forward the challenge of our very own New York poet--a challenge to be a New Yorker, American, democratic, full. 

From the Director:

" This anniversary offers New Yorkers an opportunity to re-imagine what it is to be an American, to listen to what our poet laureate wrote when the country was extremely polarized and on the brink of civil war. Whitman's declaration of interdependence is more relevant now than ever. We hope to inspire audiences that even more powerful than our greatness as individuals is our greatness as a group."

As Whitman says: “I speak the password primeval….I give the sign of democracy/By God! I will accept nothing which all cannot have their counterpart of on the same terms.” 

What We Need to Do It, and How YOU Can Help

More or Less I Am is partially funded by the National Endowment for the Arts. We need YOU to help complete our funding to mark this important event. Our $4000 goal is aimed at paying our invaluable and deeply talented performers. As a thank you we will send you back a signed program and a special Compagnia de' Colombari bookmark!

Also, since Compagnia de’ Colombari is a non-profit with 501c3 status, all of your donations are tax deductible! Please consider our campaign as one of your donations for the year and help us bring our performances to the public FREE OF CHARGE.

Get the Word Out!

Whether or not you can make a financial contribution, please PLEASE help us get the word out about our Compagnia and this fabulous production! Tell your friends by word of mouth, Facebook (Like us? Like us!), Tweet, Google+, email, snail mail, morse code, smoke signal…


Comment on our comment page—it’ll rack up our GoGoFactor and maybe even get us on to the list of featured campaigns! All thanks to you, kind reader.


Thanks for visiting our page, do check back!

story:
WHO?!

Glass Bandits Theater Company is a Brooklyn based collaborative gang of lovable misfits interested in making thrilling, accessible, unmannered theatrical events that bridge the gap between audience and performers. Our goal? To get young and non-traditional patrons excited about going to the theater! Can’t seeing a play be as exciting as watching a band play at the neighborhood dive? 


Help fund our 2012 Season; Everyone’s a Bandit!  Donate, see a show, get some free glasses and let’s definitely grab a drink after.


WHAT!?

Producing theater is a pricey endeavor and $10,000 is an amazing start! 

A successful IndieGoGo campaign will give us a leg up and put smiles on our faces for our 2012 Season!  


CANDY WE NEED // CANDY YOU GET

What does $10,000 do for a Bandit and what can a Bandit do for you?


A typical season includes 3 full productions, 3 public readings and 2 arts fundraisers involving over 50 actors, directors, writers, filmmakers, designers and choreographers ready to share their work with you!


Let's break it down...


Help Us Read!

$5 gets a script printed, bound and into the hands of an actor.

$250 prints scripts for a year. We'll think of you every time we turn a page. 

 

Help Us Get There!

$110 gets one artist to rehearsal and performances for one production.  

$5,500 gets everyone everywhere all year round! Artists have enough excuses, take travel concerns off our minds.

 

Help Us Rehearse! 

$15 gets us one hour in a rehearsal studio. Studio apartments just aren't the same!

$810 gets us 54 hours(minimum) of rehearsal for an entire production.  Never move a couch again!

$2,430 gets us 162 hours(minimum) of rehearsal for our whole season.  Scuff-free floors all year round!

 

Help Us Spread The Word!

$900 gets us up and mailing company info to you.  Snail Mail Lives!

$900 gets us marketing materials. Like posters and post cards? We do too!

$400 gets programs into the supple hands of our patrons.

$2,200 gets us all these goodies for one whole year! Mmmmm.....goodies.

 

$10,000 = One Helluva Start!


BE A BANDIT!

Can't donate today? There's still lots of ways you can help.  Follow us on Twitter, Like us on Facebook, Visit our Website, or SEE A SHOW!  Everyone's a Bandit.  Get in on the Act Today!

story:
My name is Daniel Hatton; I am 19 years old and have a passion for the performing arts. I grew up in Bradford and now live in Ilkley. I have posted this campaign to ask for your support in my future plans/dreams of training and then working within the Performing Arts Industry.

I have recently secured a place at a top Performing Arts school in London, Urdang Academy for a three year training course. However after being denied additional funding from the school; I have found myself needing support from external companies and charities such as yourself to allow my true passion to continue. My current household are not able to financially support me for my three years of training so I need as much help as possible.

I hope you are able to help me, anything will be appreciated and I will be extremely thankful for any donation made. Again any endowment will be appreciated to help me achieve my ambition.

story:
Cabbages and Kings Theater Company presents

PORTRAIT AND A DREAM

by Jacob Rice

directed by Katie Lupica

Monday 8/15 @ 9 PM

Friday 8/19 @ 4 PM

Sunday 8/21 @ Noon

Thursday 8/25 @ 7 PM

Saturday 8/27 @ 5 PM


Presented at the illustrious First Floor Theater at LaMa E.T.C.

as part of the New York International Fringe Festival

FringeNYC

A Production of The Present Company


The Show

At once hilarious and heartbreaking, PORTRAIT AND A DREAM rebounds across time and memory, coalescing into a powerful and intensely personal depiction of love, loss and human tragedy. 


Nick’s life is perfect. He loves his job, his girlfriend, their new apartment. But Nick makes a mistake. Then another, and another, until all that remains are shattered pieces. Tormented by regrets and clutching the tattered memories of an irretrievable past, he discovers that life is easy when you’re happy, but when you’re miserable… well, that’s when things get interesting.


The Company

Named for its dedication to the serious and the silly, Cabbages and Kings Theatre Company blends high and low art into a single, vibrant dramatic force that speaks to our world, present and future. Cabbages and Kings invites audiences into our community to help us explore the fundamental challenges—and pleasures—of being human.

Why Support Portrait?

Cabbages and Kings is a new company. It is a small company. But while we don't have huge funding resources, what we do have is an enormous amount of dedication, a gifted team, and a truly magnificent play. Portrait and a Dream speaks to anyone who has ever lost something and not known where to look for it. It speaks to anyone who has ever made a mistake that they couldn't take back.


Producing a show in such a major (and large) theater is a significant challenge but we have undertaken it because we believe that audiences NEED to see this show. However, we cannot do it alone. Without you we have no set. Without you we have no actors, no theater. Without you we cannot share this incredible play with the world.


What We Need

While FringeNYC helps us keep the costs of this show down, there are some absolute essentials that we cannot do the show without. +Every dollar you give goes to making this beautiful show a reality.


$15 covers the cost of all the prop books in the show. (Bought from book tables tended by men who smell suspiciously of cheese)

$35 covers the entire cost of costuming an actor. (Naked actors tend to be distracting)

$75 pays for 1 full day of rehearsal space. (Turns out plays need to be rehearsed)

$150 pays to fireproof our set. (Burning theaters are even more distracting than nudity)

$250 pays for a couch from Ikea. (That mythical swedish fountain of couches)

$400 covers the cost of printing and distributing cards and posters. (So that we can actually tell people about the show)


Other Ways You Can Help

COME SEE THE SHOW!

For information/tickets visit www.FringeNYC.org or call 866-468-7619.


And check us out on Facebook, Twitter, and the world wide web!
story_txt:
Cabbages and Kings Theater Company presents
PORTRAIT AND A DREAM
by Jacob Rice
directed by Katie LupicaMonday 8/15 @ 9 PM
Friday 8/19 @ 4 PM
Sunday 8/21 @ Noon
Thursday 8/25 @ 7 PM
Saturday 8/27 @ 5 PM

Presented at the illustrious First Floor Theater at LaMa E.T.C.
as part of the New York International Fringe Festival
FringeNYC
A Production of The Present Company

The Show

At once hilarious and heartbreaking, PORTRAIT AND A DREAM rebounds across time and memory, coalescing into a powerful and intensely personal depiction of love, loss and human tragedy. 



Nick’s life is perfect. He loves his job, his girlfriend, their new apartment. But Nick makes a mistake. Then another, and another, until all that remains are shattered pieces. Tormented by regrets and clutching the tattered memories of an irretrievable past, he discovers that life is easy when you’re happy, but when you’re miserable… well, that’s when things get interesting.


The Company

Named for its dedication to the serious and the silly, Cabbages and Kings Theatre Company blends high and low art into a single, vibrant dramatic force that speaks to our world, present and future. Cabbages and Kings invites audiences into our community to help us explore the fundamental challenges—and pleasures—of being human.


Why Support Portrait?

Cabbages and Kings is a new company. It is a small company. But while we don't have huge funding resources, what we do have is an enormous amount of dedication, a gifted team, and a truly magnificent play. Portrait and a Dream speaks to anyone who has ever lost something and not known where to look for it. It speaks to anyone who has ever made a mistake that they couldn't take back.


Producing a show in such a major (and large) theater is a significant challenge but we have undertaken it because we believe that audiences NEED to see this show. However, we cannot do it alone. Without you we have no set. Without you we have no actors, no theater. Without you we cannot share this incredible play with the world.



What We Need

While FringeNYC helps us keep the costs of this show down, there are some absolute essentials that we cannot do the show without. +Every dollar you give goes to making this beautiful show a reality.

$15 covers the cost of all the prop books in the show. (Bought from book tables tended by men who smell suspiciously of cheese)
$35 covers the entire cost of costuming an actor. (Naked actors tend to be distracting)
$75 pays for 1 full day of rehearsal space. (Turns out plays need to be rehearsed)
$150 pays to fireproof our set. (Burning theaters are even more distracting than nudity)
$250 pays for a couch from Ikea. (That mythical swedish fountain of couches)
$400 covers the cost of printing and distributing cards and posters. (So that we can actually tell people about the show)





Other Ways You Can Help
COME SEE THE SHOW!
For information/tickets visit www.FringeNYC.org or call 866-468-7619.

And check us out on Facebook, Twitter, and the world wide web!

story:
NEW GOAL of $1100

Here's what you need to know:

  • I LOVE SPACE! I have always been interested in astronomy, the moon, and how it all works. 
  • This show is important now because we are at a crossroads in space exploration that is leading us towards colonization.
  • I am an alumnus of the New York Neo-Futurists. In our signature show, formerly titled "Too Much Light Makes the Baby GO Blind: 30 plays in 60 minutes", I learned how to write, direct, and perform quickly, passionately, and in many different styles. This piece has Neo-Futurist influences. 
  • I was officially accepted as part of the Acadiana Center for the Art's 2018/19 season.  The performances will take place June 6-8, 2019.
  • I was awarded an ArtSpark grant of $4435. This will help to get the bare essentials, pay all of my collaborators a stipend, and pay for professional productions photos, which I will use to create a press packet for festival and season submissions. 
  • I have been given 75% of the grant money. I have to put up the last $1100 out of my own money and wait until the fall to be reimbursed with the last 25% of the grant. I need help raising that $1100 dollars so that I don't go into debt waiting for the rest of the grant. I'll divide up that reimbursement to further compensate my amazing collaborators.

Your support can push this production to the professional level!

What We Need & Why It's Important

Here's why I need more than the grant:

  • I need to pay for rehearsal space. 
  • To fully realize the magic of my vision.
  • I want to be able to pay my collaborators closer to what they deserve. The grant budget allows for a stipend for each, but it is not nearly enough to compensate my fellow artists. I'll divide up that reimbursement to further compensate my amazing collaborators.

The Impact

Why this show now?

  • NASA is working on a project called Moon to Mars, that seeks to "push the boundaries of human exploration" and "lay the foundation for private companies to build a lunar economy" (https://www.nasa.gov/topics/moon-to-mars/overview)
  • This piece will create a space for the audience to grapple with the morality of the cost of scientific advancement.
  • As part of the grant, I will be visually documenting the performances to create  press kit so that I can apply to theatre festivals and seasons around the country. I hope to bring this conversation to a larger community.

Risks & Challenges

  • Since I already have the grant as a base budget, the risks of the project are small. I am already included in the season and have an amazing creative team.
  • Ticket sales are the biggest variable that can determine the overall success of this project. I have a marketing plan to reach those who don't usually go to see theatre. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If your budget doesn't allow a contribution (I totally get it!), you can still help!

  • Share this campaign and add a personal comment so folks know why you want this project to succeed.
  • If you can make it to Lafayette June 6-8, buy tickets! And talk it up with your friends.
  • If you have any contacts at theatre festivals or season programming, send me the info to help me on that side of the project. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Our Story

Synopsis: Circumstantial evidence and industry jealousy land Chicha, international sensation Chola Bulldyke Fashionista in the slammer. A small kindness alters her view of the world and in the process, self-liberation. Through the use of traditional Latino story telling and multimedia, the audience experiences cultural intersections both with humor and critical insight.

 

The Solo Performance Festival in Seattle invites Gerald Alejandro Ford to perform at The Theater Off Jackson, a landmark in Seattle's diversity theater culture. What makes this performance special is that this year only female solo shows are being showcased. The content of the Gerald's show has given him the privilege to play his character Chicha and will be the only male performer in the festival this year. Selection to this show speaks to the talent, sensitivity and celebration of the content. Chicha in a nutshell is the celebration of self-empowerment.

The Impact

In collaboration with eSe Teatro (a newly formed Latino Theater Collective) the goal for the Solo Festival is to engage audiences in contemporary questions and unlikely material. Gerald wrote Chicha for an expanded audience. His goal is to show the universal questions of being and self-actualization. Moreover, Chicha embodies cross-cultures narratives. As we engage her character, we relate to her in ways never expected. Chicha will make you laugh, cry and think.

What We Need & What You Get

This may be a solo show, but a whole community of Artist are involved. This money will go to paying: 

 

A professional Director and Videographer

 

Advertising (Posters, Postcards, etc.)

 

A Costume Designer/ Fabrics and Materials

 

Props and simple set pieces

 

Rehearsal Space

 

Transportation

 

As a small token of our appreciation we have perks for donating certain amounts.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need people to get the word out and help us get the diverse audience we need! Share the Lean Like A Chicha Video with friends on Social networking sites.

 

We need someone to donate their services as a costume designer. We will provide the materials needed of course and if we will pursue funding so as to pay you.

story:
DOG STUFF

a theatre company that puts the “FUN” in “prodUciNg original experimental comedies (F).”

 

DOG STUFF is an NYC based theatre company that needs your help.

we just had an incredible 2019 with productions at Firehouse Theatre in Richmond, Virginia and The Brick in Brooklyn, New York.

in 2020, we have a big year already announced. we're holding our first annual gala on march 13th. we're bringing our critically-acclaimed show "One in Four" to even more audiences with announced tour dates in Baltimore and Nashville as well as an eight show run at The Tank in New York.

THE COST

we are raising $5,000.

this money is what we need to pay everyone who works for us fair wages. This will also help cover transportation and housing costs for our tour dates. additional raised money will be used for marketing and promotional materials.

 

here's the good news: all donations over $50 are tax-deductible because we're fiscally sponsored by Unique Projects Inc!

THE FUTURE

this is only the start for DOG STUFF. outside of what has been announced, we have more exciting projects planned for 2020. we're going to begin work shopping new pieces and take "One in Four" to even more cities. we just want to bring more fun things to more fun people, help us do that.
 

BROKE?

that's cool! we get it. we're generally pretty broke too.

if you still want to support us, consider attending our "Cmon, Please Feel The Noise" fundraiser on 3/13. we're doing readings of some new works and we've booked some great comedians. plus there's an open bar. more info here:

OR

check out one of our upcoming shows!

3/13 - Baltimore, MD - Charm City Book Store

4/15-4/25- New York, NY - The Tank

8/7, 8/8 - Nashville, TN - The Barbershop Theatre

OR

follow us on instagram and twitter (@DOGSTUFFonline) or like us on Facebook (@dogstuffofficial)

 

THANKS

seriously - we couldn't do this without your support. we truly appreciate everyone who's come out to our shows and we hope you'll keep coming to more. love u.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of theatre artists - writers, performers, directors - who feel the effects of immigration every day in our families, friends, and community. We created this play to tell our story and encourage audiences to feel the human aspect of immigration.

This summer, Ground Floor Theatre presented the World Premiere of There and Back by National Latino Playwriting Award winner Raul Garza, to audiences in Austin, TX. We were blown away by the audience reaction, critical reception, and personal feedback from audience members who felt motivated to raise their voices about social justice. Now we have the opportunity to extend There and Back's impact. And we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $10,000 to share this important message with audiences in Santa Fe, New Mexico at Teatro Paraguas. All proceeds raised go directly to offset the expenses of staging the production (set, props, costumes, etc), transportation, lodging, space rental and paying a living wage to the theatre artists and technicians bringing There and Back to life.

Touring a full-length play is technically challenging, but we're committed to giving Santa Fe audiences a full-strength theatre experience. Please help us raise awareness and motivate action regarding immigration policy. This is a story that must be told.

The Impact

In There and Back, a young woman travels from Mexico to join her husband on a migrant farmworkers’ camp. Her arrival on President John F. Kennedy’s inauguration day reveals stark contrasts between the American dream and her reality. A series of visits by a liberated Virgen de Guadalupe offers a glimpse of her future, and presents a life-altering choice: stay in the United States as a member of the underclass, or abandon her dream of immigration to claim dignity and fulfillment.

Karina Dominguez, a bilingual, Austin-trained actor with over 12 years experience in film and theater in Texas, plays Gloria, who travels to the US from Mexico as part of the Bracero Program.  Karina says "By far the role of Gloria in There and Back has been closest to my heart. To be able to tell the story of a Mexican woman existing in America over the course of her lifetime and to express the struggles, heartbreaks and setbacks she encounters as an unwelcome part of American society has been a cathartic gift".

Giselle Marie Muñoz, a proud daughter of immigrants, has a background in dance, studied in New York City and produces short films. She plays La Virgen de Guadalupe and is called upon when Gloria needs her most as a friend, sister and even as a mother. For Giselle, playing La Virgen in There and Back  has lit up her life and has solidified why storytelling is so important as it brings people together, especially when it's needed most.

Mical Trejo plays all of the men in Gloria's life- her husband Victor, her son Rey, and her grandson Max. Trejo is excited to return to Teatro Paraguas in another piece by Raul Garza, having performed Confessions of a MexPatriate in Santa Fe just a few years ago. This story, There and Back, is timely, moving, and important. 

This is a story that clarifies a particular myth in U.S. history and humanizes those who have been attacked by hateful rhetoric since that time.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help invest in There and Back financially at this time, that's ok!  You can help us immensely by sharing this campaign with folks you think would be interested and letting friends in Santa Fe know that we are coming!  Performances will be Nov. 8 - 17, 2018 at Teatro Paraguas and tickets should be available on their website soon!

story:
Let’s save our own youth! According to the USA Today statistics as much as 40% of high-school students have tried some kind of drugs. For some kids, drugs are the way to communicate, make friends and deal with pressure. Before it becomes their way of life, Practice HORA through HORA-TRACK Endurance Dance training is offering an alternative choice that will build their self-sufficiency and super endurance, Naturally.

HORA-TRACK Dance Endurance Training (Evanston, IL)
14th International Youth Anti-Narcotics and Anti-Exhaustion HORA TRACK Event.
Training of physical & intellectual unusual super endurance will be presented.

Evolutionary Creation vs. Self-Destruction.

Wednesday November 7th, 2012

  • This is the training of physical and intellectual super endurance.
  • This is an interactive dance event with social focus and benefits to the participants.
  • At the event, active participants follow the leader of HORA-TRACK dance by mirroring the moves.

HORA-TRACK is directed first and foremost at the young people. It is not directed towards drug-addicts. We should focus on rescuing the children, those who are not yet addicts, to rescue them from influence of addicts, to create in them a protective barrier. How drug addict referred to drugs? That drug is a communication medium.

We can give our kids a good education, and we need to save them from the negative influence of social environment. HORA-TRACK is a dance of life that stands against the dark, life-exhausting influences.

It is a method of recover after any type of exhaustion and opportunity to break free from any type of addiction, stress or depression. Not only, the exhaustion from addiction, but also the exhaustion that comes from aging, emotions, creative work, etc.

For more information about HORA-TRACK dance events, visit:

http://www.horausa.com/english/HORA-TRACK-Video/hora-track-documentary-a-video-of-the-international-anti-narcotics-event.html

$10,000 in funding for HORA-TRACK in the USA, will allow us to help existing sponsors and organizers to offset the cost of space rental, the video and picture crew, light and sound crew.  The US$10,000 is 2/3 of our actual event budget. The other 1/3 is funded by us directly or ticket sales to adults and college students.

Space is limited to 100 people. Register today.

 Price: 

  • High School Students (14 years and up)  -- free
  • College Students and young adults under 25 years of age  -- $30
  • Adults -- $150
  • 50% discount for visitors traveling from outside of Chicago Metro area
  • 50% discount for individuals attending this event for the 1st time

 Please note: Spots for children yonger that 14 year of age are very limited. Please call before the event.

The biggest benefit is that we can continue to sponsor and provide this event to middle school and high-school students at no cost to them. Current even location can handle about 130 individuals actively participating in the HORA-TRACK. Each event can handle up to ~ 90+ kids from middle school and high school at no cost.  All funds raised by ticket sales from adults are reinvested in the event organization. The organizers do not make any profit from this event.

  • In 2009, an estimated 21.8 million Americans aged 12 or older were using drugs in a past month. For some kids, drugs are the way to communicate, make friends and deal with pressure.
  • 11% of 8th graders had tried drugs and 50% of high school seniors reported having tried drugs.

Before it becomes their way of life, Practice HORA through HORA-TRACK Endurance Dance training is offering an alternative choice that will build their self-sufficiency and super endurance, Naturally.

Testimonials from one of the participants of HORA-TRACK Dance:

  “… Aftertaste measures it all. If this sensation from the HORA trance can be sustained, then it would be fantastic. This dance HORA is very natural, and there is no exhaustion after, you are not tired, and you wish to continue further. These 50 minutes of dance feel like 10 minutes. I could dance like that for very, very long.”  Andrey 27, Young Professional

Visit our Gallery for the video testimonials from the HORA-TRACK event in Evanston IL, July 2012

No amount is too small - even $10 will help us reach or goal.  We understand not everyone can help financially, but you can help us by spreading the word.

Let’s save our own youth!

 

Share this campaign, share our website, share our facebook page.  While donations are essential, having youth come and experience the super endurance training is important!   IF you like HORA-TRACK, pass it along!


Thank you,

Svetlana Baklanova

Svetlana Baklanova, first official representative and leader of Practice HORA in the U.S.A.

Organizes International Youth Anti-Narcotic HORA-TRACK Endurance Dance.

First HORA-TRACK took place in Moscow, Russia September 2011.
