$10,000 in funding for HORA-TRACK in the USA, will allow us to help existing sponsors and organizers to offset the cost of space rental, the video and picture crew, light and sound crew.  The US$10,000 is 2/3 of our actual event budget. The other 1/3 is funded by us directly or ticket sales to adults and college students.
Space is limited to 100 people. Register today.
 Price:  

High School Students (14 years and up)  -- free
College Students and young adults under 25 years of age  -- $30
Adults -- $150
50% discount for visitors traveling from outside of Chicago Metro area
50% discount for individuals attending this event for the 1st time

 Please note: Spots for children yonger that 14 year of age are very limited. Please call before the event.
The biggest benefit is that we can continue to sponsor and provide this event to middle school and high-school students at no cost to them. Current even location can handle about 130 individuals actively participating in the HORA-TRACK. Each event can handle up to ~ 90+ kids from middle school and high school at no cost.  All funds raised by ticket sales from adults are reinvested in the event organization. The organizers do not make any profit from this event.

In 2009, an estimated 21.8 million Americans aged 12 or older were using drugs in a past month. For some kids, drugs are the way to communicate, make friends and deal with pressure.
11% of 8th graders had tried drugs and 50% of high school seniors reported having tried drugs.
Before it becomes their way of life, Practice HORA through HORA-TRACK Endurance Dance training is offering an alternative choice that will build their self-sufficiency and super endurance, Naturally.
Testimonials from one of the participants of HORA-TRACK Dance:
  “… Aftertaste measures it all. If this sensation from the HORA trance can be sustained, then it would be fantastic. This dance HORA is very natural, and there is no exhaustion after, you are not tired, and you wish to continue further. These 50 minutes of dance feel like 10 minutes. I could dance like that for very, very long.”  Andrey 27, Young Professional
Visit our Gallery for the video testimonials from the HORA-TRACK event in Evanston IL, July 2012
No amount is too small - even $10 will help us reach or goal.  We understand not everyone can help financially, but you can help us by spreading the word. 
Let’s save our own youth! 
 
Share this campaign, share our website, share our facebook page.  While donations are essential, having youth come and experience the super endurance training is important!   IF you like HORA-TRACK, pass it along!
 Thank you,
Svetlana Baklanova
Svetlana Baklanova, first official representative and leader of Practice HORA in the U.S.A.
Organizes International Youth Anti-Narcotic HORA-TRACK Endurance Dance.
First HORA-TRACK took place in Moscow, Russia September 2011.

story:
DanceWorks

DanceWorks is a modern dance concert being presented by Melissa West in collaboration with her dance company, MWest and Company, and the Staten Island Dance Jam.

Over the past 6 months, the Staten Island Dance Jam has grown from a small seed of imagination into a weekly group meeting facilitated by Melissa West and Diana Domoracki-Kisto. Diana is currently working on a piece of choreography to present at DanceWorks that includes our lovely dance jam participants of all ages, levels and experiences.

MWest and Company has been working on dances together since 2011. We were recently awarded the Excellence in the Arts grant and commissioned to present a new dance at the LUMEN festival. Our project at LUMEN was a big hit and we continue to make and refine our works for DanceWorks.

Melissa West is New Dorp's premiere choreographer. She has curated dance programming as part of Second Saturdays Staten Island; has produced shows at the New Dorp Moravian Church, Hunter College, the Bowery Poetry Club, and various other locations throughout Staten Island, NYC, and the east coast. She loves dance and Staten Island so let's help combine these loves into one amazing presentation!

Help us put on an incredible show!

Even though we have received a generous grant from the Council on the Arts and Humanities on Staten Island (funded through the Department of Cultural Affairs), we still need some help to cover production expenses for DanceWorks.

We are trying to raise $1000 to help pay our dancers, fund our venue space, aid in rehearsal space rentals, and cover the many production costs for this show. Even if we don't reach our goal, your generous support will help make this show happen. We cannot do it without the backing of our community. Let's help the Staten Island's dance scene grow!

When you help support DanceWorks, you will get some really cool local gifts, tokens of appreciation, from Staten Island artists. 

 

The Impact

Staten Island has recently seen a surge of activity from local artists, both young and old. With events such as Second Saturdays and the various art events scattered around our borough, we have a hotbed of activity. The Staten Island Dance Jam is a result of this activity and features dancers ranging from 14 years old to 75; these are the faces of Staten Island's diverse population.

When you contribute to projects like this, it helps us plan for future events. It helps us plan to create artistic programming for our community for many years to come. By donating a monetary contribution or volunteering your time, or by showing up to our event, you are keeping the arts alive on Staten Island and we thank you so much for that!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you could donate $5, $10, $20, $100 or more, we'd be forever indebted to you. However, even if you cannot donate a single dollar there are other ways you can help. You can show your support by:

  • Offering to volunteer the day of the show. We can always use helping hands to organize, clean, usher, and assist with the production.
  • Sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, and through emailing your friends and family.
  • By spreading the word. Getting people hyped about dance, Staten Island, and the arts is something you can do just by telling people about this show.
  • Offering any other assistance. We can always use donations of equipment, materials, and other production related things. If you have something you think we can use, just ask/offer! We always return lent items in better condition than they were given to us.

So there you have it. This is how you can make a huge impact in your community. Dance is one of the most invaluable forms of communication. Everyone, no matter how old or able, responds to movement and art. Help us put on a great show but even more-- help us foster a community of dancers, thinkers, artists, and all around good folks trying to better Staten Island, NYC, and beyond.

story:
After the success of "Bubble Boy: The Musical" this fall (October 2016 at the Colony Theatre), we've raised almost enough to produce our spring season, but we need your help to reach our goal! We've got some awesome theatrical projects planned, with opportunities to feature LA writers, actors, directors, and technicians. Consider giving today to help us reach our final goal for the year!

If you're not in a place to donate today, please consider sharing this campaign on social media and helping us get the word out about future projects!

Contempo Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Contempo Productions must be are
tax‐deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

2016-2017 SEASON:

October 2016- Bubble Boy: The Musical at the Colony Theatre

February 2017- Unlikely Valentine's Day Cabaret (Location TBD)

March/April 2017- Workshop of an Original Play, directed by Courtney Buchan

June 2017- Published Play (Announcement coming soon!) at the Hollywood Fringe Festival

 

ABOUT CONTEMPO: Contempo Productions is a not-for-profit theatre company specializing in the formation and production of new works, as well as contemporary classics.


In establishing a framework where artists can devise and present these works, we hope to cultivate a supportive, thriving theatre environment, benefiting creators, performers, and audience members and enriching the Los Angeles theatre community.

 

MISSION STATEMENT: To create a place where Los Angeles-based artists can foster their theatrical works and grow in their craft.

story:
Short Summary

"The Vagina Monologues" is a series of monologues based on Eve Ensler's interviews with women on relationships, sex, violence against women and the perception of vaginas. MSU joins an international effort, through V-Day: Until the Violence Stops, to end violence against women and girls. 90% of proceeds from the show go to benefit MSU Safe Place, which is a place that ensures the personal safety, welfare, and dignity of those who experience relationship violence and stalking within the MSU and greater Lansing communities by providing shelter, support, and referrals for those affected, increasing community awareness about relationship violence and stalking to improve prevention efforts and community responsiveness, and  offering a learning environment for members of the community through volunteer and internship opportunities.  The remaining 10% of proceeds will benefit V-Days efforts to help end violence against the women and girls.


 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Attend the show Feburary
  • Buy our merchandise
  • Attend fundraisers
  • Love Vaginas  ({})

story:
What is Reverie Dance Theatre?

            Reverie Dance Theatre is an exciting, new company from the South Jersey area. It is Reverie’s mission to provide its audience and dancers with a unique experience and the ability to embrace a passion for the art form while they work toward artistic excellence. We believe that dance should be inspiring, entertaining, and accessible, not just for avid dance patrons, but for anyone seeking a visually awing experience. It is Reverie’s vision to collaborate with local musicians, fine artists, schools, and outreach programs to create a unique experience and bring back the art of storytelling. In addition, a key goal for Reverie Dance Theatre is to instill in its dancers a desire to have a positive influence within their community.

What We Need?

            Getting a professional dance company up running and putting on productions takes a lof of time and talent, but nothing would be possible without money. We need fund to…

  • File legal paperwork to obtain our non-profit status
  • Rent the theater and dance flooring
  • Pay dancers’ stipends

We are hoping to reach $1,500 in donations. Any amount you can give will be greatly appreciated.

What You Get!

            When you donate to Reverie Dance Theatre, not only will receive our never ending gratitude for your contribution and the satisfaction of knowing that you are supporting the arts, but you will also receive so gifts to show our appreciation.

Perks include….

  • Reverie Dance Theatre T-shirts and stickers
  • Company photo
  • Opportunity to sit on select rehearsal or mention in our first program
  • Ticket to the show

What Your Support Means to Us

When you donate to Reverie Dance Theatre, you are not only helping out a group of wildly talented and passionate dancers, you are making an investment in the cultural scene of Southern New Jersey. If you are (or know) a musician, actor, dancer, or visual artist, you know how difficult it can be to make your medium seen (and appreciated)! Your contribution serves as a statement that you are behind the growing cultural movement of South Jersey and the entire Tri-State area. In addition to your contribution, you can help us out by getting the word out about our campaign and sharing it with your friends, family, and followers. You can also follow Reverie Dance Theatre via FaceBook or on our web page: www.ReverieDanceTheatre.com   Thank you in advance for your love and support!

story:
ITALIAN _  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=reFxJ0wGoAk

(English version, scroll down)

L'ANTEPRIMA MONDIALE DI OCEANIA AL FESTIVAL LAMAMA MOVES DI NEW YORK CITY: AIUTATECI A REALIZZARLO.

Se un giorno mi avessero detto che sarebbe successo di poter presentare il mio lavoro coreografico nella città di New York, che ognuno di noi, dentro la propria memoria, porta stampata come l'immagine per antonomasia della civiltà umana e del pianeta terrestre, non avrei potuto crederci. Per questo, per me e per i miei giovani 7 danzatori, colleghi, amici e compagni di un vocabolario espressivo che ci accomuna e che parliamo tramite la nostra danza, avere avuto l'opportunità di presentare il nostro nuovo lavoro Oceania in occasione del Festival Internazionale di danza LaMama Moves presso LaMaMa experimental theatre club di New york e' l'incoronazione di un sogno nonché la realizzazione delle motivazioni che hanno ispirato la creazione dello spettacolo stesso. L'Oceano ci separa dalla city, ed Oceania parla di noi. Speriamo che dentro ad esso ognuno possa ritrovare un po' di se stesso, e speriamo che grazie alle vostre donazioni e alla realizzazione di questo nostro sogno, sia come realizzare pezzi di sogni che ognuno di voi porta dentro se stesso: e, perché no, speriamo anche che molti di voi, le sere del 14, 15 e 16 Giugno 2013 possa essere seduto a guardare il nostro spettacolo. Afshin Varjavandi

Oceania è uno spettacolo di hip hop theather...
Lo spettacolo è danzato da sette giovani ballerini italiani che hanno lavorato insieme per un lungo periodo sotto il nome di Collettivo,l' INC innprogresscollective, che ha un enorme significato per noi come ballerini ma principalmente come persone e sotto la guida del nostro coreografo, Afshin Varjavandi, un noto ballerino e coreografo iraniano, il cui desiderio è stato da sempre quello di portare il suo lavoro nella città più prestigiosa a livello artistico.

All' INC innprogresscollective è stata data la possibilità di esibirsi in La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club dopo che i membri de La MaMa hanno visto il Collettivo esibirsi nella sede italiana del Fringe Festival de LaMaMa a Spoleto.

Adesso noi continuiamo ad esibirci in tutta Italia e il nostro modo di ballare ispira e porta i giudizi della gente che considera il nostro lavoro unico nel suo genere.
Oceania andrà in scena il 14 15 16 giugno a NY.

Lo scopo di questo appello è quello di ottenere risorse economiche per quello che riguarda i biglietti aerei e le spese di viaggio.

Le donazioni serviranno a: - pagare 8 biglietti aerei Roma-New York - cibo per i 10 giorni di permanenza - assicurazione di viaggio. Per favore, sosteneteci a renderlo possibile. Grazie, One love

The International premiere of Oceania at La MaMa Moves of New York city : Help us to make this dream come true.
If one day someone said to me that my choreographic work would be performed in New York , a city that everyone, in his own memory has printed as the image quintessentially of the human civilization and of the Earth, i could not have believed it.Because of this, for me and for my 7 young dancers, colleagues, friends and companions, with whom i share an expressive vocabulary that talks about our way of dancing, having the opportunity to performe our show OCEANIA in the theatre club of New York is the coronation of our dream and the realization of the reasons which inspired the creation of the spectacle.
The Ocean separates us from the city and Oceania talks about us.We hope that watching the show you could find a little of yourself  and we hope that with your donations and with the realization of our dream it would be like realizing pieces of yours : and why not, it would be nice if you could come and watch the entire show on June 14, 15, 16 .
 
The aim of this appeal is to get economic recources for what concerns : 8 air tickets Rome-New York , board expenses for 10 days permanence , travel insurance. Please, support us to make it possible. Thank you, One Love.
 
Oceania is an hip hop theater show more specifically deals with urban dances and visual art. The show is performed by 7 young italian dancers who have worked for a long time together under the name of Collective, the INC innprogresscollective, which has a huge meaning for us as dancers but primarily as human beings and under our choreographer's guidance, Afshin Varjavandi, a well-known Iranian dancer and choreographer, who's desire has always been to take his work in the most prestigious artistic level city.

The INC innprogresscollective has been given the possibility to perform Oceania in the La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club after La MaMa's members had seen the Collective perform in the Italian seat in the Fringe Festival of La MaMa in Spoleto.

Now we continue performing all over Italy and our way of dancing inspires and moves people senses who considers our work unique in its genre.

The aim of this appeal is to get economic resources for what concerns air tickets and board expenses.

http://www.innprogresscollective.org

story:
My Story

I assume that everyone who is reading this knows my "story" by virtue of the fact that I'm sending this or posting this campaign in places where people know me.

But, for the people who don't know me, here's the quick and dirty: I was born a poor black child....Dang, that's how Steve Martin started the movie "The Jerk" so I better be more original.

I'm a late-in-life playwright by route of being the "Diversity Diva" who has been writing, speaking and working in the diversity and inclusion field for nine years. Before that I was an attorney and a journalist, yada, yada, yada.

All my paths in life have lead me to being a woman who loves writing plays. I love stories. I love soap operas. I love mysteries. I love eavesdropping on people in coffee shops and in airports. I like contained drama, involving people I make up in my head, and that's what fuels me to write. 

Maybe instead of fueled, I should have said fed, but I do what I do because I love it and having my play "Wiccans in the 'Hood" chosen to be in the Third Annual Midwinter Madness Short Play Festival in New York City in February 2013 is what brings me to seeking to find Patrons of the Arts. 

My Story's Story

I live in the 'hood. Not a neighborhood. Not a sweet little suburban enclave. Not an urban, regentrified "fixer-upper" but I live smack dab in the middle of the urban core of the mean streets of Kansas City, Kansas. I live in the house that my grandparents bought when I was nine years old. I moved back in the house when career choices (mine) and unfortunate twists of fate (my grandma's Alzheimer's) converged. But, yep, I live in the hood.

So, when a friend passing through my neighborhood, called to tell me that she saw a crescent-shaped pattern of fire burning on a patch of grass a few blocks from my house, my first thought was "Wiccans in the 'Hood?"

That crazy thought in my head ended up being this play.

What if a handful of white folks, mistaken for Wiccans ("good" witches), chose to do some of their spellwork in an urban neighborhood? What would the neighbors think? 

In my 45-minute play, the characters aren't Wiccans but they're engaging in an African religion ritual that still looks mighty strange taking place in the 'hood. 

With a blend of comedy and drama, my play takes on what happens when religions clash. When races clash. When assumptions get examined about life in the middle of a cemetery at night.

What I Need & What You Get

Putting a NYC play on its feet from Kansas City, Kansas is no small venture. In addition to hiring New York City playwright Kevin R. Free, it requires a person to do sound cues, five actors and a program. Not to mention rehearsal space and me getting to NYC for final rehearsals and the performances.

The festival generously provides the festival staff and the venue of the Roy Arias Studios in Times Square, however, they take the box office so your contributions all go to production costs.

In terms of the breakdown of expenses: Approximately $750 will go to the director, $250 will go to expenses of the actors, $200 to a sound person/stage manager, $300 to rehearsal space, $300 to programs and other minor expenses (such as the cost of this campaign) and approximately $600 for half of my travel and boarding expenses for a weeK in NYC so that I may attend some of the rehearsals and all three of the performances. 

While most of you who give will do it just because you believe in me and support what I do, I'm still dangling a few perks. 

The Impact

A donation will not cure a disease, fund a philanthropic cause or even finance a potential blockbuster movie that might lead to fame and fortune and a chance for you to meet George Clooney or Halle Berry on my yacht in Italy. If you send me a little money, or a lot, you’ll be helping me put on a small play in a small festival in the theatre capital of the world.

On a purely selfish level, you'll be helping me with the exciting experience of having a play I've written on a stage in New York City.

For those of you curious types who want to see what you are contributing to, most of you will get your chance during the Kansas City Fringe Festival that takes places with local actors on July 18-28, 2013 and will be directed by Donette Coleman. 

Vicki Vodrey's "Lot in Life Productions" is the Producer for both the NYC production and the Kansas City Fringe Festival Production. (Vicki, as usual, has been wonderful at offering advice and expertise, but since I'm the stubborn type who ignores most of it, don't blame her if you don't like the quirky approach I took in this campaign. I figured my friends would be disappointed if they didn't get a splash of eccentricity.) 

Other Ways You Can Help

No amount of money given is too small but if that's something you can't or don't want to do, spreading the word by posting it on Facebook or Twitter, forwarding it by email or using the Indiegogo share tools would still be very much appreciated.

If all you do is just send good thoughts my way, that will mean a lot to me too.
story_txt:
My Story
I assume that everyone who is reading this knows my "story" by virtue of the fact that I'm sending this or posting this campaign in places where people know me.
But, for the people who don't know me, here's the quick and dirty: I was born a poor black child....Dang, that's how Steve Martin started the movie "The Jerk" so I better be more original.
I'm a late-in-life playwright by route of being the "Diversity Diva" who has been writing, speaking and working in the diversity and inclusion field for nine years. Before that I was an attorney and a journalist, yada, yada, yada.
All my paths in life have lead me to being a woman who loves writing plays. I love stories. I love soap operas. I love mysteries. I love eavesdropping on people in coffee shops and in airports. I like contained drama, involving people I make up in my head, and that's what fuels me to write. 
Maybe instead of fueled, I should have said fed, but I do what I do because I love it and having my play "Wiccans in the 'Hood" chosen to be in the Third Annual Midwinter Madness Short Play Festival in New York City in February 2013 is what brings me to seeking to find Patrons of the Arts.

story:
'The show must go on' as they say. In times when access to public funding and sponsors is limited, artists resort to numerous efforts in order to raise the funds needed to get their work shown. Help our show 'go on' so that we may entertain, delight and captivate audiences with this innovative and dynamic performance.

the space between us - June 19-22, 2013 8pm at Dancemakers Centre for Creation. Toronto, ON

        

About 'the space between us'

Created by Aviva Fleising (choreography) and Jason Rothery (text, staging), the space between us is a new dance performance that fuses original live and recorded music, theatrical staging, and multiple choreographic styles into a fantastic voyage through space and time. the space between us is a sublime meditation on our astronomical origins, our place within the cosmos, the fundamental forces that bind and repel us, and anxieties surrounding distance, intimacy, and the inherent human need to connect.

“Space” — both literal and figurative — is the jumping-off point for a physical and philosophical exploration of the glory and wonder of the immense abyss that lies beyond our little blue dot. From atoms to planets to stars; solar systems, galaxies, and superclusters; gravity, light, and the fabric of time; the roiling chaos of quantum foam to the gargantuan gravitational void of a black hole, the space between us surveys the subtle connections and contradictions, parallels and paradoxes, and the deceptively simple systems that underpin creation, evolution, and entropy. 

Featuring original music by Tatjana Cornij (piano, voice) and Vast Imaginations (electronica),performed by Brittany Duggan, Erin Eizenman, Aviva Fleising, Allara Gooliaff (stilt dance), Ofilio Portillo, Janine Ross, Jason Rothery and Apolonia Velasquez. Read more about the extremely talented cast HERE.

All funds raised will go directly towards offsetting the cost of production including: venue rental, technicians, artist fees, marketing, and administrative expenses.

                         

Live in Toronto or planning a visit this summer? Come and see the show, we'd love to meet you! Full performance details can be found at www.tziporahproductions.ca 

Fun Facts

 Statistics taken from CAPACOA's The Value of Presenting Report

  • Canadians volunteered 100 million hours for arts and culture organizations in 2010.
  • Canadians believe that the presentation of performing arts equally benefits the individual who attends and the community as a whole.
  • Canadians who attend performing arts events are first and foremost looking for a fun, entertaining experience (84%). They are also seeking emotional, intellectual or spiritual stimulation (58%), as well as the opportunity to experience or learn something new (57%).
  • Canadians believe that performing arts venues provide benefits such as improved quality of life (87% say moderate to high importance), fostering a sense of community pride (87%), contributing to economic development (88%), and greater community safety through increased activity at night (60%).

From Hill Strategies

  • “many arts goers have better health, higher volunteer rates, and stronger satisfaction with life”.  (Cultural participation / Social benefits of culture. February 2013, Vol. 11 No. 9)
  • The average earnings of artists are $22,700, compared with an average of $36,300 for all Canadian workers. (Artists in Provinces and Territories, March 2009, Vol. 7 No. 5)

 

Thank you for your support and your interest in our work. Be sure to connect with us online through our website www.tziporahproductions.ca or on Facebook ... or see you at the theatre!

story:
Beryl and Eejit...

THE SHOW

Beryl and Eejit is a darkly comic look at the lives of two older ladies, whiling away their latter years in the claustrophobic world of gardening and domesticity - until an unexpected letter renders them potentially homeless.  Mother left the house to - him?  And where is he now?  

Exploring themes of sibling rivalry, jealousy, and the potential for old ladies to be anything but sweet, we accompany the ladies on their journey to find the truth about their inheritance.

THE TEAM

Written by: Billie Traynor
Starring: Helen Roche and Billie Traynor
Directed/Produced by: Eamonn B. Shanahan

DoItYerself...

In an industry where youthfulness predominates, DoItYerself Theatre  Company aim to provide a platform for the older actor. Through new and engaging writing we portray the position of this generation in the Irish cultural landscape.

DoItYerself Theatre Company has had considerable success with previous productions - Life After Love, which ran for six weeks in Bewleys and subsequently toured Ireland, and The Importance of Being Honest, which had two successful runs in Bewleys, another in the Viking, and a triumphant Irish tour.  This play is under consideration for production in several Irish Arts Centres in the USA.

What we need...

We have been blessed with such great in-kind support from Theatre Upstairs, Fishamble, The Irish Theatre Institute and Poppin Productions and we thank them sincerely for their contribution is instrumental to success of our production. 

However there are costs that we cannot defer such as printing, set materials, travel and team stipends. With this in mind we ask for your financial support through our Indiegogo campaign. We welcome all contributes large and small and are most grateful for all donations.

Perks...

We have a number of perks that you can avail of all listed on the left.

Other ways to support...

SPREAD THE WORD
Help us get the word out about Beryl and Eejit by sharing our campaign and information about our show on Facebook and Twitter.

SEE THE SHOW
What better way to support Beryl and Eejit than to come see them at there best, and their worst!

 

Beryl and Eejit

THE WORLD PREMIERE
​Theatre Upstairs, Eden Quay, Dublin

Tues 29 Aug - Sat 9 Sept 2017
Previews from Aug 25
Mon-Sat 7pm, Wed & Sat 1pm.

Tickets: €10-€12.
Book Now: www.theatreupstairs.ie
Call: 085-77-27-375

story:
A reimagining of a classic play.

Four lovers, a musician, an historic mansion... and you.

Vanya, by playwright Sam Holcroft, follows Yelena, Sonya, Astrov, and Vanya, stuck under the thumb of a dying man, but struggling for love and freedom. The exquisite language of the play is like 19th century poetry and a subway shouting match at the same time. Ms. Holcroft’s work has been produced by the National, Soho, and Gate Theatres of London.

Eleusis brings the play to the elegant, eerie and ever curious Stan Mansion in Chicago’s historic Logan Square. The play will be performed as a promenade piece: there is no fixed audience/actor separation or designated stage area and the actors will move throughout the entire mansion. Eleusis believes this creates a unique, visceral experience for its audiences, engaging with architecture, characters, and the theatrical story. 

Stan Mansion: Originally a Masonic temple, the Stan Mansion’s grand façade and elegant interiors reflect the design by Moritz F. Stranch. Built in 1921 and completely restored in 2010 the Stan Mansion is located in the historic and charming Logan Square, recognized as one of the oldest neighborhoods in Chicago.

The Eleusis Collective is dedicated to creating "a space for the female imaginary." Eleusis is a Chicago-based company that explores issues of gender, identity, and representation through performance, literary, and multimedia arts. This past summer, we launched our first project in the community of Rutland, VT, implementing a theatre arts workshop for local high school girls. This fall, we produced an original play called The Last Sleepover at the Chicago Fringe Festival. This spring, we tackle the Chicago premiere of Sam Holcroft's Vanya, exploring Chekhov's characters (especially female) through a contemporary lens in a unique site-specific production. 

 

Where Your Money Will Go:

$2415 – Bringing you to Stan Mansion (rental fees)
$500 – Bringing you the exquisite language of playwright Sam Holcroft (the rights)
$1000 – Bringing you a talented, creative, and not-homeless team (company stipends)
$550 – Bringing you into our world (costumes, set pieces, lights)
$200 – Bringing you new friends to experience the performance with (marketing/publicity)
$135 – Bringing you the odds and ends of magic (props, printing etc...)

 Total: $4,800

 

What You Get:

Besides the glorious feeling of contributing to artistic, theatrical, feminist, historical and architectural causes all at once, check out the perks secrtion on the right to discover the wonderful perks you can receive when you donate! Please note all donations are NOT tax deductible.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If online donating just isn’t your thing, check out our Fundraising Party at Heritage Bicycles General Store on February 22nd 2013 at 9:30 PM. 15 dollar admission earns you unlimited free drinks and live music. We hope to see you there!

 

Low on cash? We still appreciate your will to make this powerful show happen!

  • Let other people know about our campaign! Share it with friends, family, your News Feed, twitter, tumblr and beyond. Check out the fabulous IndieGoGo share tools.

  • Want to give a hand with the production? E-mail producer Miriam Cross at vanya.stanmansion@gmail.com

Vanya at Stan Mansion

Performances: April 11th, 12th, 14th, 18th, 19th, 21st at 8 PM


Check back for more updates!

story:
What’s all this, then?

I have recently been accepted into the highly selective Stanislavsky Summer Program, which is an extension of the world-renowned Moscow Art Theatre - the theatre of Stanislavski and Anton Chekhov. The program is a rare chance for American actors to learn Stanislavski's system by working on the plays of Anton Chekhov. I will be going to Cambridge, MA this coming July to sharpen my craft as an actor and an artist.

Why are you fundraising? Just get a job, hippie.

While the Moscow Art Theater USA does offer a  generous grant, it cannot covers the bulk of this endeavor, and even though the program is under the umbrella of the Moscow Art Theatre School and associated with the American Repertory Theatre at Harvard University, it does not qualify for any educational scholarships or student loans.

Let’s talk digits.

Tuition: $3,250

Room and Board: $975

Books/Materials: $70

Airfare: $300-400 (approx.)

Y’know, I don’t even really like you all that much. Why should I do this for you?

This is a first-class training program taught by some of the greatest directors and artists alive today: the students of the students of Stanislavski. The actors who attend do so out of pocket because the training is worth it.  Being one of them this summer is a personal dream and a labor of love. Your generosity means I can take this once-in-a-lifetime chance to learn Chekhov from today's Russian masters. Every dollar helps!

story:
"You can discover more about a person in an hour of play

than in a year of conversation"

-Richard Lingard

 

Update:

At the close of our funding campaign, we are proud to announce the launch of Paidia's web site.  Check it out! You can contact us through the website to book a consultation to discuss your event, and for a limited time we are offering FREE consultations to non profit organizations.  Keep checking this page, too, as we develop and switch to InDemand funding. We'll be listing new perks and selling tickets to our Launch event all from this page! You can still donate, too!                                                                           

The Paidia Story:

   I've been creating imaginary worlds and adventures since I was a little girl playing in the woods behind my home in the Catskill Mountains.  These creations were the beginning of a twenty-year professional career telling stories through dance, theater, and performance art.   As the mother of two young children, I began to use my theatrical skills to develop immersive events and camps for them and their friends that joined story, play, and adventure.  Inspired by the way that these events excited both the kids and their parents, I began to design similar theatrical events for adults, putting special emphasis on creating unique and beautiful aesthetic experiences within environments that supported creative free play.   These endeavors perfectly paired my passion for imaginative play with my skills in event creation and production management.  In 2017, at the suggestion of several friends (and guests at my events) I decided to turn my passion for creating events into a business, and Paidia (pie-dee-uh) was born.  We are currently recruiting an amazing team of actors, designers, artists, and dancers to work with Paidia, and plan to officially launch in October, 2017.

Why put immersive theater into private events?

We believe in the power of play. In fact, we feel so strongly about play that we named our company after Paidia, the Greek goddess of play.  Our goal is to create vivid fantasy worlds that become playgrounds for the imagination, where the line dissolves between audience and performer, and actors and guests enter together on an adventure into the unknown.  Our events are more than entertainment, they are completely unique three-dimensional experiences that you and your guests will never forget.  

Is this basically Live Action Role Play?

Yes... and no. Many LARPs' focus is primarily on “the adventure”.  At Paidia, we understand that the aesthetic aspects of an event are just as important as the adventure. We are intensely passionate about creating beautiful events, and we will work with you to design a stunning event where  your theme, entertainment, and chosen adventure blend seamlessly.   We also meticulously craft our event adventures, which are full of surprises. Perhaps you will receive an anonymous love letter, or a mysterious traveling salesman will appear in your midst. You might be presented with a mysterious package, or an urgent coded message. Expect the unexpected. 

How does it work?

When fully launched, Paidia will offer three tiers of event support:

  • An online store with original theatrical materials designed to support your event, including custom designed letters and tickets, original hand-made props (designed and crafted by our in-house props designer Zzoe Rowan), immersive theater "party packs" and creative costume and cos-play accessories.  We plan on launching the store in early 2018.
  • Full-service themed event planning (without actors). Let us handle the planning! We will work with florists, caterers, lighting designers, and venues to create an unforgettable event adventure that is accented with our hand-made props and custom designed graphics.  Choose one of our available themes or have one custom designed. Includes on site support before, during, and after event.
  • Full-service themed event planning (with actors). The same level of support as above, but with the addition of actors, dancers, and/or other performers. 

We need your help!

Our team believes we have something really special to share with the world, but we can't do it alone! We are in good shape for our launch, but we need start-up funds to cover

  • Insurance
  • Website development
  • Rehearsal space and pay for the actors
  • Research and development of event stories 
  • Marketing and Administrative support- so that the world knows we are here!

Check out our perks, and choose whether you want to be a Pirate, a Detective, a Witch or Wizard, a 1920s Film Star, a Lord or Lady, or perhaps an Airship Captain.  ALL donations over $50 give you a ticket to our launch event, which is currently scheduled for Spring  2018.  You also get our deep and sincere gratitude.

 

Have a question...an idea?

We'd love to hear from you. Post your comment here and we promise to get back to you. You can also help us decide what event story should be developed in 2017 by taking our doodle poll. Just click on the link below.

​http://doodle.com/poll/s3erxdxut524x2za

Want to help but just can't donate? 

Don't worry! You can help without spending a dime by sharing our campaign, our website, and our vision with the world. 

And Finally,

Thank you!
story_txt:
"You can discover more about a person in an hour of play 
than in a year of conversation" 
-Richard Lingard
 

Update:
At the close of our funding campaign, we are proud to announce the launch of Paidia's web site.  Check it out! You can contact us through the website to book a consultation to discuss your event, and for a limited time we are offering FREE consultations to non profit organizations.  Keep checking this page, too, as we develop and switch to InDemand funding. We'll be listing new perks and selling tickets to our Launch event all from this page! You can still donate, too!                                                                           
The Paidia Story:
   I've been creating imaginary worlds and adventures since I was a little girl playing in the woods behind my home in the Catskill Mountains.  These creations were the beginning of a twenty-year professional career telling stories through dance, theater, and performance art.   As the mother of two young children, I began to use my theatrical skills to develop immersive events and camps for them and their friends that joined story, play, and adventure.  Inspired by the way that these events excited both the kids and their parents, I began to design similar theatrical events for adults, putting special emphasis on creating unique and beautiful aesthetic experiences within environments that supported creative free play.   These endeavors perfectly paired my passion for imaginative play with my skills in event creation and production management.  In 2017, at the suggestion of several friends (and guests at my events) I decided to turn my passion for creating events into a business, and Paidia (pie-dee-uh) was born.  We are currently recruiting an amazing team of actors, designers, artists, and dancers to work with Paidia, and plan to officially launch in October, 2017.

Why put immersive theater into private events?
We believe in the power of play. In fact, we feel so strongly about play that we named our company after Paidia, the Greek goddess of play.  Our goal is to create vivid fantasy worlds that become playgrounds for the imagination, where the line dissolves between audience and performer, and actors and guests enter together on an adventure into the unknown.  Our events are more than entertainment, they are completely unique three-dimensional experiences that you and your guests will never forget.  


Is this basically Live Action Role Play?

Yes... and no. Many LARPs' focus is primarily on “the adventure”.  At Paidia, we understand that the aesthetic aspects of an event are just as important as the adventure. We are intensely passionate about creating beautiful events, and we will work with you to design a stunning event where  your theme, entertainment, and chosen adventure blend seamlessly.   We also meticulously craft our event adventures, which are full of surprises. Perhaps you will receive an anonymous love letter, or a mysterious traveling salesman will appear in your midst. You might be presented with a mysterious package, or an urgent coded message. Expect the unexpected.

An online store with original theatrical materials designed to support your event, including custom designed letters and tickets, original hand-made props (designed and crafted by our in-house props designer Zzoe Rowan), immersive theater "party packs" and creative costume and cos-play accessories.  We plan on launching the store in early 2018.

Full-service themed event planning (without actors). Let us handle the planning! We will work with florists, caterers, lighting designers, and venues to create an unforgettable event adventure that is accented with our hand-made props and custom designed graphics.  Choose one of our available themes or have one custom designed. Includes on site support before, during, and after event.

Full-service themed event planning (with actors). The same level of support as above, but with the addition of actors, dancers, and/or other performers. 


We need your help!
Our team believes we have something really special to share with the world, but we can't do it alone! We are in good shape for our launch, but we need start-up funds to cover

Insurance
Website development
Rehearsal space and pay for the actors
Research and development of event stories 
Marketing and Administrative support- so that the world knows we are here!

Check out our perks, and choose whether you want to be a Pirate, a Detective, a Witch or Wizard, a 1920s Film Star, a Lord or Lady, or perhaps an Airship Captain.  ALL donations over $50 give you a ticket to our launch event, which is currently scheduled for Spring  2018.  You also get our deep and sincere gratitude.

Thank you!

story:
"AND WHO CAN SAY WHAT DREAMS ARE?" - SPRING AWAKENING


What is HAUS of COSA?

HAUS of COSA is a company that aims to merge civic engagement and the arts.  Formed in 2012 by now senior Shontay Richardson, HAUS of COSA takes a hands-on approach to improving their community by volunteering their time with organizations and schools in the surrounding area.

This Spring, as part of Shontay's Senior Project, HAUS of COSA will be presenting a staged concert of SPRING AWAKENING to Purchase College and the surrounding community.  Along with the presentation of the show, the cast will be working with outside organizations to bring some of the show's stronger messages to light.

Why this show?

Set in 1891 Germany, SPRING AWAKENING explores the confusion and desperation that ensue when the onrushing tide of hormones meets the ignorance of children. SPRING AWAKENING celebrates the unforgettable journey from youth to adulthood with a power, poignancy, and passion that you will never forget.  This show tackles many issues that are still prevalent in today's society.  One of these issues being suicide, which is the 2nd leading cause of death among young people ages 10 to 24.  Another large issue that is brought up in the show is the subject of Women's Health, Sexual and Reproductive Rights.  Through this show we want to help promote suicide prevention/women's health and educate the community on its importance. 

It's YOUR $$ and WE need it REALLY SOON :)

This production will be produced entirely by students.  For this reason, we really need your help to make this project come to fruition.  If we do not reach our goal the funds that we do receive can still help contribute to the necessities listed below.

Your contributions will help fund:

  • Compensation for our wonderful musicians!
  • Materials to build the set/props and select costumes pieces.
  • Since this show is set in 1891 Germany there will be a handful of period costume pieces that we will need to acquire.  Will may also need to purchase costumes so that everyone looks the same in certain scenes.  On the other hand there are also a few props/set pieces that we may not be able to find and will then have to build with our BARE hands!  Money will go towards materials for those props/set pieces and costuming.
  • Posters / Playbills and other advertisements for the show.
  • Posters will be hand printed which will require a little bit of cash.  Money will go towards the materials needed such as paint, paper, screens etc.
  • Microphone/Light rentals.
  • This will be a VERY large expense for the production.  Due to the location of the production we will need to set up lighting and sound.  This alone could possibly take up a large amount of the funds that we're asking for.  

Along with all of this you will be helping Shontay graduate from college!  Who doesn't want to help make that happen?  Don't have money at the moment?  You can still help us out!

  • Make some noise! Ask your family, coworkers and friends to contribute.
  • Share this page on all of your social media sites.
  • Volunteer your time (more opportunities in the future).
  • Remember to donate when you do have money ;)

Production Team

Director -  Shontay Richardson

Music Director- Stephen Ferri

VIDEO COMING SOON

Along with making some noise about these issues mentioned above we will be taking donations at the show for the Make an Impact Fund.  This is an emergency fund for the students of Purchase College. Loans and scholarships are so helpful and beneficial, but they might not cover expenses like textbooks, train fares, or an unexpected flight home. This Fund intends to help those in need, ensuring that no student forgoes textbooks, misses class because of transportation costs, or is unable to respond to a family emergency because they simply cannot afford the flight.  This fund is NEED BASED and not time sensitive which is very beneficial when situations just arise.

story:
"Now is the winter..."

Long Island's North Fork is a community filled with history, including many beautiful performance spaces. When contemplating a production of Richard III, the newly formed East End Mobile Theatre decided that the audience and performers would benefit from a production that would change venues after one or two performances. Just as Shakespeare's own company did in the late 16th century, we will travel Richard III around the community, creating numerous opportunities to experience this eerily contemporary play. 

Our production team, some of whom will also perform on stage, is filled with young theatre artists who have met through past productions and college training across Long Island and NYC.

The production is led  by actor and director Colin Palmer, who has been studying and working on Shakespeare's history plays for all of his young theatrical career. By contributing to this campaign, you will to help make a production 10 years in the making a reality.

The historical Richard III and family

 

"Can I do this, and cannot get a crown?"

With any theatre production, a substantial budget is needed. Our $4,000 budget will be spent this way:

  • 40% for performance space rentals: our potential performance locations are all community owned non-profits and depend on rental fees to survive. Our performances are just as much for them as they are for our audience.
  • 25% for printing and marketing: ensuring that as many people as possible are able to attend our performances, we will have to advertise online and in print media. We will also have to create programs and other posters
  • 15% for sets, costumes, and props: our set pieces (which will have to be able to move from venue to venue) will have to be built from scratch. Small props and costume pieces will also have to be purchased for most actors.
  • 5% for actor stipends: some of our actors will be commuting from New York City and western Long Island. This will help to defray their travel costs.
  • 5% for miscellaneous expense: this includes perks for our sponsors, refreshments for the audience, and other assorted odds and ends
  • 10% for Indiegogo fees

When you contribute to our campaign, you'll receive perks that keep you connected to our performances, whether during the rehearsal process, in person at a show, or after we close.

Set Model Detail for Act IV

 

"Was ever woman in this humor wooed?"

The North Fork has a wonderful tradition of providing quality theatre to residents and visitors, especially in the summertime. Our production builds on that tradition, since we are setting out to reach as large an audience as possible. Not only will more people be able to see the play, but our audiences will get to develop an new appreciation for the wonderful meeting houses and performance halls in their own backyards.

This may seem like a lofty goal, but rest assured: this is not our first rodeo. Members of  the cast and crew have been involved in self producing their own work on the East End for years, mostly with the youth theatre group Management Productions. They have presented thought provoking and popular productions of Assassins, The Who's Tommy,  and All in the Timing all over Riverhead and Southold.

Costume Sketches

 

"A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!"

Of course, a very real possibility remains: that this crowdsourcing campaign will not reach its goal. No matter what, our production will go on. If we do not reach our goal of $4,000, then we will have to decrease our number of performances and venues, and possibly alter our production design. But, if we raise more than our goal, that means more performances and a wider availability to East End theatre goers

 

"Let us to't pell-mell / If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell."

Please consider sharing our campaign with your friends, coworkers, and family. Word of mouth will not only help us reach our goal, but also reach out to a wider audience when it comes time to finally perform. Thanks for reading and we'll see you in the audience!

story:
THE PRODUCTION 

MILLICENT SCOWLWORTHY is an ensemble production put up by a cast and creative team of 15+ emerging theater artists in NYC. We'll be performing the show September 20th-September 30th at UNCANNY VALLEY, a new performance space in Brooklyn. Our group is made up of a director, twelve actors, a dramaturg, and designers from all around the country. We frequently work professionally in theater and in television, but all believe in the value of generating and leading our own work.

And that's why MILLICENT SCOWLWORTHY is so important to us-- it's a deeply theatrical play asking important questions, and the production is being generated entirely by young artists. It's a play about how young people react to violence, and every single person involved in this production is under 30.


AND THOSE PEOPLE INCLUDE...

Sam French (director), Stephanie Kane (dramaturg), Lucy Pope (set), Lizzie Donnelan (costumes), and actors Sarah Chalfie, Alexis Floyd, Harron Atkins, Kyle Wilson, Maya Maniar, Jacob Stewart, Ellen Haun, Luke LaMontagne, Rosie Yadid, Jackson Perrin,  Nicole Vazquez, and Iris Beaumier.

THE BUDGET (and the belief behind it)

In budgeting our production of MILLICENT SCOWLWORTHY, it was important for us to respect every dollar given to us. In our eyes, that means keeping the budget as small as possible. It also means not wasting money on superficial elements that will end up in the dumpster after we close. Instead, we're putting as much of the money as we can into the space, the people in it, and the ideas being discussed.
 
Of the $5000 we are raising...

  • 50% goes to paying (a little) to the artists involved.
  • 32% goes to securing the right performance space and the right rehearsal spaces.
  • 13% goes to the actual physical production of the show-- costumes, sets, etc.
  • And the rest goes in a bunch of crazy directions-- insurance, scripts, etc.

story:
About us

Hi, we're Jorge and Adam. Two members of the Unnatural Selection podcast and we're deciding to get back to our roots and make some theatre. We meet studying performing arts at Monash in 2009 and since then we've been involved in independent projects, film and TV and even writing and producing our own work.

Through our friend (and director of the show Thomas Lawton) we came across the work of Ariel Dorfman - a brilliant writer from Argentina whose works are always clever, dark and circle around redemption and entrapment. We fell in love. Seeing the modern connections between being stuck in limbo and the uncertain fate of those in detention centres has brought the concept into the real world for us and it was at that point we knew we needed to produce it.

Up until this point our producing work has been pretty independant. I mean really independant - like with a capital 'I'. More like guerilla theatre, we're talking about here. Shoestring budgets, calling in favours from friends and definitely less than traditional spaces. Now's the time to break out and produce something on a big scale for a bunch of people - not just friends and family.

But to do that we need some help. Your help.


What We Need & What You Get

Okay, so here's the deal. We're both putting some serious dough on the line. Both of us by the end of the production process will both be a few grand deep. Neither of us are millionaires - we're just two guys in our mid-twenties that are keen on producing great works that give people a reason to think. We've got the know-how, we've got the experience, all we need are some extra funds.

Ideally we'd get the whole $6,000 budget fully funded though you lovely people, but we're happy if we can hit $700. That'll allow us to spend a bunch more money on improving the set - for a more immersive theatre experience - as well as outreach and getting the word out about the show. It may not sound like a lot, but it might just mean the difference between a successful show and taking a hit which might delay or even prevent us doing another. Every little bit counts. 

If you help us raise some of this funding we'll have a bunch of different rewards for you, from free opening night tickets to access to exclusive behind-the-scenes content from the cast and crew, interviews and so much more.  Check out the perks listed on the page to find out more!


For us it's not about making money.  It's about making great theatre, getting people to see it and not going bankrupt. If we don't hit our goal that's fine - every cent that we raise will go into making this show the best it can be. We really can't stress how pivotal this campaign is to helping us achieve our goal.


How we plan to succeed

Obviously an endeavour like this is not without risk. Though the Melbourne theatre scene is pretty vibrant there's no guaranteed formula for getting bums in seats. Audiences can be fickle and sometimes you're just drowned out. So here's our plan:

  • We've got two people with multiple years worth of experience in producing on-board.
  • We've got talented and hard-working creatives on the project that we can personally vouch for.
  • We have an extensive and growing communications strategy which utilizes census and arts community data to help us target our perfect audience.
  • We will be working consistently on outreach to relevant advocacy groups and drama departments for support. 
  • We will work non-stop to make this happen. 


About Our Production

Check out the video on this page to find out just that little bit more of those involved!

Who:

Written by:  Ariel Dorfman

Directed by:  Thomas Lawton

Starring:  Hannah Vanderheide & Paul Knox

Where:  

The Brunswick Mechanics Institute

270 Sydney Road, Brunswick VIC

When: 

13th - 16th of April

20th - 23rd of April

7:30pm


Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has money - we get it. But that doesn't mean you can't lend a helping hand! We would love you to share this page, link a friend who you think might be interested or just tell your mum. That's right, your mum. Just make sure you use all of indigogos sharing tools so we know what's up!

Much love and thanks for your help,

Jorge & Adam


For more info:

www.UnnaturalShow.com

What We Need & What You GetOkay, so here's the deal. We're both putting some serious dough on the line. Both of us by the end of the production process will both be a few grand deep. Neither of us are millionaires - we're just two guys in our mid-twenties that are keen on producing great works that give people a reason to think. We've got the know-how, we've got the experience, all we need are some extra funds.Ideally we'd get the whole $6,000 budget fully funded though you lovely people, but we're happy if we can hit $700. That'll allow us to spend a bunch more money on improving the set - for a more immersive theatre experience - as well as outreach and getting the word out about the show. It may not sound like a lot, but it might just mean the difference between a successful show and taking a hit which might delay or even prevent us doing another. Every little bit counts. If you help us raise some of this funding we'll have a bunch of different rewards for you, from free opening night tickets to access to exclusive behind-the-scenes content from the cast and crew, interviews and so much more.  Check out the perks listed on the page to find out more!

For us it's not about making money.  It's about making great theatre, getting people to see it and not going bankrupt. If we don't hit our goal that's fine - every cent that we raise will go into making this show the best it can be. We really can't stress how pivotal this campaign is to helping us achieve our goal.


    How we plan to succeed Obviously an endeavour like this is not without risk. Though the Melbourne theatre scene is pretty vibrant there's no guaranteed formula for getting bums in seats. Audiences can be fickle and sometimes you're just drowned out. So here's our plan:  We've got two people with multiple years worth of experience in producing on-board.
We've got talented and hard-working creatives on the project that we can personally vouch for.
We have an extensive and growing communications strategy which utilizes census and arts community data to help us target our perfect audience.
We will be working consistently on outreach to relevant advocacy groups and drama departments for support. 
We will work non-stop to make this happen.     

About Our Production
Check out the video on this page to find out just that little bit more of those involved!
Who:
Written by:  Ariel Dorfman
Directed by:  Thomas Lawton
Starring:  Hannah Vanderheide & Paul Knox
Where:  
The Brunswick Mechanics Institute
270 Sydney Road, Brunswick VIC
When: 
13th - 16th of April
20th - 23rd of April
7:30pm


Other Ways You Can Help Not everyone has money - we get it. But that doesn't mean you can't lend a helping hand! We would love you to share this page, link a friend who you think might be interested or just tell your mum. That's right, your mum. Just make sure you use all of indigogos sharing tools so we know what's up!
Much love and thanks for your help,
Jorge & Adam

For more info:
www.UnnaturalShow.com

story:
Often people go throughout their entire life wandering aimlessly not knowing their purpose.  As you see in the world today, there are many instances of pain, emotional struggle, strife, unforgiveness, malicious behavior and no regard for authority.  Most often due to lack of self-worth or the inability to determine their purpose.  So they find themselves in a repeated cycle of inadequacy, not realizing that God created them for a reason.  The goal of Soul Purpose is to save lives, restore marriages, mend broken hearts, restore hope to those that have giving up on life.  This play will leave you empowered, encouraged, motivated, impacted, and uplifted.  We invite you to partner with us on this journey of discovery.  Soul Purpose is a labor of love and a story of hope and forgiveness.  Be a part of history.  Be a part of the #SoulMovement.  By being a part of this project you will impact the lives of thousand of people that have yet to realize that "Every Soul Has a Purpose".

Synopsis:

5 strong and powerful, African American women from different walks of life that through an unexpected sisterhood develop a spiritual bond that is unbreakable. Their heartfelt journeys & purpose, while all different, find they are traveling in the same direction. These women will leave you empowered, encouraged, motivated, impacted, and uplifted. They all discover that it’s not their struggles that define them, but how they overcome them that does. Their strong faith in God and full dependence on Him, make all of them triumphant in spite of their circumstances. Each of them seeking and finding God’s purpose for their life, in their own unique and special way.

Meet The CAST

Angela: An Educated, hardworking, single mother of 3 who is at odds with the choices of her oldest son…  Learn her story this spring at the play Soul Purpose.

Elizabeth: First lady of the church struggling w/strained relationship between her husband and son.  Will her relationship with the men in her life be fixed?

Tamara: Most of us are either in a storm, coming out of a storm, or about to go into a storm.  Some of us are like Tamara who hasn’t seen the sun shine in a long time.  Will her problems keep her from finding joy? Will she find her Soul Purpose?

Brooklyn:  Single and searching.  All the Single Ladies! What is your Soul Purpose?

Saundra:  An encourager in public and dying in private.  Are you like Saundra? Are you about to break into fighting your own personal issues?

Jessica fights her own self worth issues that causes destructive behavior. 

https://todayspurposewoman.com/a-conversation-with-cheryl-p-williamson-the-producer-of-the-highly-anticipated-stage-play-soul-purpose/

To Be Continued

story:
Edit:

Any and all donations that are over the $25 mark will be given a tax receipt for your records and benefit! Just one more reason to make a donation!

Who Are We?

The Canadian Dance Assembly (CDA) is the voice of the professional dance sector in Canada and promotes a healthy, sustainable environment in which professional dance practice can grow and thrive.  CDA cultivates a strong national voice for Canadian professional dance and supports the development of resources for this field of artistic expression. Through conferences, workshops, and networking events we connect the dance community from coast to coast, building a cohesive and dynamic milieu.

The Brass Tacks

What is International Dance Day (IDD)? Why are we having an event?

International Dance Day was introduced in 1982 by the International Dance Committee of the International Theatre Institute (ITI), a UNESCO partner NGO, and is celebrated on April 29 every year. The date was suggested by the International Dance Committee of ITI to commemorate the birthday of Jean-Georges Noverre (1727-1810), creator of modern ballet and author of the famous Lettres sur la danse published in 1760 in Lyon[1]

The goal of the “International Dance Day Message” is to celebrate Dance, to revel in the universality of this art form, to cross all political, cultural and ethnic barriers and bring people together through the common language of Dance. Every year, the International Dance Committee of the UNESCO International Theatre Institute circulates a message around the world as part of International Dance Day celebrations. Additionally, since 2005, the Canadian Dance Assembly (CDA) has issued a Canadian message in conjunction with the UNESCO message. Santee Smith, choreographer, dancer, and Artistic Director of Kaha:wi Dance Theatre offers her call to action, on behalf of the Canadian Dance Assembly in celebration of International Dance Day 2014.  

This year Canadian Dance Assembly is coordinating a free noon-hour event for the public at Yonge and Dundas Square in celebration of IDD.  Our enthusiastic MC, Kevin Ormsby of KasheDance, will guide us through a dance journey to be sure we ‘catch the rhythm’ on this special occasion.  The Canadian Dance Assembly will also invite local politicians to attend and dance with us.  

Catch the Rhythm is completely free and is open to general public ages 1 to 100.

Each dollar you donate go towards making Catch the Rhythm a fun and dynamic event for everyone to enjoy. All proceeds go towards logistics and operating costs. 

Where the money goes and what you get for your contribution:

  • Technical requirements, the lights, the speakers, the stage, the people behind the scenes making the day come together.
  • From swag, honourable mentions, or you can even buy a tent to help promote your own project, business or organization!
  • No matter the amount raised it will go towards the event and towards thanking those who help us with on the ground support during the day.
Event Schedule
11:15am - 11:30 Mama Dances led by Kate Alton

11:30am-Noon
Dance Yoga led by Jaimee Horn, Lululemon Ambassador
 
Noon-12:15pm 		 
Sharing Dance Flash mob dance lesson, led by Patrick Parson of Ballet Creole
 
12:15pm-12:30pm
 		  
Motus O Dance Theatre, interactive lecture-demo (courtesy of Prologue to the Performing Arts)
 
12:30pm-12:45pm 		 
Dance Migration, performance (courtesy of CPAMO)
 
12:45pm-1:00pm 		 
Jasmyn Fyffe Dance, performance (courtesy of Dance Ontario)

The Impact

Here at CDA we are crazy about dancing! We believe that dance is more transcendent and necessary to life.

In the words of Santee Smith who wrote this special message for International Dance Day:

"Let dance into your life. Call dance into your life. Breathe dance into your life. Let dance be the connection between your spirit and the living universe. Let dance be the voice of your soulful resistance, your statement of I am here, in this space, now. Let dance resonate from your ancestral memories, from your DNA extending like tendrils to future generations. Call your body    forth to move, to speak a language without words. Dance your dreams and poetry. Find that place deep inside your inner landscape that longs for expression. Close your eyes and remember the heartbeat rhythm, the first music you heard in your consciousness. Be the witness to a singular body animated in time and space or to the awesomeness of a multitude moving in unity. Let dance represent your metaphor, art, ritual, ceremony and ecstatic transformation. Energize, revitalize and renew yourself through dance. Renew your bond to the rhythms of the earth. Heal yourself, be yourself and together we can dance our humanity. Transform your life … let dance into your life. Join the celebration and ceremony of life; join the dance."

Come Catch the Rhythm with us April 29!

Come Catch the Rhythm with us April 29!

story:
Short Summary

On a whim I threw out an idea to the popular OC Comics Scene group on Facebook and the local internet immediately exploded with interest. My hand has been forced.

Here is the IndieGoGo campaign:

  • A roast disguised as a classy award show! Nobody will be crowned "Funniest Comic" because that's not what this show is. There will be genuine moments of praise, but primarily, these are categories you wouldn't want to be nominated for.
  • Comedians from all over Orange County and beyond will descend upon STAGEStheater in Fullerton. They will be greeted by a red carpet, photographers, media, a host, an announcer, trophies, a trophy lady, a slide show with fancy graphics, a keynote speech and catering! And more, probably!
  • Tuxedos and fancy dresses shall be worn!
  • Comedians will know that they have been nominated, but will not know for what category until they're in the theater and the show is rolling. 
  • The night's theme, without a doubt, will be "We Family!"

What We Need & What You Get

If you're a local comic, that's great that you want to present or are hoping to get nominated. But we're not planning anything unless we know for sure that you will be there. And money talks.

Here's how it all breaks down:

  • Bare minimum to make this work is $400 (theater, staff, awards & photography) but there is no reason to stop there. 
  • An additional $200 gets us free Thundergoat Tacos for the entire night. 
  • Indiegogo & Paypal want about $50 total.
  • The more funding, the more outlandish this event gets.
  • $10 Pre-Sale Tickets get you in the door. If you are a local Orange County standup comic, we'll consider you to present and/or "win" - if we think it fits. We just need the pre-sale to at least know you're coming. 
  • $12 tickets will be available at the box office the night of the event. We'll be glad to see you. We'll likely talk about you. You won't present or "win" anything. 
  • $25 Pre-Sale Tickets get you and a +1 into the event. You are also automatically guaranteed a "Technical Achievement Award" which will be handed out at the top of the show, in a category that roastfully fits you. Additionally, you will be eligible to "win" in other categories as well as present - because we know you will be there. If your +1 is another Orange County comic, please let us know so we can include them.
  • Own a business? $100 gets you add space on our red carpet photography backdrop! 
  • THANKS TO FULL FUNDING: FREE TACOS TO ALL THAT ATTEND! 

The Impact

There is no charity attached to this event, but...:

  • It will be heavily photographed. Fancy dressed comics holding awards (fake as they may be) all hanging out with each other having a great time will not only raise awareness of our scene but perhaps bring us together?
  • Recent new year resolution comics won't have to wait so long at open mics.
  • "Winners" can totally use their award credit in their show fliers!
  • Most importantly of all, we will be handing out a super classy lifetime achievement award to an individual who has made an amazing impact in the local comedy community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this event with other local comedians.

Admittedly, this is event is pretty "inside baseball", so I can't imagine anybody outside Orange County giving a damn about this campaign. And rightfully so.

But if you're feeling generous...  

  • Repost!
  • Reblog!
  • Retweet!

Thank you for your time!

01/07/2014: We have reached full funding with 17 days left in the campaign. We are by no means done, but I am totally blown away by how much we've done with only 19 contributors in just a week. 

Sure $650 isn't THAT MUCH, but these are comics we're talking about. This is a miracle. 

Theater: Rented + Staffed
Food: Catered

The Self Indulgent Podcast and Blanket Opinion will both be on the scene covering the event in their own ways. 

Other elements like photography, the red carpet (thinking shag) and the production itself still depend on the overall contributor total. 

For the latest information, please check our Facebook event.
