story:
In Brief

Grease Yaka is an original devised play about Sri Lankan society, its doubts and its fears, real and imagined, that will make a lasting impact on all who see it. Created entirely by young people and directed by well known dramatist Ruwanthie de Chickera, the play stars students & young alumni of Ananda College Colombo and a handful of invited guest performers.

Grease Yaka debuts at Colombo's Lionel Wendt Theatre on 8th & 9th August. 

Though a few corporate sponsors and individual donors are helping us stage this production, we need your support to make Grease Yaka a truly unforgettable theatre experience. Your contributions will help us stage the play in the way it deserves, and your support will encourage us greatly just before we take the stage.


Who We Are & The Story So Far

AnandaDrama is the theatre collective of Ananda College, comprising students and young alumni. It grew from an initiative that began in 2006 to improve the English skills of students through theatre. In 2013, we set up AnandaDrama as a proper theatre company and staged two very successful public shows.

The first of these, Alles in Wonderland, was an original political satire that began as a championship winning entry to an inter school drama competition. Due to popular demand, it was later staged as a sell out public show seen by top officials and even identified in local discourse about Indo-Sri Lanka relations. Next came Kensuke's Kingdom, a lyrical full length play that explored different aspects of theatre and gave our young cast fresh challenges. 

When we started work on our production for 2014, we wanted to set the bar even higher by involving everyone in the cast in the creative process. Instead of performing to a pre-written script, we decided to devise an original full length play.

In January, we invited internationally acclaimed playwright, screenwriter and director Ruwanthie de Chickera and the Stages Theatre Group to help us devise. Workshops started in February. In the first few weeks, we worked on our acting skills and also talked through the stories and issues that really moved us as a group.

We realised early on that we all wanted our play to be more than just entertainment. We wanted to tell a story that would provide important insights about our society. The idea of using the Grease Yaka as the vehicle for our play sprang up during one workshop, and immediately caught everyone's interest. Over the next few months of devising, the play took shape.


Why Grease Yaka

Sri Lankan society tends to get worked up about all sorts of things--quite often, for little or no reason. The Grease Yaka phenomenon that gripped the country not so long ago is the metaphor that we have used to hold up a mirror to society.

Yaka is the Sinhala word for demon, and describes many mythical beings that have populated Sri Lankan folklore for centuries. The Grease Yaka is much more recent: it is an urban legend about a grease covered, near naked man who delights in peeping at unsuspecting women. Some believe that the Grease Yaka is more than a really creepy voyeur: robbery, rape and murder have also been laid at his door.

There was a sudden uptick in reported Grease Yaka sightings all over Sri Lanka a few years ago. This led to a social phobia that almost veered towards mass hysteria. Our play is a fantasia that charts this process. Though it employs a very light touch, the play poses searching questions about what sort of society we want ours to be. 

At a time when there are distant (and not so distant) rumblings of new confusions, phobias and hysteria in our midst, Grease Yaka is topical and very relevant. And, needless to say, as a piece of original devised theatre, it is also hugely entertaining.


Why We Need Your Help

The devising is done. The script is ready. The theatre is paid for. The set design is done. The posters are up. The actors are pumped. Come what may, we will put on a show to remember... and to provoke thought. But we need your help!

Immediate Requirements

We need you to help us pay for the Set, Costumes, Props and Makeup. These are turning out to be a lot more expensive than we initially thought, but if we can afford them, they will contribute hugely to the magic we hope to create on stage. 

We also want to share Grease Yaka with more people than just the lucky 1,240 who will get to see it in the theatre this August. If we reach our funding target, we will make sure that a performance of the play is made into a professional DVD. 

After the Production

Grease Yaka is part of the Stages Theatre Group's Education Outreach effort. This involves educating students from selected schools about the process of creating and shaping the play. Workshops will be held before and after the production, and a comprehensive Resource Pack will be shared with students and teachers to encourage further learning. Your contributions will help make this happen.

Even more importantly, we believe that the play and its message are important enough that Grease Yaka needs to be seen much more widely. We have plans to take it on tour around Sri Lanka and maybe even perform it abroad. While we are not looking for funding for this just yet, your contributions at this stage will help us create the magic in the initial production that will make touring almost inevitable. 


The Funding Situation At The Moment

This is the estimate of what we will need to stage Grease Yaka in style:


This is where we stand now (just two weeks to go to the performance!)


We need approximately $9,000 more to ensure that the play is fully funded!


How Things Could Play Out

  1. We meet our target: We put on a show that will forever be remembered by its audience, and is available on DVD for posterity, and is turned into a creative learning experience for a large number of students in Sri Lanka.
  2. We exceed our target: Every single cent above and beyond what we spend on the play (as well as all proceeds from the play) will be used to fund English and Theatre development activities at Ananda College.
  3. We don't meet our target:  Indiegogo will send us whatever funds we do raise, so hopefully we will have something significant to work with even if we don't reach our target. No matter what, the show will go on!

Please Help Us!

Please donate whatever you can. Any and all financial contributions are most welcome, and we have special perks lined up for contributions of a certain value.

Please spread the word. We want everyone to know about this play. Please share our campaign with people who you think will be interested in helping us, and people who may be interested in seeing Grease Yaka.

Please get in touch if you have any questions or would like to know more about us. Our website is right here.

We've put our hearts and souls into creating Grease Yaka and we're really, really excited about sharing it with the public in the most magical way possible. Please help us make this happen!
story_txt:
In Brief
Grease Yaka is an original devised play about Sri Lankan society, its doubts and its fears, real and imagined, that will make a lasting impact on all who see it. Created entirely by young people and directed by well known dramatist Ruwanthie de Chickera, the play stars students & young alumni of Ananda College Colombo and a handful of invited guest performers.
Grease Yaka debuts at Colombo's Lionel Wendt Theatre on 8th & 9th August. 
Though a few corporate sponsors and individual donors are helping us stage this production, we need your support to make Grease Yaka a truly unforgettable theatre experience. Your contributions will help us stage the play in the way it deserves, and your support will encourage us greatly just before we take the stage.




Who We Are & The Story So Far

AnandaDrama is the theatre collective of Ananda College, comprising students and young alumni. It grew from an initiative that began in 2006 to improve the English skills of students through theatre. In 2013, we set up AnandaDrama as a proper theatre company and staged two very successful public shows.
The first of these, Alles in Wonderland, was an original political satire that began as a championship winning entry to an inter school drama competition. Due to popular demand, it was later staged as a sell out public show seen by top officials and even identified in local discourse about Indo-Sri Lanka relations. Next came Kensuke's Kingdom, a lyrical full length play that explored different aspects of theatre and gave our young cast fresh challenges. 
When we started work on our production for 2014, we wanted to set the bar even higher by involving everyone in the cast in the creative process. Instead of performing to a pre-written script, we decided to devise an original full length play.
In January, we invited internationally acclaimed playwright, screenwriter and director Ruwanthie de Chickera and the Stages Theatre Group to help us devise. Workshops started in February. In the first few weeks, we worked on our acting skills and also talked through the stories and issues that really moved us as a group.

We realised early on that we all wanted our play to be more than just entertainment. We wanted to tell a story that would provide important insights about our society. The idea of using the Grease Yaka as the vehicle for our play sprang up during one workshop, and immediately caught everyone's interest. Over the next few months of devising, the play took shape.


Why Grease Yaka


Sri Lankan society tends to get worked up about all sorts of things--quite often, for little or no reason. The Grease Yaka phenomenon that gripped the
country not so long ago is the metaphor that we have used to hold up a mirror
to society.
Yaka is the Sinhala word for demon, and describes many mythical beings that have populated Sri Lankan folklore for centuries. The Grease Yaka is much more recent: it is an urban legend about a grease covered, near naked man who delights in peeping at unsuspecting women. Some believe that the Grease Yaka is more than a really creepy voyeur: robbery, rape and murder have also been laid at his door.
There was a sudden uptick in reported Grease Yaka sightings all over Sri Lanka a few years ago. This led to a social phobia that almost veered towards mass hysteria. Our play is a fantasia that charts this process. Though it employs a very light touch, the play poses searching questions about what sort of society we want ours to be. 
At a time when there are distant (and not so distant) rumblings of new confusions, phobias and hysteria in our midst, Grease Yaka is topical and very relevant. And, needless to say, as a piece of original devised theatre, it is also hugely entertaining.



Why We Need Your Help


The devising is done. The script is ready. The theatre is paid for. The set design is done. The posters are up. The actors are pumped. Come what may, we will put on a show to remember... and to provoke thought. But we need your help!
Immediate Requirements
We need you to help us pay for the Set, Costumes, Props and Makeup. These are turning out to be a lot more expensive than we initially thought, but if we can afford them, they will contribute hugely to the magic we hope to create on stage. 
We also want to share Grease Yaka with more people than just the lucky 1,240 who will get to see it in the theatre this August. If we reach our funding target, we will make sure that a performance of the play is made into a professional DVD. 
After the Production
Grease Yaka is part of the Stages Theatre Group's Education Outreach effort. This involves educating students from selected schools about the process of creating and shaping the play. Workshops will be held before and after the production, and a comprehensive Resource Pack will be shared with students and teachers to encourage further learning. Your contributions will help make this happen.
Even more importantly, we believe that the play and its message are important enough that Grease Yaka needs to be seen much more widely. We have plans to take it on tour around Sri Lanka and maybe even perform it abroad. While we are not looking for funding for this just yet, your contributions at this stage will help us create the magic in the initial production that will make touring almost inevitable. 


The Funding Situation At The Moment
This is the estimate of what we will need to stage Grease Yaka in style:




This is where we stand now (just two weeks to go to the performance!)





We need approximately $9,000 more to ensure that the play is fully funded!

How Things Could Play Out



We meet our target: We put on a show that will forever be remembered by its audience, and is available on DVD for posterity, and is turned into a creative learning experience for a large number of students in Sri Lanka.

We exceed our target: Every single cent above and beyond what we spend on the play (as well as all proceeds from the play) will be used to fund English and Theatre development activities at Ananda College.

We don't meet our target:  Indiegogo will send us whatever funds we do raise, so hopefully we will have something significant to work with even if we don't reach our target. No matter what, the show will go on!


Please Help Us!



 Please donate whatever you can. Any and all financial contributions are most welcome, and we have special perks lined up for contributions of a certain value.
Please spread the word. We want everyone to know about this play. Please share our campaign with people who you think will be interested in helping us, and people who may be interested in seeing Grease Yaka.
Please get in touch if you have any questions or would like to know more about us. Our website is right here.We've put our hearts and souls into creating Grease Yaka and we're really, really excited about sharing it with the public in the most magical way possible. Please help us make this happen!

story:
Hello beautiful people of the Internet.

We are Theatre Sentinel
aka 
Rebecca Hooton - Director/Producer
Elyssia Sasaki - Set Designer/Choreographer
Wes Lincoln R - Costume/Sound Designer
Nicole De Angelis - Playwright/Sound Designer
Spencer Schunk - Playwright/Dramaturge
Josh Johnston - Playwright/Actor

It's very nice to meet you.
 
Over the past few years, our group members have created pieces canvassing such topics as: Biblical reinvention, cannibalism, rave culture, Canadian serial killers, nuclear family dynamics, the surrealist movement, the Earths carrying capacity, vaginas and general raging against the machine.

For us, Fringe is a HUGE opportunity to put what we have learned thus far to work in the real world. ‘HACK’ is our first foray into real life and we think you’ll enjoy it. We've got crazy obsessions, green jello, puppet therapy, hypnotism, bizarre desire, comic relief... this play has everything you never thought you would see onstage!

Still with me?

While we will do anything for our art (see above video), we can only get so far for free. A trip to Montreal, for example… not free. We need to move the six of us, our unbelievably talented and attractive actors (Sheri Godda, Tyler Hagemann and Rose Tuong), our exquisite lighting designer (Garrett Levine) AND our entire set from Toronto to Montreal in order to get this play in front of our adoring fans (positive planning for the win!).

SO the first $800 raised will go to getting us on our stage, but where will anything over that go you wonder? The answer, dear internet, is simple. It will go straight into making this show as thrilling as humanly possible.
That means:
creating costumes 
building the set
lighting the show
LOUD NOISES (sound design)
advertisements/ flyers/ posters (we love posters, posters are key... I'm gonna say posters one more time... POSTERS)
and all of the Fringe fees 

As you can see, this is quite a feat. We could do it alone, but only if we all gave up food and shelter for the next few months so please, help us out.

If you can't donate at this time, please feel free to share the campaign via facebook, twitter, email, carrier pigeon, smoke signal, interpretive dance, or however your little heart desires. Everything helps.

Follow the progress of this show on our blog or on twitter.

THANK YOU SO MUCH FROM THE BOTTOM OF ALL OF OUR HEARTS (we have very deep hearts, so that is a lot of love coming your way)

A bientot Montreal!

story:
Dear Friends,

Hi!  I'm Adyana de la Torre, the Artistic Director/Producer of Ticket 2 Eternity Productions. Thanks for stopping by!

Our company, cast and crew are so excited to have been selected to perform 2 full-length plays by our Writer in Residence, Matthew Ethan Davis in 2 major theatre festivals in NYC.  Fringe NYC International Theatre Festival and the Midtown International Theatre Festival. We are truly honored to have been chosen. We have been waiting for the opportunity to come along to produce these plays for 3 years now...the wait is over.  But we need your help!

So... the scripts are final, the cast chosen, the crew settling into place and we're ready to rehearse!  

As you can imagine, we did not anticipate having this wonderful opportunity for not just one, but two plays being produced this summer. With the double production comes double the expenses. Your generous donations will ensure that we can properly produce these 2 wonderful plays, Falling Awake & Ticket to Eternity!

Your contribution - no matter what the dollar amount will make a real difference!

Falling Awake by Matthew Ethan Davis will appear in the Midtown  International Theatre Festival from July 21-August 5, 2012. www.midtownfestival.org

Ticket to Eternity by Matthew Ethan Davis will appear in the FRINGE NYC INTERNATIONAL THEATRE FESTIVAL from August 10-26, 2012. www.fringenyc.org.

The Players:

Brendan Wahlers, Adyana de la Torre, Jay Rivera, Sara Minerd, Julia Kelly and Laris Macario

The Crew:

Matthew Ethan Davis - Playwright

Erica McLaughlin - website Design

Javier Perez-Karam - Director of Ticket to Eternity

Dennis Yeuh Yeh Li- Production Assistant

Brett Thomas Miro - Associate Producer

Sherry Martinez - Costumer 

Adyana de la Torre - Director of Falling Awake

Prospect Photography:  Photography

Adyana de la Torre: Company Director/Producer

Jackie Filer: Stage Manager for Falling Awake

Angela Rodriguez- Assistant Director for Ticket 2 Eternity 

Michael Kaufer- Bookkeeper

William Christian- Videographer

 

What We Need:

Rehearsal space: $1000

Festival Fees: $ 1200

Advertising: $300

Props: $200

Sets: $800

Costumes: $500

Crew: $1000


The Impact

This summer opportunity goes beyond just as an opportunity to perform. Being produced in these two festivals can really propel our theatre company to the next level with coverage from press, reviews, new patrons, potential sponsorships, and other opportunities to have these plays produced Off-Broadway in a larger theatre with an extended run.  

As well as an opportunity for potential representation by agents for the actors and our Writer. These productions could lead to more work, more opportunities, more visibility and credibility.

It could also mean an opportunity for funding for a future home for our theatre company.  

Next on our wish list:

A permanent rehearsal/meeting space. $ 30,000 for our first year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help!

Help us spread the word by using the IndieGoGo Share Tools.

Follow us on FACEBOOK at www.facebook.com/ticket2eternityproductions

Follow us on TWITTER at www.twitter.com/tick2eternity

Visit our website for more company info at www.ticket2eternityproductions.com

Attend our BAR NIGHT on Friday, June 22 at 6-9pm at Village Pourhouse, 64 3rd ave, btw 10th/11th st, NYC. First round of drinks FREE.  15% of bar sales go towards the festivals. www.funbars.com.

 

THANK YOU!

From Ticket 2 Eternity Productions, Adyana de la Torre, Brendan Wahlers, Matthew Ethan Davis, Jay Rivera, Erica Lauren McLaughlin, Erin Ronder, Laris Macario - we thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

story:
Summary of the Project:

My name is Bobby Halvorson and I am a student at California Institute of the Arts. I am earning a Doctorate of Musical Arts in music performance and composition. As my final performance presentation project I, with the help of my collaborator Daniel Alexander Jones, am producing an original musical based on "The Marvelous Land of OZ" by L. Frank Baum. I hesitate to use the word "musical," however.

What we intend to create is not a piece that resembles the classic musicals of Rogers and Hammerstein or Andrew Lloyd Weber that many people are familiar with. We wish to create a physical environment (the Land of OZ) that the audience may step in and out of. The colors, characters, sounds, and biospheres will all define this universe and upon entering the space in which the performance will be held, audience members will be transported. In other words, there will be no fourth wall or separation between the audience and the elements of OZ. Audience members will be encouraged to sit or stand or walk about the space as they wish.

There will be a linear narrative written by Jones that is based on the storyline of the book. Musical numbers will be performed throughout, linking the journey together. There will be a chamber music ensemble of approximately 9 members, a mixed choir of approximately 15 singers and a cast of around 8-10. Most of the personnel will be either currently enrolled CalArts students or CalArts affiliated. 

This presentation is incredibly important as it will be the jumping off point of future productions. After this presentation, which we plan to document in its entirety, we plan to present this piece to multiple theaters both nationally and internationally and therefore we'd like your help in making it as wonderful as possible.

The show you will be contributing to will be presented globally and your help in creating the best product we can achieve is paramount.

 

What We Need:

We are hoping to achieve a goal of $3,000 by March 1st, 2013. What we need is your personal contribution to help us fund this work. Your donation will be going to the following:

  • costume and set design and the materials needed for each
  • lighting design/equipment rental
  • sound system rental and set up
  • honorarium for outside contributors (lighting board technician, sound engineer, costume and set designers, projectionist, etc.)
  • advertising and promotion
  • piano tuning

The Impact

This project will completely alter the way musical theater is viewed. Since the days of Rogers and Hammerstein, musical theater has become a tired genre as opposed to an innovative form of art. Opera and musical theater have been divided into two seperate forms of music for theatrical purposes. What is the reason for this? Traditionally, opera is entirely sung whereas musical theater makes use of spoken dialogue. Aside from these characteristics, the music in musical theater has tended to lean more toward popular idioms and the singing styles employed are not "classical" in style. Why can't musical theater make use of non-traditional harmonies and song structure? Why can't musical theater explore the farthest reaches of the human voice and all its capabilities to create deeper character dynamic? We plan to further the genre of musical theater so it doesn't get stuck in the mud. New ideas are preeminant and to make these ideas realities, we need your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

GET THE WORD OUT! Pass this along to your friends and those who would be interested in helping to fund this project.

Create a work yourself inspired by the desire to bring musical theater back to life!

 

The presentations will be held the 26th and 27th of April, 2013 in the Butler Building at California Institute of the Arts.

story:
Aerobics finally has its day

Broadway has taken on so many important subjects: mental illness, the French Revolution, flying nannies.  But when has it ever dared to venture into the unsung world of the 1980's group fitness?

Inspired by the cult-classic youtube clip, the Crystal Light National Aerobics Championship hosted by Alan Thicke, developed by a team of some of the sharpest, buffest writers in the game, Spandex now has the chance to step-kick its way onto the Off-Broadway stage.  But we need your help to get there.
 
If we raise the funding, we will open at the new 777 Theatre, just off Times' Square, for three glistening weeks, May 10th-26th, 2013.  Please reach into that fanny pack, and help us achieve this goal. 
 
It could be the most worthwhile thing you've done since breakfast. 

Here's the Routine

  • Putting up an off-Broadway show requires a budget of $45,000.  We're raising as much as we can through partnerships and sponsorshps but we won't come close to what's needed.
  • Every dollar contributed will go towards theatre rental, actors, designers, crew, head bands, leg warmers, etc.
  • Contribute at the 2-pack, 4-pack, 6-pack, or Richard Simmons levels and get fantastic rewards, such as clothing, NYC tours, and your own personal fitness session.

Spandex the Musical

Burn it.

Spandex the Musical
Burn it.

story:
The Birth of Birthday Sax

The time was the 80's.  The place was New Jersey.  A solo saxophone played in the distance.* A child was born to a German father and an American mother.  That child was Tim Girrbach.  And little did anyone know that this combination would inspire Tim to create his character Manheim (based on his German father) and the show "Birthday Sax," known in some circles as "I Wanna Sax You Up!"
 
*slight fabrication for impact

The Impact

We are presenting a 1-night only fully-realized production of "Birthday Sax" at Ars Nova, as part of their fantastic ANT FEST.  There will be Manheim.  There will be his Frauleins.  There will be The Garden State Sax Quartet. And of course there will be all of your favorite 1980's movie soundtrack songs!

What We Need

As most of you probably know - puttin' on a show ain't cheap!  Even though it is a 1-night event, we still need everything we would for a longer run.  We will use these fabulous contributions for costumes, props, music, rehearsal space, and more!  We will also be paying our cast and creative team a little something for their hard work. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every contribution will help and we are not asking a lot.  If you can't give $25, give $10.  If you can't give $10, send this link to a friend who might be able to.  Seriously every little bit will add up and help us greatly.  And whatever you do, don't forget to buy your ticket at Ars Nova for June 8th!

story:
Reverend Billy and the Stop Shopping Gospel Choir

The Church of Stop Shopping, along with Reverend Billy, is a New York City based radical performance community, with 45 performing members and a congregation in the thousands. We are anti-consumerist gospel shouting, earth loving activists and have worked with communities on 4 continents defending land, life, and imagination from reckless development and environmentally destructive practices.  Learn more about our work at www.revbilly.com.

Sermon and Song at the Temple at Burning Man

Burn-a-lujah!! The Stop Shopping Choir is honored to be asked to perform at the Temple by artists David and Maggie Best and the Temple's community of artists and builders. The Temple is constantly active over the week of Burning Man.  People journey there with their mementos from those loved ones who have died in the last 12 months.  The entire week, any time of day or night, mourners can be found at the Temple gazing into photographs, reading messages, tacking up a bit of cloth or a feather.  Then on Sunday night, the last night of Black Rock City each year, the Temple is burned down to the embers within a ring of tens of thousands of silent mourners. 

The Burning Man 2012 theme is Fertility.  This year, the ones who have lost their mothers will have special care.  The "Temple of Juno" honors the love and the work of mothers, and honors our sorrowing for our mothers when they pass from us.

The Mother Earth is under attack by corporations and governments like never before.  The power of creativity is profited-from, but unacknowledged by the economy based on Consumerism and Militarism.  The present leaders cannot seem to stop subsidizing fossil fuel habits, and CO2 rises every week. This is the era of the extinction of living things.  We carry around with us the threat to the lives of our children.  We pretend that we will never live to see the motherlessness of the Silent Spring. 

We will come to the end of this year's Burning Man on the high desert playa and prepare for the 51 weeks back in cities, traffic, and computers with a pledge to become radical Earth warriors.  The Temple of Juno will be the mother of our courage! 

Partner with Us in our Mission to Black Rock City!

Please join us in bringing the Stop Shopping gospel to Burning Man this year! We are sending 27 active members of our Church to perform with Reverend Billy at the Temple.  Your support will help us cover our camp infrastructure, performance equipment, food, and desert-survival provisions for all traveling performers. 

Our budget is as follows:
 
Food and water:  $2040 (for 22 performers and 5 members of the Church) 
 
Shade infrastructure for the Camp:  $750
 
Power generator and fuel:  $650
 
Music equipment for the desert:  $500 (keyboard and vocal amps)
 
Camp supplies (gray water system, lights/electronics, chairs, bike rack):  $1060
 
Total Funds Needed:  $5000

story:
A Little More Story

I have been making performance in Philadelphia since I came here to study at the Headlong Performance Institute in 2012. My work with Chelsea Murphy has been presented locally and in other cities by FringeArts, JACK, Joe’s Pub DanceNOW, the Effervescent Collective and NoTheme Festival. I received an Independence Fellowship in 2018. My work romances many genres: dance, theater, stand-up comedy, and lecture/demonstration.  I work collaboratively and in daunting isolation. Themes that come up again and again for me are: shame, death, grief, wildness, subversion, childhood and sass. 

From 2012-2015 I was the Artist-in-Residence at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. I taught visual art to children and young adults in the oncology units. This was some of the most meaningful work of my life. This show is in direct response to my experiences at the hospital. It asks the question: what would a child do with paint if no adult ever told them they were doing it wrong? What would a child do if they had all the resources I could give them? This piece is made possible through an Independence Fellowship.

What I Need & What You Need

The money is going towards:

  • a temporary wall to be used as a giant canvas
  • colorful paint to create an original mural every night
  • white paint to cover the mural in between each show
  • white pants, shirts and socks for me every night
  • glitter
  • costumes for the audience
  • treats for the audience
  • unanticipated parking tickets as I load in and out
  • original sculptures and art tokens to be given as gifts

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money, but have some extra stuff laying around in your basement I will take it!

  • white latex house paint
  • vibrant colors of latex paint
  • yards of soft fabric in any color
  • white shirts (small)
  • white pants (small or medium)
  • large household tools like mops, brooms, hammers, paint rollers
  • winter hats
  • white sneakers (size 7.5)
  • latex gloves for deep cleaning

If you have a car and would like to drive me around on last minute errands during August or September that would be a huge help.

If you love to cook and take care I could also use help with meals during the grueling run I imagine this will be.

story:
Short Summary

I'm Ethan Fishbane, the writer and director of "A Presentation by the People of Lake Victory for Our Leader".  This is a new show I've been working on for the past year, and I am so excited to announce it's first showing and run at The Assembly at Judson Memorial Church here in NYC from May 25-31, 2014! I am co-directing this show with a great friend and wonderful collaborator, Jay Eisenberg!  We are so excited to present this piece of art depicting the interactions and lifestyle of the people of Lake Victory, my own vision of the last true communist state on earth.  We are working with an amazing cast and crew, but this show can't happen with you!

We need to raise money to make Lake Victory come to life.  Aside from the ideas and the script, we need to rent rehearsal space, make costumes, assemble promotional materials, and of course pay our incredibly talented cast and creative team!

With your assistance, we not only get to put on this show, which I am so excited to share, we also get to keep asking questions about people, governments and how we see the world.  You can become a part of this dialogue and all it take is as little as one dollar into our campaign!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise money for costumes, set, rehearsal studio rentals, space rentals, properties, lights, sound, and of course to pay our wonderful cast and creative team!

We have some really exciting perks that should pump you up about donating! From our awesome poster designed by Denny Khurniawan, to some amazing original artwork by Jay Eisenberg, to dinner gifted by Jay and I, ourselves!  Everyone gets to be a part of the fun!

The Impact

Last year, I brought my show "ASBA: The American Suicide Bomber Association" to South Africa.  I raised funds through a similar campaign and was so lucky to meet my goal and tour my show to Johannesburg.  Without the kindness and assistance of the global citizens who contributed along the way, I wouldn't have been able to create the discussion I lent way to in South Africa as I did here in NYC. 

My performances are about more than the show itself.  I want to inspire conversation and new understanding of the world.  By donating to this project, you are donating to a book that is just opening.  The impact may not seem outwardly effecting, but the impact you are making will be tremendous! 

By donating, you are sharing in this process with all of us!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign!
Share "A Presentation by the People of Lake Victory for Our Leader" on facebook, instagram and twitter!
Share in the performance itself!

We can't wait to see you there, and in the meantime we will be working hard!

All the best,

Ethan Fishbane and Jay Eisenberg

story:
The Studio Of Performing Arts has been putting performers in the spotlight since 1993. At the end of 2013, the Studio decided it was time to move into their own space and relocated to 805 W. Grand Avenue in Grover Beach. We are excited about our new home and final details include our new flooring in the studios.  Any and all help is greatly appreciated so we can continue to have the youth of five cities shine in the Spotlight.

Thank You From, 

Shannon and Simon Lowrie -Owner

And all the Students, Staff and Families

story:
OUR NEW GOAL IS $5000

We reached our goal for 501c3 and greatly overestimated the time it would take to raise it!!

So here we are with 37 days left in our campaign and now way to end it early to receive our funds. Within 5 days of the campaign starting, we shattered the $1000 mark!! Thanks to the help of so many generous supporters. Since we are unable to collect our funds until the campaign is over and we are not allowed to end the campaign earlier than the time we had initially allotted, we have decided to extend the purpose of the campaign to sponsoring our upcoming season!

Our 2013-2014 Season includes 4 productions:
The Complete History of America (Abridged) - September 27th - October 20th 2013
I Ought To Be in Pictures - January 31st - February 23th 2014
The Irish Curse - March 14th - April 6th 2014
The Authentic Life of Billy the Kid - May 30th - June 22nd 2014

Each of these shows will cost at least $5000 to produce, that includes royalties, advertising, printing, costumes, sets and props.

If we can raise $5000 now to fund our first production we can then rool the ticket sales of that production into the next and so on.

SO OUR NEW GOAL IS $5000!!

We cannot change the price of the original goal here on indiegogo, but there is no cap! Please help us reach this new goal, allowing us the opportunity to produce 4 amazing shows this season!

There are also no caps on your contributions! Although the highest perk value is $50 any amount over that is highly acceptable and greatly appreciated.

ABOUT THE SPOT

THE SPOT opened its doors in February, 2011 with the mission to “enrich the cultural development of our community by producing cutting edge professional theater and offering a performance space to any other local groups in need of a temporary home.” The first full season of shows produced by THE SPOT included: an Original Works Festival, Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead, Tuesdays with Morrie and The Hairy Ape.

Producing Director, Jake McGuire, has built THE SPOT from pure passion, sweat and the a clear vision of creating exciting, cutting edge theater on the Central Coast. He's spent the past year jumping through the hoops necessary to become a 501(c)3 organization to take THE SPOT to the next level and with your help has made that dream come true. Your generous contributions are helping Jake achieve his non-profit status and continue to produce powerful theater in our area.

If you're not able to contribute yourself, please share this campaign with your friends and family.

story:
DESPERATION

Dark Humour Productions is a Chicago-Based Theatre Company that creates and performs new works.  Our current project, "Desperation," is an improvised dramatic one-act play that uses an improvised fight style created by D.H.P.'s Co-Artistic Director and Resident Fight Guy Alex Farrington.  

We are very excited about "Desperation" because it is a project that we haven't heard of before.  The actors will create everything in front of the audience: The characters, the relationships, their stories, and even the fight choreography.  

What We Need & What You Get

Since improvisation allows the actors to create everything they need, costs are pretty minimal.  We're renting a space to rehearse and a space to perform.  

Here's what we're looking at

  • Roughly $300 for rehearsal space
  • About $700 for theatre rentals and insurance

What's in it for you?

We've got some pretty cool gifts on the right hand side.  Check them out!

Where does the money go?

If we don't make our goal Dark Humour will cover the rest of the cost.  If we do make the goal the next $200 goes to Dark Humour, and everything over that gets split evenly between the actors, the director, and the fight guy.

What We're Trying To Do

We really like this project because we're bringing something new to the table.  There is a lot of improv in Chicago, and the bulk of it is comedic.  There are far fewer companies creating dramatic improv, but we don't know of anybody doing it with improvised stage combat.  

Dark Humour has always valued original works, but to us that meant either writing our shows or putting on projects of new playwrights.  Now we're trying to create something we haven't seen before, and to be honest, we think that's really cool.  We're betting that other people will think it is too.  

But I'm Broke!

Trust us.  We're actors.  We've all been there.  If you can't afford to give anything right now we wish you the best.  If you still like our idea and wanna help out, just give us a tweet or a facebook plug.  We really appreciate it.


Desperation will be performed by:
Sam Howard, Alex LeBaron, Oopey Mason, Bryce Read, Dustin Sharpe, Sophie Shrand, and Corinne Wilson

Directed By: Gabe Caruso

Fight Trainer: Alex Farrington

story:
Onion Creek runs December 2-11, 2011 at Son of Semele Theatre in Silver Lake, Los Angeles.  The play is presented by Padua Playwrights Productions in association with Son of Semele Ensemble.  The cast features: Mark Bramhall, Bridget Flanery, David Haley, Julanne Chidi Hill and Mona Lee Wylde.

 

 All donations are tax deductible.


The Play

It is the summer of 1873 in Del Valle, Texas and former slave owner White Poppa is dead.  Upon his passing, Nathaniel Haws, his mixed-race virgin son, encounters Minerva Simmons, an Irish sojourner who soon begins working on the orchard.  When Nat's relationship with Minnie moves from the field to the ranch house, their growing intimacy teaches both generations of Haws men the true meaning of intimacy, legacy, and identity.


Our Story

Onion Creek was first developed by playwright Roger Q. Mason under the guidance of Pulitzer-winner Lynn Nottage at Princeton University in 2007.  It received workshop presentations at Ensemble Studio Theatre/LA and The Dramatists Guild.  In 2011, Mason was invited to present the play at the award-winning Son of Semele Theatre in Silver Lake, Los Angeles. 


Roger Q. Mason is a Los Angeles-based playwright, director, and producer.  He received an AB in English and Theatre from Princeton University; he is currently pursuing a MA in English from Middlebury College.  His plays have been featured at such venues as McCarter Theatre Center, Ensemble Studio Theatre/LA, and Theatre of NOTE.  For this project, Mason will collaborate with Padua Playwrights Productions, a lauded theatre company founded in 1978 by Obie-winning playwright/poet Murray Mednick. 


The project will be supervised by Padua's artistic director, Guy Zimmerman, under whose direction the company has staged over 25 productions of new plays - including three in New York City and three abroad - garnering a host of LA Weekly, Ovation, Garland and Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle Awards.  June Carryl will direct.  A member of The Actors Studio and Director's Lab, Ms. Carryl has worked with such companies as The Blank Theatre Company, Pianofight Productions, and San Francisco Shakespeare Festival.   


The Impact

Mason's work utilizes theatre to illuminate "forgotten moments in remembered times" - hidden history that tradition has silenced or cast aside.  Over the course of two weekends, Onion Creek will present powerful, thought-provoking theatre that asks us to remember where we've been so we know where we are going. 


What We Need & What You Get

This is a small production, costing under $10,000.  While we have received generous initial backing, which is dedicated to rental fees, actors' stipends, and honorariums for designers and other creative staff, we still need to raise an additional $2,500 to make this production possible.  The monies earned through this fundraiser will finance set building materials, costumes, and props for the play.  Please review our exciting perks to see how we can thank you for your generous contribution.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you or someone you know can help build the set or assist with promotion of the play, we'd love to speak with them.  Please write to info@onioncreekplay.com.  Thanks!

story:
Resonance Theatre: blurring the lines between opera, movement, instrumental music, multimedia and song

“When the music and the characters are flawlessly synchronized, the opera develops
an emotional force that movies and plays cannot match.”  
~ Bruce Beresford, Film Director

We couldn’t agree more. We keep it real.
We keep it simple.  We tell stories.

We are passionate about a local, non-commercial approach to theatre.  The goal for our productions: relevant, accessible and affordable theatre.  We will feature the finest talent available and take an interdisciplinary approach at every appropriate opportunity.  The space in which we perform may not always be conventional but it will always reflect the work.  

We are also dedicated to creating an Education and Community Outreach programme which offers members of the community an opportunity to be a part of the process and collaborate on work of their own.

Your support is critical if this approach is to continue to succeed.  

What's on the menu for our 2013 season (July - August):

THE APPERITIF:  Beginnings - A Staged Song-Cycle ~ featuring our Resonance Artists in Training... the 'Rats', if you will!  

THE MAIN COURSE:  La Traviata ~ G. Verdi

LIGHTER FARE:  Iolanthe ~ Gilbert & Sullivan 

FOR THE KIDS:  Little Red Riding Hood ~ Tom Smail (remount of our much adored production from July 2011)

DESSERT:  Drawing a Blank: Portrait of a Smokin' Serial Killer ~ R.K. Finch

story_txt:
Resonance Theatre: blurring the lines between opera, movement, instrumental music, multimedia and song
“When the music and the characters are flawlessly synchronized, the opera developsan emotional force that movies and plays cannot match.”  ~ Bruce Beresford, Film Director
We couldn’t agree more. We keep it real.We keep it simple.  We tell stories.
We are passionate about a local, non-commercial approach to theatre.  The goal for our productions: relevant, accessible and affordable theatre.  We will feature the finest talent available and take an interdisciplinary approach at every appropriate opportunity.  The space in which we perform may not always be conventional but it will always reflect the work.  
We are also dedicated to creating an Education and Community Outreach programme which offers members of the community an opportunity to be a part of the process and collaborate on work of their own.
Your support is critical if this approach is to continue to succeed.  
What's on the menu for our 2013 season (July - August):
THE APPERITIF:  Beginnings - A Staged Song-Cycle ~ featuring our Resonance Artists in Training... the 'Rats', if you will!  
THE MAIN COURSE:  La Traviata ~ G. Verdi

FOR THE KIDS:  Little Red Riding Hood ~ Tom Smail (remount of our much adored production from July 2011)

story:
Short Summary

  • We are Unified Theatre Company (UTC)! We are Lynchburg based, but touring, and our goal is to create immersive theatre and help raise money for other non-profits partnered with our productions!
  • We are raising money for our upcoming season! This season is full of shows that entertain and send an important message. 
  • With the contributions, we would be able to fully secure our season, and successfully put on the shows within the season! This would allow us to continue to help raise money for the non-profits we partner with and deliver insightful messages to our audience. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are asking for $2,500. This would go towards securing and making payments for the rights to the two musicals in our season! Anything additional to our goal will be used to pay for venues to perform shows at, and other things like costumes and props!
  • We partner with Non-profits that relate to the theme of our shows in order to raise money and awareness for specific causes!
  • If our entire goal is not reached, the amount raised will still go towards securing the rights to our two musicals.

The Impact

  • We would love to bring more theatre to people all around Virginia! The arts are therapeutic for many people. We want to bring as many opportunities as possible for people to see AND participate in the theatre!
  • Our last season ended on September 28, 2019, with UTC's first sold-out show (Dog Sees God)! We had a successful 2019 season and were able to build up our relationship with local audience members and patrons and show how much theatre means to us! 
  • At the end of the day, we want to encourage people to think outside of the box, and spread awareness for specific causes through theatre. We want to use theatre as a tool to educate and help people put themselves in someone else's shoes!

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge so far has been exposure and getting our name out there! It has been difficult to get our name to be instantly recognizable, but the more shows and events we do, the more recognized we are!

  • These challenges are fixable! The more events and shows UTC puts up, the more publicity we get! We've already made a step in the right direction by selling out our most recent show!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Sharing our campaign and story helps immensely! 
  • You can use indiegogo's share tools to help us out!

We partner with Non-profits that relate to the theme of our shows in order to raise money and awareness for specific causes!
If our entire goal is not reached, the amount raised will still go towards securing the rights to our two musicals.


The Impact

We would love to bring more theatre to people all around Virginia! The arts are therapeutic for many people. We want to bring as many opportunities as possible for people to see AND participate in the theatre!
Our last season ended on September 28, 2019, with UTC's first sold-out show (Dog Sees God)! We had a successful 2019 season and were able to build up our relationship with local audience members and patrons and show how much theatre means to us! 
At the end of the day, we want to encourage people to think outside of the box, and spread awareness for specific causes through theatre. We want to use theatre as a tool to educate and help people put themselves in someone else's shoes!

Our biggest challenge so far has been exposure and getting our name out there! It has been difficult to get our name to be instantly recognizable, but the more shows and events we do, the more recognized we are!
These challenges are fixable! The more events and shows UTC puts up, the more publicity we get! We've already made a step in the right direction by selling out our most recent show!

You can use indiegogo's share tools to help us out!

story:
About Me?

My name is Eshe Shukura. I am currently a third year student at Hampshire College studying theater with an emphasis on acting and social justice. Theater has been a part of my life since the age of 11and I've always had a deep emotional connection to the art form. I believe theater can change the world. Theatre explores human nature and behavior. It bridges communities, tells untold stories, and weaves together a loose sense of humanity. I want to work in theater as a career and I dream of one day opening my own theater company that produces new works that challenge the current social order. My theatre company will exist to fully support social justice projects and scholarship.  

Why NTI?

The National Theater Institute (NTI) is a semester-long conservatory style theater program put on by the Eugene O'Neill Theater, a non-profit theater company in Waterford, CT. At NTI, I will have the chance to work with theatre professionals in multiple disciplines of theatre who will provide me the resources and knowledge I need to realize my dreams. At NTI, the learning will stretch beyond the classroom and even the state of Connecticut. A semester at NTI provides students with the unique opportunity of a two-week theater study at St. Petersburg State Theatre Arts Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia. Participating in NTI is a chance that will broaden my cultural outlook and my artistic bank.

Why Fund This?

As a student of color, I notice the absence of students like me in advanced theatre programs outside of the college classroom. I applied to NTI as a chance to advance my studies in theater, and it is an incredible honor to have been accepted to this highly competitive program. I believe money should never be obstacle when a person is advancing their education and pursuing their dreams.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share my link with at least five people. Send me information about other funding opportunities

story:
About Indah and the Project

Indah M. Walsh is a choreographer, dancer, and teacher.  She is in the MFA dance program at NYU Tisch.  As a second year MFA student at NYU Tisch, she has been awarded a Graduate Assistantship in Video for the Department of Dance.  Prior to pursuing graduate studies, Indah completed a BFA in dance from SUNY Purchase College Conservatory of Dance and continues to choreograph and present work in New York, California, and Taiwan.

This campaign will make it possible for Indah to create a work in collaboration with a percussionist.  This October, Indah will present a new group work as part of the Second Avenue Dance Company Concert.  For this piece she will collaborate with fellow NYU students; two lighting designers and five dancers.  With enough of your contributions, she will have the means to work with a live percussionist!

Being in New York City surrounded by talented and passionate artists it's a shame there aren't more collaborations!  If you are a supporter of dance and music collaborations please consider making a contribution to this campaign.  

What We Need

This project will involve 10 rehearsals with the musician and 2 performances for an estimated cost of $700.  Any amount of contributions will help make the collaboration happen.

Why Contribute to Dance and Music Collaborations?

Working with live musicians and having music made specifically for a dance piece offers possibilities for a full, dynamic work of art.  It allows for the work to develop in ways that may be limited by pre-recorded music.  Collaborating with others also creates an environment for artistic and personal growth for all involved including the dancers, musician, and choreographer.  

Other Ways You Can Help

It's understandable that not everyone can contribute financially to this campaign.  Other ways to contribute would be to share this information with some one and/or attend live dance performances.  Our performance will be October 17-19 at 8pm at 111 2nd avenue New York, NY in the 5th Floor Theater.

story:
Find us on FACEBOOK

&
Visit us at Studio620.org!

Every Christmas Story Ever Told- What is it??

Every Christmas Story Ever Told (and then some) is a 90 minute madcap romp through the holiday season.

Written by Michael Carleton, Jim FitzGerald & John K Alvarez with an Original Song by Will Knapp.


This show has it all: A Christmas Carol, It's A Wonderful Life, The Grinch, The Nutcracker and even the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade! You name it, it's in the show! It will leave you laughing harder than spiked egg-nog, that's our guarantee!! YULE CRACK UP!


From the Living Room to the Studio...

Several Christmases ago, two best buddies had the wonderfully unique idea to stage a Christmas "Spectacular" in one of their houses. It featured thousands of manually operated dancing Christmas Lights set to original music as well as a bunch of Christmastime standards- it was called "Lights of Joy". From this humble beginning came the next installment, the following Christmas. This one featured an original storyline combining elements from The Nutcracker & A Christmas Carol (ie: a scene was shared between Ebenezer Scrooge and the Drosselmeyer). As time went on, the quality of their shows increased until they reached the inevitable, stumbling upon the exhilarating script that was: Every Christmas Story Ever Told in 2008. Thus marking the first production under their new title- Masters' Theatre Group. This performance took place at Grace Lutheran Church and School with minimal production value- our name was fresh and, with that, the word had not yet reached the masses. Our support team, while minimal received the show with great gusto and inspired us to keep going!


We're back and better than ever! A holiday homecoming of sorts, several artists are coming from their current locations in New York and all around Florida to put on a show that will take Masters Theatre Group to a new level! We, at MTG, consistently strive to deliver the highest quality in innovative, original theatre and it is only made possible by the generous contributions from people like you. The future of MTG is dependent upon YOU- our supporters! Theatre is very important to all of us and it is a very important piece of our culture- it is a valid means of communication and storytelling, it is an escape from everyday life and the magic of theatre comes alive when friends, family and strangers are able to bond over a single event. 


THE TEAM


Alexander Whittenberg is a co-founder of Masters Theatre Group. Native of St.Petersburg, he is a proud graduate of the Pinellas County Center for the Arts (Class of 2010) and a current student at the Conservatory of Theatre Arts at SUNY Purchase where is working towards a BFA in Scenic Design. He is an Artistic Associate of the Studio @ 620 and veteran to the local arts scene having worked on productions for Studio @ 620, S.P.L.T., The Academy of Ballet Arts and more. He recently completed work as a Props Designer at Interlochen Center for the Arts in MI for the productions of "Jane Eyre" and "Carousel". Some favorite performance credits include: Me and My Girl, Picasso at the Lapin Agile, Into the Woods and, of course, the original St.Petersburg production of "Every Christmas Story Ever Told". Some favorite design credits include Scenic Design for Elephant Man at PCCA and Shel's Shorts, A Long Day's Journey into Night and Knives in Hens- all here at the Studio. He is also the proud co-founder of the Pinellas County Center for the Arts Improvisational Comedy Troupe. In New York, he's collaborated with William Joseph Stribling on a couple projects- a hit short film entitled "Break A Leg" and another short, produced as part of the Long Island Film Festival- "Daisy". Upon his return to school in the Spring, he will be leading the props department on a production entitled, "Loves Fire". He thanks his family for their unending support and everyone who has brought him this far in life---this show is for you! Thanks for your support and Merry Christmas! You can reach Alex, always, at: A.Whittenberg@Purchase.edu or visit www.imdb.com/name/nm4531937/


Christopher Futch is a co-founder of Masters Theatre Group. A native of St. Petersburg, FL, Chris graduated from the IB Program at St. Petersburg High School, and received his bachelorï¿½s degree in Political Science and Applied Economics from Florida State University. He is currently working towards his Masterï¿½s degree in Higher Education at FSU. Chris has performed in many shows over the years, including Les Miserables , Guys and Dolls, How to Succeed in Business without Really Trying, Songs for a New World, Footloose, Fiddler on the Roof, and The Complete Works of Shakespeare Abridged. He would like to thank you for your support of our efforts to spread the Christmas cheer!


George Kielty (Actor in ECSET) is a senior performance theatre major at the Pinellas County Center for the Arts at Gibbs High School. You may have seen him on the 620 stage before as Katurian in The Pillowman, or as a cameo in Vesuvius. He is very excited to be working with Mr. Whittenberg again, and Mr. Futch for the first time. He hopes you enjoy this wonderful christmas-y show. After high school, he plans to attend Florida State University for theatre, but he doubts this will be the last you see him on the local stage!


William Joseph Stribling (Projectionist) is a senior at NYU Tisch School of the Arts double-majoring in Film & TV Production and Dramatic Literature, where he has written, directed and produced numerous films. A St. Petersburg native, Stribling is no stranger to the Studio @620, where he is an Artistic Associate. In August of 2011, Stribling directed the world premiere production of the play Vesuvius by Michael L. Piel as a part of the Inkies Summer Repertory. He also directed a production of Shel's Shorts by Shel Silverstein at the Studio @620 and has appeared on stage at the Studio @620 as Dennis in This Is Our Youth (Inkies) in Art by Yasmina Reza as Marc. Stribling recently completed a short film entitled "Break A Leg" which premiered at the TriBeCa Grand Hotel (owned by Robert DeNiro) in June and has been screened as official selections of the Oundle International Film Festival in England, The Black Bear Film Festival in Pennsylvania, and The Orlando Film Festival in Florida.  Stribling spent the fall semester of 2010 in Dublin, Ireland participating in Tisch's screenwriting intensive, in which time he wrote his first feature-length screenplay. Stribling is currently directing a TV pilot entitled "Lift Off!" as a part of his advanced level studies at NYU and will go on to make his thesis film in the spring. He is also the author of two other NYU thesis films currently in production, the first entitled Dan The Man (directed by Bobby Johnson) and the second is currently untitled (directed by David Sabshon). Stribling is slated to direct his first feature film in May/June of 2012, produced by Jonathan Weisbrod and written by renowned author and photographer judywhite entitled "Lies I Told My Little Sister."  In the spring of 2011, Mr. Stribling designed projection and video for Orange Grove Dance Company's production of Verona in Brooklyn. He is a graduate of the Pinellas County Center for the Arts at Gibbs High School (Musical Theatre, Eikon winner). Favorite roles include "Francis Flute" in A Midsummer Night's Dream (8 O'Clock Theatre), "Cornelius Hackl" in Hello, Dolly! (PCCA), "John Proctor" in The Crucible (PCCA), "Officer Lockstock" in Urinetown (Palladium), and "Carney" in Biloxi Blues (SPLT). After graduating NYU, Stribling hopes to attend a graduate program in California and pursue a career in the film industry. Contact him atwilliam.stribling@nyu.edu or visit: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4490351/


Mina Asayesh-Brown (Stage Manager)- Mina Asayesh-Brown is a senior in the IB program at St. Petersburg High School and the president of Troupe 2559. She directed productions of MASH and Urinetown last year at St. Pete High and is currently directing Troupe 2559's District One Act. She has previously worked at the Studio@620 as a part of Knives in Hens and the Inkies Summer Repertory. She is also a student editor and the film critic for the St. Petersburg Times' high school publication tb-two*. She would like to thank Alex for the opportunity, her friends for their support, and the entire cast and creative team.


Anthony Gervais (Creative Consultant) Anthony L. Gervais is a Junior Musical Theatre major at the Pinellas County Center for the Arts. He was recently seen as Banquo in Macbeth and Beadle Bamford in Sweeney Todd. He first worked with Masters Theatre Group in It's A Wonderful Afterlife: A Christmas Mystery. In 2010, he co-founded the DAGs Theatre Company and co-directed a production of the Pillowman, in which he played Ariel. He would like to thank Alex, Chris, and the entire cast and crew. Happy holidays!


Help Us Spread the Holiday Cheer!

In order to produce a fully staged production, like this one, there are several elements. Sets, Costumes, Props, Marketing, Royalties, etc. The value of the production is focused a great deal on the quality of these elements which is, in turn, the purpose of your contributions. Please, by no means, feel obligated to donate: WE UNDERSTAND! However, should you feel the desire to assist us in reaching our goal- WE HAVE PRIZES! Check 'em out below!

What will You get?

Stocking Stuffer (Anything from $1.00 to $24.99)

As A Token of Our Appreciation, your name will be listed in our program as a contributor.


The "Elf" Package ($25-$49)

You'll receive...

-a single ticket to (1) performance of your choice

-Your name listed a contributor in our program 


The "Rudolph" Package ($50-$74)

You'll receive...

-Two tickets to (1) performance of your choice

-Your name listed as a contributor in our program AND said during the pre-show announcement 

-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!


The "Santa" Package ($75-$99)

You'll receive...

-Three front-row tickets to (1) performance of your choice

-Your Name in the Program AND said during the pre-show announcement

-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!

-Access to the VIP Dessert Party with the cast following the performance!


The "Partridge in a Pear Tree" Package ($100 and up)

You'll receive...

-Four front-row tickets to (1) performance of your choice

-Your Name in the Program AND said during the pre-show announcement

-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!

-The opportunity to be a part of the show! (Voluntary)

-VIP Dessert Party with the cast following the performance!



Other Ways YOU Can Show Your Support!

Please share this campaign with anyone who know who might have an interest in the project! Word of Mouth plays a HUGE part in the success of events like this.

Come see what all the hype is about, for yourself:

Every Christmas Story Ever Told will give 2 Performances Only!

December 27th, 2011 @ 7:00pm

&

"Pay What You Can" Night
December 28th, 2011 @ 7:00pm 
(featuring Post-Show Talkback)

The Studio @ 620 is located at 620 First Avenue South, St.Petersburg, FL
You Can Visit Them on the Web @ Studio620.org

Tickets for the Tuesday Performance are priced as follows:
General Admission: $10.00
Military, Student (with ID) and Senior: $5.00

For any further inquiries, please E-Mail us at ECSET2011@Gmail.com
