He would like to thank you for your support of our efforts to spread the Christmas cheer!

George Kielty (Actor in ECSET) is a senior performance theatre major at the Pinellas County Center for the Arts at Gibbs High School. You may have seen him on the 620 stage before as Katurian in The Pillowman, or as a cameo in Vesuvius. He is very excited to be working with Mr. Whittenberg again, and Mr. Futch for the first time. He hopes you enjoy this wonderful christmas-y show. After high school, he plans to attend Florida State University for theatre, but he doubts this will be the last you see him on the local stage!

William Joseph Stribling (Projectionist) is a senior at NYU Tisch School of the Arts double-majoring in Film & TV Production and Dramatic Literature, where he has written, directed and produced numerous films. A St. Petersburg native, Stribling is no stranger to the Studio @620, where he is an Artistic Associate. In August of 2011, Stribling directed the world premiere production of the play Vesuvius by Michael L. Piel as a part of the Inkies Summer Repertory. He also directed a production of Shel's Shorts by Shel Silverstein at the Studio @620 and has appeared on stage at the Studio @620 as Dennis in This Is Our Youth (Inkies) in Art by Yasmina Reza as Marc. Stribling recently completed a short film entitled "Break A Leg" which premiered at the TriBeCa Grand Hotel (owned by Robert DeNiro) in June and has been screened as official selections of the Oundle International Film Festival in England, The Black Bear Film Festival in Pennsylvania, and The Orlando Film Festival in Florida.  Stribling spent the fall semester of 2010 in Dublin, Ireland participating in Tisch's screenwriting intensive, in which time he wrote his first feature-length screenplay. Stribling is currently directing a TV pilot entitled "Lift Off!" as a part of his advanced level studies at NYU and will go on to make his thesis film in the spring. He is also the author of two other NYU thesis films currently in production, the first entitled Dan The Man (directed by Bobby Johnson) and the second is currently untitled (directed by David Sabshon). Stribling is slated to direct his first feature film in May/June of 2012, produced by Jonathan Weisbrod and written by renowned author and photographer judywhite entitled "Lies I Told My Little Sister."  In the spring of 2011, Mr. Stribling designed projection and video for Orange Grove Dance Company's production of Verona in Brooklyn. He is a graduate of the Pinellas County Center for the Arts at Gibbs High School (Musical Theatre, Eikon winner). Favorite roles include "Francis Flute" in A Midsummer Night's Dream (8 O'Clock Theatre), "Cornelius Hackl" in Hello, Dolly! (PCCA), "John Proctor" in The Crucible (PCCA), "Officer Lockstock" in Urinetown (Palladium), and "Carney" in Biloxi Blues (SPLT). After graduating NYU, Stribling hopes to attend a graduate program in California and pursue a career in the film industry. Contact him atwilliam.stribling@nyu.edu or visit: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4490351/

Mina Asayesh-Brown (Stage Manager)- Mina Asayesh-Brown is a senior in the IB program at St. Petersburg High School and the president of Troupe 2559. She directed productions of MASH and Urinetown last year at St. Pete High and is currently directing Troupe 2559's District One Act. She has previously worked at the Studio@620 as a part of Knives in Hens and the Inkies Summer Repertory. She is also a student editor and the film critic for the St. Petersburg Times' high school publication tb-two*. She would like to thank Alex for the opportunity, her friends for their support, and the entire cast and creative team.

Anthony Gervais (Creative Consultant) Anthony L. Gervais is a Junior Musical Theatre major at the Pinellas County Center for the Arts. He was recently seen as Banquo in Macbeth and Beadle Bamford in Sweeney Todd. He first worked with Masters Theatre Group in It's A Wonderful Afterlife: A Christmas Mystery. In 2010, he co-founded the DAGs Theatre Company and co-directed a production of the Pillowman, in which he played Ariel. He would like to thank Alex, Chris, and the entire cast and crew. Happy holidays!

Help Us Spread the Holiday Cheer!
In order to produce a fully staged production, like this one, there are several elements. Sets, Costumes, Props, Marketing, Royalties, etc. The value of the production is focused a great deal on the quality of these elements which is, in turn, the purpose of your contributions. Please, by no means, feel obligated to donate: WE UNDERSTAND! However, should you feel the desire to assist us in reaching our goal- WE HAVE PRIZES! Check 'em out below!
What will You get?
Stocking Stuffer (Anything from $1.00 to $24.99)
As A Token of Our Appreciation, your name will be listed in our program as a contributor.

The "Elf" Package ($25-$49)
You'll receive...
-a single ticket to (1) performance of your choice
-Your name listed a contributor in our program 

The "Rudolph" Package ($50-$74)
You'll receive...
-Two tickets to (1) performance of your choice
-Your name listed as a contributor in our program AND said during the pre-show announcement 
-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!

The "Santa" Package ($75-$99)
You'll receive...
-Three front-row tickets to (1) performance of your choice
-Your Name in the Program AND said during the pre-show announcement
-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!
-Access to the VIP Dessert Party with the cast following the performance!

The "Partridge in a Pear Tree" Package ($100 and up)
You'll receive...
-Four front-row tickets to (1) performance of your choice
-Your Name in the Program AND said during the pre-show announcement
-A Playbill and Poster signed by the entire company!
-The opportunity to be a part of the show! (Voluntary)
-VIP Dessert Party with the cast following the performance!


Other Ways YOU Can Show Your Support!
Please share this campaign with anyone who know who might have an interest in the project! Word of Mouth plays a HUGE part in the success of events like this.Come see what all the hype is about, for yourself:Every Christmas Story Ever Told will give 2 Performances Only!December 27th, 2011 @ 7:00pm&"Pay What You Can" NightDecember 28th, 2011 @ 7:00pm (featuring Post-Show Talkback)The Studio @ 620 is located at 620 First Avenue South, St.Petersburg, FLYou Can Visit Them on the Web @ Studio620.orgTickets for the Tuesday Performance are priced as follows:General Admission: $10.00Military, Student (with ID) and Senior: $5.00For any further inquiries, please E-Mail us at ECSET2011@Gmail.com

story:
Women of Color Human Rights Theatre Project

Women of Color Productions, Inc. is a non-for-profit company that produces, creates and presents new plays, classical plays, musicals, performance art pieces, film festivals and TV projects by or about Women of Color.  Our projects are multicultural and deal with the alternative political and cultural perspectives from the past, present and future.

The Women of Color Human Rights Theatre Project will present workshop productions of five one-act plays that deal with human rights issues from the perspective of characters who are women of color.  The three playwrights in our 2011 Playwright Development Program, Kristine M. Reyes, Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza and Jacqueline Wade, began researching and writing their plays in April 2011 under the guidance of dramaturg Maxine Kern.

From the Philippines to Rwanda, Nazi Germany to New York City, these plays span time and place in order to shed light on the many injustices suffered by women of color throughout the world’s history.  While each story is unique, there is a common thread that proves the strength and resiliency of these women characters, even in the face of tremendous hardship.

Your contributions and support will help make this project a reality, and allow these untold stories to finally be heard.

We want to thank everyone who helped us raise $550 in the first campaign.  We have used the money to pay for advertisement for auditions for actors, payment for rental spaces for auditions, down payment to union director-choreographer of the plays, "Lola Luning’s First Steps" and "Mama Africa", payment for Volunteer insurance needed to apply for the Actors’ Equity Showcase status for the  project, and down payment for rehearsal space and other expenses.  We were able to put the money we raised to thus far to great use.  Thank you. 

We still need your generous assistance and support with raising more funds for this wonderful human rights project of one-act plays. This is a project of love for everyone involved in it.   However, it still takes money and your support to make it happen.  These are great plays that need to be seen.  Also, if you know one of the playwrights or other artists involved in the project, please help support them.   They have all worked very hard on it.

Some of our expenses.  include:  raising more money to help pay off the rest of the rental for the theatre, payment of the playbill, raising more money for material for costumes, sets, and props, stipends for actors, final payments for directors’ fees, sound designer’ fee, lighting’ designer’s fee, stage manger’s fee, publicist’s fee, along with other expenses, Your generous contributions will be put to great use. It will help us bring a high quality professional production.  Thank you for all of your support.

We would also like to be able to set aside some free tickets or discounted tickets for organizations of domestic violence, human rights and other such groups who would greatly benefit from the productions. Your support is needed to make all of this possible. Please spread the word.  Once again, thank you for everything.  Your support is very important.

Performances are scheduled for: June 22-24 and June 29-July 1 (additional dates will be added)

 
Location:  Joria Productions Theatre
260 West 36th Street, 3rd Floor
New York, NY
 

THE PLAYS

Lena’s Way by Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza

Lena’s Way is a story about first love in the time of Philippine martial law.  A young girl awakens to the wonders of first love in the midst of violence and chaos.  Her family sabotages that love, her loved one betrays her and what she does next surprises everyone, including herself.

 

Triptych Knot by Jacqueline Wade

Triptych Knot is three short plays that explore what happens to women who are entangled and stuck in a web of unbearable situations when their human rights have been violated or taken away.  One woman is from Rwanda in, Mama Africa, another is from Nazi Germany in, Sterilization, and the third, Mary Theresa is stuck in the New York City Board of Education, "rubber room."   How do they find freedom and survive?

 

Lola Luning’s First Steps by Kristine M. Reyes

As Lola Luning’s worsening dementia causes the trauma of her young life in the Philippines during WWII to resurface, her granddaughter Gabriela struggles to uncover the whole story.  Meanwhile, Lola Luning’s daughter Virgie denies that what’s happening is anything more than the workings of a failing mind, exposing her inability to confront the truth about her own past.  Can Gabriela put together the pieces of her family’s history before Lola Luning falls deeper into dementia and their story is lost forever?

 

THE PLAYWRIGHTS

 

Kristine M. Reyes is a Filipina American playwright raised and based in New York City.   Her one-act plays Quarter Century Baby and Something Blue were produced as part of Diverse City Theater Company’s (DCT) Pearl Project: A Filipino-American Theater Festival at The Clurman Theatre at Theatre Row, July 2010.  In 2011, her 10-Minute play Ready, Aim…Fire! was presented twice, first in Primary Stages Einhorn School of Performing Arts’ (ESPA) Detention Series, and then in The Asian American Women Playwrights Short Play Festival, co-presented by Actors’ Equity Association and Leviathan Lab.  She is a Playwright Associate at DCT where she was a First Draft Fellow for her full-length play Queen for a Day.  Kristine is a Co-Director of the Leviathan Lab Asian American Women Writers Workshop, a Mary Louise Rockwell Scholar at ESPA and a member of The Dramatists Guild. 

 

Jorshinelle Taleon-Sonza holds a Ph.D. in Postcolonial Literature from Drew University and an MFA degree from the Actors Studio at The New School.  Her play The Encounter was produced by Diverse City Theater Company as part of The Pearl Project: A Filipino American Theater Festival at The Clurman Theatre in 2010.  Her trilogy of plays, Migration Blues, was produced by the University Initiative at The New School; and her play, Sandman, was presented at the Circle in the Square Theater as part of the Actors Studio repertory season.  Sonza’s play, Dog Days in America, earned a spot in the University of Massachusetts Southeast Asian Women Playwright Archive.  Cold Flesh, her one-act play, was presented at The Clurman Theatre in 2005.  Other awards include the Philippine Centennial Literary prize for her play, Domestic Helper, and the Palanca Literary Award for her play, Pure.

 

Jacqueline Wade is a graduate of Temple University's Theatre Department and Circle in the Square Two Year Actor's Training Program.  She is a member of the professional acting unions, AEA and SAG.  As a playwright, she has written over 20 plays and performance art pieces, including Juneteenth, A Caribbean Christmas Carol, Phillis Wheatley: The African Muse, Black Panther Women, Women in Comedy, Madam C.J. Walker, The Three Sides of Anita Hill, Miles Davis, Tituba, Garvey's Wives, Zora’s Tales, Nat Turner, Rosa, Mae.  Her plays have been produced at and/or toured many theatres and festivals, including New York International Fringe Festival, LaMaMa ETC., Henry Street Settlement, 40 Queens Libraries, African Meeting House Museum, Mary McLeod Bethune Council House Museum, Old South Meeting House Museum, Harlem School of the Arts, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, New York University, York College Performing Arts Center, Queens Theatre in the Park, Black Spectrum Theatre, Jamaica Arts Center, Sun Dog Productions, Riverbank State Park, Vinnette Carroll Theatre.  Jacqueline’s mission is to bring theatre to the people and to present the side of history that is not often told.  In 2002, Franklin Westbrooks was nominated for an AUDELCO AWARD for his role in her play, Miles Davis.  Jacqueline has been awarded the Walt Disney Pride Rock Grant and the Ethel Surgent Grant for $15,000, which helped to fund the touring of her plays to over 30 culturally deprived schools and institutions in Pennsylvania.  She has worked extensively with youth to motivate them to be positive, to have empowerment, and to be creative through workshops, art-in-education programs, and creative dramatics programs as a director, playwright, and acting teacher.  She was honored by Delta Zeta Chapter in Philadelphia for teaching cultural literacy through drama, and recently awarded a writing residency at Virginia Center for the Creative Arts.  Ms. Wade has directed and produced many plays and is co-founder of Through Her Eyes Women of Color Film Festival.  She is the founder and executive producer of Women of Color Productions, Inc.

story:
My name is Kelsey LaCoste and I will be directing "Proof" by David Auburn this coming fall. I am a senior at the University of Louisiana, and I have been chosen to direct this play as our student directed piece for the Department of Performing Arts. It will be performed at a charming intimate location in Downtown Lafayete, LA. A place with an emerging theater scene. Let me tell you a few things about the play I am putting.

When "Proof" by David Auburn came out in 2000, it was obviously a hit shown by the many awards it received including a Tony Award for best play. "Proof" portrays the struggle of a young woman to be her own person. For a long time, Catherine has been the caretaker of her father and now that he is dead she must find her own way while struggling under his last departing gift, the doubt of her sanity. One reason I believe that this play should be seen today is because there are so many young women and men out there trying to be their own person and not only be seen for what their family does. I have seen this a lot in Lafayette, Louisiana. I want to direct this play for them, the men and the women of this society who still feel under the pressure of their family in one way or another. So they know they aren’t the only ones going through this type of struggle.

The world of this play is the back porch of a rundown Chicago home. It is set in the realism of the character of Catherine and stays in the same location the entire time.

 

The set is the biggest cost of the production so far. Right now it is almost impossible for us to build it without your help.

Set designed by Mario Raymond

In short, $500 will be spent towards the set where the other $200 will be spent on costumes and props.

Now let me tell you about my story and why it means so much to me that this is the best production it can be. I have been in love with theater since 5th grade. I was in the play "Little Abner" and I was hooked. When I got to high school I was displaced to Plano, Texas due to Hurricane Katrina which destroyed my house. In Dallas, where I attended Ursuline Academy, I fell in love with the technical side of theater. Since then I have been involved in everything technical I could be. I worked backstage at the spring productions for my high school in New Orleans, LA when I returned and then came to University of Louisiana at Lafayette to get a Bachelor of Arts with a concentration in Stage Management. In the department I have stage managed six productions, designed the set of one, and worked in the scene shop on the past seven building the set, hanging lights, and helping set up sound equipment.

Now I am on to the area I didn't realize I would love. Directing. Last year I was taking a visual arts class when the last day I could I switched from that into Directing I. I fell in love with it! All of it, working with the actors, being able to mold the play to my vision, and so much more. I have directed four scenes in class and also was a part of the Kennedy Center American College Theater Festival new playwright initiative this year which took a new ten minute, gave it to a director and gave them six rehearsals to get it done. The play I directed went on to the National level of the competition.

With the experience I have gained and being appointed to this task, I know this will be a success. Please donate what you can to my cause. I would love this play to be all it can be.

story:
Endorsed by Bruce Campbell and embraced by Sam Raimi, EVIL DEAD THE MUSICAL is the official live stage show of the cult classic film trilogy. This award-winning fan favorite production has been painting Las Vegas bloody since 2011!

FANS NEEDED TO HELP BRING OFFICIAL EVIL DEAD LIVE CAST RECORDING TO DEATH UNDEATH LIFE!

The creative team behind the longest-running production of the official live stage adaptation of the cult classic film trilogy EVIL DEAD is releasing a live CD.

100% authorized, 100% official, 100% demented!

Because this is a live CD, in addition to the songs from the show, you will hear parts of the actual stage production. Live through the cheers and screams as 20 gallons of fresh warm blood spray over the Splatter Zone! Yell along with Ash's iconic lines, including the "Boomstick" speech! Feel the energy of the show pounding through your earholes as you listen (and sing) along!

PUTTING YOUR CASH TO WORK!

Unlike a purely studio recording, a live CD has some unique elements that require extra care and attention, and we are working to ensure that every aspect of the sound is just right.

We've been hard at work on this project for some time. The initial elements of the project have been recorded including the main performances, the audience participation, the fans, and the studio enhancement elements.

Now we are in the home stretch which includes the editing, post production, and mastering phases of the process - as well as getting the CDs pressed.

We are making sure everything is mixed properly, sounding right, and cleaned up so everyone who gets the CD in their hands can hear the quality of the recording and understand why we took as much time as we did to get this done. We are working with one of the best production facilities in the business to ensure the quality of the CD will be top-notch, and none of this happens for free.

These funds will get the CD edited, mixed, and mastered, and get the first pressing in our hands.

"SHENANIGANS!"

Sure, sure, maybe you've backed a crowd-funded project in the past and never heard back from them. Or maybe the finished product wasn't what you were expecting. This sort of risk is unavoidable when backing this sort of thing. So...how do you know supporting this project will actually lead to a finished product?

1. For starters, we have been performing in Las Vegas since October of 2011 and have been on the Las Vegas Strip for 2 years. We've gone up against some of the biggest shows in town and have stood the test of time, all without their budgets, their stars, or their control of the local media. We've won awards, have fans coming from all over the world to party down with us, and we always deliver on what we set out to do.

2. The main guts of the CD are done. All the recordings and basic structure are in place. This means the heavy lifting is over and the relatively easy part is left. One way or the other, the CD is going to be completed. The more funds we raise, the better the finished product will be.

3. It's EVIL DEAD! This is the next best thing to being at the show, and we are excited to get this CD into our fans' hands!

WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

Once released, this CD will be a limited edition item available exclusively at the venue where our performances take place. This means no matter where you live - as far as away as Australia or as close as California, you need to come to the show in Las Vegas to purchase the CD! You will NOT be able to buy it online, pick it up at Best Buy, or find it for download on iTunes.

If you do not come to our show, supporting this campaign and claiming one of the perks is the only way to get the CD!

Not only will you get the CD, but we will do one step better by making sure it is autographed by the entire cast!

OTHERS WAY TO HELP

We've made it as far as we have thanks to our fans, and we know not everyone can spare any cash to help out. And that's okay too! If you like what we're doing and can't throw in any funds to help, never fear! You can still help!

Simply share this campaign with your friends, family, social network, in-laws, enemies, boss, mother, creepy uncle, or anyone else who may - or may not - give a damn and you'll be helping us create one of the most killer EVIL DEAD projects to come around in a very long time!

PERKS & REWARDS

Just the knowledge that you have helped out is not enough, huh? Being a part of horror history can't get you to open your wallet? That's okay. We completely understand and we have you covered! From personalized "thank you" images from the cast to a full-on private performance of the show for you and 200 of your closest friends, we have levels for all tastes and budgets!

If we reach our goal, we'll add stretch rewards and perks as well!

The Fan! $10
A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.

The Standard! $25
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. An autographed copy of the CD mailed to you. (If you live outside of United States you will be responsible for additional shipping costs)

The Single! $50
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. VIP admission for 1 person on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD, (CD will be given to you the night of the performance.)

The Couple! $100
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. VIP admission for 2 people on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD (CD will be given to you the night of the performance.)

The Group! $200
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. VIP admission for 4 people on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD for you and each of your guests, with a limit of 4 CDs total. (CDs will be given to you the night of the performance.)

Splatter Zone Group! $500
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. Splatter Zone admissions for 4 people on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD for you and each of your guests, with a limit of 4 CDs total (CDs will be given to you the night of the performance.)

Splatter Zone Large Group! $1,000
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. Splatter Zone admissions for 8 people on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD for you and each of your guests, with a limit of 8 CDs total (CDs will be given to you the night of the performance.)

Splatter Zone Party! $5,000
1. A personalized THANK YOU Image from the cast & crew posted online for you to share with the world.
2. Splatter Zone admissions for up to 40 people on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates.
3. 1 Autographed CD for your and each of your guests with a limit of 40 CDs total. (CDs will be given to you the night of the performance.)

The Big Kahuna! $10,000
1. Personalized THANK YOU Image posted online for you to share with the world.
2. Private performance at our venue on a date that you choose from a list of selected performance dates. (Up to 40 Splatter Zone, 150 VIP, & 50 General Admission seats)
3. Q&A with the cast & director after the show.
4. Tour of the set for you & one guest after the show.
5. 1 Autographed CD each for you & your guests with a limit of 40 CDs total. (CDs will be given out at performance.)
story_txt:
Endorsed by Bruce Campbell and embraced by Sam Raimi, EVIL DEAD THE MUSICAL is the official live stage show of the cult classic film trilogy. This award-winning fan favorite production has been painting Las Vegas bloody since 2011!FANS NEEDED TO HELP BRING OFFICIAL EVIL DEAD LIVE CAST RECORDING TO DEATH UNDEATH LIFE!

The creative team behind the longest-running production of the official live stage adaptation of the cult classic film trilogy EVIL DEAD is releasing a live CD.100% authorized, 100% official, 100% demented!

Because this is a live CD, in addition to the songs from the show, you will hear parts of the actual stage production. Live through the cheers and screams as 20 gallons of fresh warm blood spray over the Splatter Zone! Yell along with Ash's iconic lines, including the "Boomstick" speech! Feel the energy of the show pounding through your earholes as you listen (and sing) along!PUTTING YOUR CASH TO WORK!

Unlike a purely studio recording, a live CD has some unique elements that require extra care and attention, and we are working to ensure that every aspect of the sound is just right.

We've been hard at work on this project for some time. The initial elements of the project have been recorded including the main performances, the audience participation, the fans, and the studio enhancement elements.

Now we are in the home stretch which includes the editing, post production, and mastering phases of the process - as well as getting the CDs pressed.

We are making sure everything is mixed properly, sounding right, and cleaned up so everyone who gets the CD in their hands can hear the quality of the recording and understand why we took as much time as we did to get this done. We are working with one of the best production facilities in the business to ensure the quality of the CD will be top-notch, and none of this happens for free.

These funds will get the CD edited, mixed, and mastered, and get the first pressing in our hands."SHENANIGANS!"

Sure, sure, maybe you've backed a crowd-funded project in the past and never heard back from them. Or maybe the finished product wasn't what you were expecting. This sort of risk is unavoidable when backing this sort of thing. So...how do you know supporting this project will actually lead to a finished product?

1. For starters, we have been performing in Las Vegas since October of 2011 and have been on the Las Vegas Strip for 2 years. We've gone up against some of the biggest shows in town and have stood the test of time, all without their budgets, their stars, or their control of the local media. We've won awards, have fans coming from all over the world to party down with us, and we always deliver on what we set out to do.

2. The main guts of the CD are done. All the recordings and basic structure are in place. This means the heavy lifting is over and the relatively easy part is left. One way or the other, the CD is going to be completed. The more funds we raise, the better the finished product will be.

3. It's EVIL DEAD! This is the next best thing to being at the show, and we are excited to get this CD into our fans' hands!WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

Once released, this CD will be a limited edition item available exclusively at the venue where our performances take place. Simply share this campaign with your friends, family, social network, in-laws, enemies, boss, mother, creepy uncle, or anyone else who may - or may not - give a damn and you'll be helping us create one of the most killer EVIL DEAD projects to come around in a very long time!PERKS & REWARDS

story:
Our Story

My Mission is to bring performances that my audience can enjoy. I have always been able to make people laugh and to bring that to life with my writing, imagination, creativity and a great cast I know I can achieve anything. I started writing in grammar school when I wrote my very first play in the 8th grade.  I have been given a gift and know now it is my time to unfold it and share it with the world. My vision is way beyond just stage plays, I am writing my first novel and working in film and television. I would like for my audience to laugh more than cry. The world today is filled with so much violence and hate. My mission is not to remind my audience of death, hurt, pain and unhappy situations, but to make them remember what it was like to be happy and what made them smile. It is always good to focus on ways to address how to stop gun violence, to help our youth, poverty, teen pregnancy, drugs and gangs. I have addressed that through my productions. Sometimes we need our minds to be at ease and I deliver the message that GOD wants me to deliver. Yet and still, my message will be about everyday living with a few heart-felt sadness and tears. But more LAUGHTER to bring you back for more.

"SUGAR DADDY"......55 year old Pete (old man Lofton) wants to get his groove back and he finds three sexy young ladies who are all about the "Benjamins" (Vanilla, Chocolate' and Lexi) that makes him feel like the player that he think he is. His best friend Otis disagrees with his lifestyle and tells him he needs to date women his own age. Pete blows him off and not knowing Otis has a crush on Bianca, gives him the okay to date her. When Bianca runs to Otis for help to rekindle the fire with Pete, she is in store for a big surprise. Pete's nosy roommate Isabelle who loves gossip, is a comical southern woman who gives advice to help Bianca get Pete back, but has a thing for him too. Old man Lofton gets a slap from reality and realizes that Bianca is the right one for him, but when he tries to make things right will he get Bianca back or will it be to late?

The Impact

It will show others that they can build up the courage to pursue their dreams. We all know that in this lifetime, everything cost money. The problem is, there are so many talented people that don't have the finances to even start a production. A lot of us out here know what it's like when you are passionate about your craft and you have family and friends that don't want to support you. Most of them tell you, you are wasting your time and to stop dreaming. Well I have GOD and two young ladies that look up to me each and everyday. My daughters, Ketajia and Tenarra and also my husband Terrance Brown.They believe in me 100%. Just to have them behind me is enough to believe in myself. We all can have people that are truly in the business for their love of the arts, but I like to involve them in something and show them why their hard work, talent and dedication pays off. That shows more appreciation than just a handshake and a thank you.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $3000. This is to help pay for my set design (materials to build the set and furniture), light, sound (mics), audio and video equipment. All the money that I am trying to raise is going towards my production. In hopes that my tickets sell the way that I plan, that will cover everything else. Even if I don't make a profit, it will be a blessing to have successfully put my production on stage. Upon raising my funds, my perks are a good way to show my contributors that I am thankful for their support and that I am giving them a gift also in return. I will gladly show my appreciation.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE spread the word on this network. Share it with your friends and family by tweeting my info and sharing it on facebook. If you have any other ways....email blast, through text messages or any other online network. I would gladly appreciate your support.

story:
Damaged

NYTW 4th Street Theatre

83 East 4th Street, 1st Floor, New York NY


Fine wine, finger foods and silly affairs: this is what occupies the lives of Richard and Kathy as they entertain friends for their own self-interests. Meanwhile upstairs, a secret will fester and grow, threatening to leave nothing left but stale appetizers.


April 4th @ 2:30pm, April 5th at 7:30pm & April 7th at 7:30pm

 

 

 

 Starring: Kathleen Marsh*, Kevin Bohl, Clea Straus Rivera*, Paul Kelly*, Samantha Walsh & Dylan Kammerer

 

(*Actors Appear Courtesy of Actors Equity Association)

 

Dramaturgs: Ellen Joffred 

Production Stage Manager: Steven Rowe


Damaged is a new play written by Simone Marie Martelle, written as her MFA thesis play for Columbia University School of the Arts.  This play was written with the guidance and mentorship of esteemed playwright David Lindsay-Abaire.  


What We Need & What You Get

Columbia University School of the Arts gives each playwright $1500 to produce their thesis show.  While this may seem like a lot, costumes, props, sets and make-up effects are very expensive.  We have estimated that we need at least $3000 to cover the costs of this show. That is why we need your help to raise another $1500!


 

We want to be extremely transparent with you about our finances! Below are the costs that this campaign will cover:

 

  • Prop Food (We need to get fresh food for each performance)
  • Building elements of the set
  • Prop Rental/Purchase (We have a lot of props in this play)
  • Costumes
  • Make-up Effects
  • Designer Honorariums (For our Set Designer, Fight Choreographer, Costume Designer)
  • Actor Union Fees
  • Promotional Material Printing Fees (Costs to print posters, postcards, programs etc)

And of course... we have some perks for all of you that help us

 

  • A thank you in the program and on our website
  • A chance to meet the cast after the show
  • Prime seats reserved for you in the audience
  • Be listed as a Producer to all those who make donations of $100 and up
  • A cast signed poster for donations of $500 and up.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

And of course there is more that you can do to help!

  • Please spread the word to others who would like to support our project financially.
  • Come see our play!
  • And when it will get closer to the show, please spread the word to press and industry.

story:
Our Story

Woody Guthrie Dreams is a play with music about the life, ideas & dreams of America's greatest troubadour, Woodrow Wilson Guthrie, an agitator, a sign painter, and a guitar picker. 


Michael Patrick F. Smith began writing the play in 2002, reading Guthrie's writings, interviewing his buddies, talking to his family and immersing himself in the music. A previous version of the play appeared at Creative Alliance in Baltimore in 2004. Now, after nearly a decade of work, the play will receive it's New York premiere at Theater for the New City on September 8th, 2011.


The Impact

Raising the money that we need through this campaign will mean New York City will be singing Woody Guthrie songs for the entire month of September.  And longer.


What We Need & What You Get

We have already raised over $15,000 from individual donors and through throwing fund raising parties.  We now need $10,000 to cover the rest of our costs.  This campaign will pay for our costumes, the set, as well as our lighting and sound design.  It will cover the modest stipends we are offering to our excellent design team and incredibly talented actors and musicians. This campaign will pay for our fliers and press material so we can get the word out loud and clear about what we believe is a powerful & important project.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell your friends!  We truly believe that this play contributes greatly to the legacy of Woody and we believe Woody's legacy is as important now as it ever was.  Woody's story deserves to be told and the people of this country deserve to hear it.

story:
About the Carnival

The carnival itself is made up of a core group of performers and workers who believe in the value of live entertainment.  They want to bring back the old style carnival shows that used to travel North America bringing entertainment to small towns.  The idea is to bring together performers that have talent and who want to go professional but just need some more experience and take them to towns that have a lack of quality entertainment.  That way both benefit and great times would be had by all. 

The plan is to build great performers and to give them the tools to better promote themselves so that one day they can make a living doing what they love.  We are looking for all types of performers to fill out our roster. Singers, acrobats, magicians, jugglers, musicians, stilt walkers, hula hoopers, fire performers, dancers and anything else that can be put on a stage that will entertain an audience.  All performers get a share of profits made as this is not a business per say, but a cooperative of entertainers.

The Financial Breakdown:

As with all great projects we need to pay for the required equipment and that is why we are here.  We believe that there are people out there, possibly like yourself that want to support good talent and help bring live entertainment to those who don’t always have the chance to experience it.  So, here is what we need to pay for.

The carnival tent, this is by far the biggest expense. We have already sourced a few dealers to get the best value for cost.

Cargo trailer, for transporting the tent, props, seating, stage and everything else needed to put on an exceptional show.

Promo posters and handbills, to promote the show in the towns that we visit.

Generator, to power the sound and lights.

Materials to build the stage and audience seating.

 We have already acquired much of the needed equipment.  Such as sound systems, lighting, trucks for hauling equipment and a tour bus for hauling people.

 

Q and A

Q: What will you do if you reach more than your goal of $25,000?

A: We will be adding more to the carnival to make it a better experience for all.  At $30,000 we will be investing into top notch medical gear and send our resident emergency medical responder for his first aid instructors course so that we can all stay up to date on our first aid.  At $40,000 we will be investing into a bunk RV so that our performers and workers have better accommodations as well as creating Carnival of Calamities T-shirts for all the backers that donated $50 or more.  At $50,000 we will be adding solar panels to the bus so that the carnival can be self powering without the need for a generator. 

Q: Are you going to use all the funds for the carnival?

A: Yes.  This is a legitimate project that we have been working on for over half a year.  We plan to keep this venture going for many years so that we can benefit as many audiences and performers as possible.

Q: Is there any other way that you are raising funds?

A: Yes.  The core group is donating what they can to launch this project.  They have already put in over $20,000 themselves.  They are very dedicated to the dream.

Q: What kind of places does the carnival plan to visit.

A: We plan to find towns between the sizes of 2500 to 15,000 people all through the USA and Canada. We think that they would really enjoy having a carnival in town.

Q: What if people want to help but can’t afford to donate?

A: They can easily help by spreading the word to all of their friends.  The more people that know about it, the better the odds of the carnival getting the assistance it needs.

 

This could be you!!!

For the right donation, we will create an original vintage, fabric poster with your likeness and your carny name on it.  This is but one of the many possible perks that you can get by backing Dr. Von Houligan.

 

Cannot contribute?

If you want to assist with the carnival but cannot donate, please share our story with others.

 

Connect with us:

To keep up to date on what is happening with the carnival, check in with us at:

www.drvonhouligan.com  or

www.facebook.com/dr.von.houligan

About the Carnival
The carnival itself is made up of a core group of performers and workers who believe in the value of live entertainment.  They want to bring back the old style carnival shows that used to travel North America bringing entertainment to small towns.  The idea is to bring together performers that have talent and who want to go professional but just need some more experience and take them to towns that have a lack of quality entertainment.  That way both benefit and great times would be had by all. 
The plan is to build great performers and to give them the tools to better promote themselves so that one day they can make a living doing what they love.  We are looking for all types of performers to fill out our roster. Singers, acrobats, magicians, jugglers, musicians, stilt walkers, hula hoopers, fire performers, dancers and anything else that can be put on a stage that will entertain an audience.  All performers get a share of profits made as this is not a business per say, but a cooperative of entertainers.


The Financial Breakdown:
As with all great projects we need to pay for the required equipment and that is why we are here.  We believe that there are people out there, possibly like yourself that want to support good talent and help bring live entertainment to those who don’t always have the chance to experience it.  So, here is what we need to pay for.
The carnival tent, this is by far the biggest expense. We have already sourced a few dealers to get the best value for cost.
Cargo trailer, for transporting the tent, props, seating, stage and everything else needed to put on an exceptional show.
Promo posters and handbills, to promote the show in the towns that we visit.
Generator, to power the sound and lights.
Materials to build the stage and audience seating.
 We have already acquired much of the needed equipment.  Such as sound systems, lighting, trucks for hauling equipment and a tour bus for hauling people.


 
Q and A
Q: What will you do if you reach more than your goal of $25,000?
A: We will be adding more to the carnival to make it a better experience for all.  At $30,000 we will be investing into top notch medical gear and send our resident emergency medical responder for his first aid instructors course so that we can all stay up to date on our first aid.  At $40,000 we will be investing into a bunk RV so that our performers and workers have better accommodations as well as creating Carnival of Calamities T-shirts for all the backers that donated $50 or more.  At $50,000 we will be adding solar panels to the bus so that the carnival can be self powering without the need for a generator. 
Q: Are you going to use all the funds for the carnival?
A: Yes.  This is a legitimate project that we have been working on for over half a year.  We plan to keep this venture going for many years so that we can benefit as many audiences and performers as possible.
Q: Is there any other way that you are raising funds?
A: Yes.  The core group is donating what they can to launch this project.  They have already put in over $20,000 themselves.  They are very dedicated to the dream.
Q: What kind of places does the carnival plan to visit.
A: We plan to find towns between the sizes of 2500 to 15,000 people all through the USA and Canada. We think that they would really enjoy having a carnival in town.
Q: What if people want to help but can’t afford to donate?
A: They can easily help by spreading the word to all of their friends.  The more people that know about it, the better the odds of the carnival getting the assistance it needs.


 
This could be you!!!
For the right donation, we will create an original vintage, fabric poster with your likeness and your carny name on it.  This is but one of the many possible perks that you can get by backing Dr. Von Houligan.
 
Cannot contribute?
If you want to assist with the carnival but cannot donate, please share our story with others.
 
Connect with us:
To keep up to date on what is happening with the carnival, check in with us at:
www.drvonhouligan.com  or
www.facebook.com/dr.von.houligan

story:
Dear friends,

We are currently developing and producing a puppet theatre piece that we have gotten the opportunity to present through the University of Maryland School of Theatre, Dance, and Performance Studies Second Season on September 21 and 22 of this year. While we are allowed a budget through the university, the financial necessities of a fully costumed puppet production stretch beyond what the school can provide me. We are hoping that through this website, we will be able to fund this particular production, and then keep all of the puppets and costumes for future iterations and productions of the piece, which we hope to continue developing and working on well beyond our time at the university.

Here is a brief description of the show: Gretel is an innovative take on the age-old fairy tale, Hansel and Gretel, that tells the story of a young girl dealing with a scary stepmother, an absent-minded brother, and an absent father. Set to Stravinsky's Rite of Spring, and featuring a fierce cast of nine incredibly talented women, this puppet-theatre production provides a haunting twist to the children's story, and explores profound themes of womanhood, sacrifice, and food - lots and lots of food.

After just a few rehearsals with our artistic team, we can both already tell that this group of women is going to be a joy to work with and that this project is going to be an emotional journey for the artistic team as well as the audiences we are able to bring it to. Do check out the video above, which shows an improvised movement piece that Olivia had the pleasure of doing with one of our cast members, Moriamo Akibu, on the first day of rehearsal. As you can see, there are almost no costumes or puppets in the video, so see below to see what your contributions will go towards:

  • Uniform suits for all of the actors
  • Masks for the actors
  • Puppet equipment including clay, papier-mâché, yarn, fabric, foam, etc.

We are so very grateful for all of your support as our artistic journeys continue, and we thank you in advance for any contribution.

Warmly,

Olivia Brann (Director) and Anjna Swaminathan (Assistant Director and Development Dramaturg)

story:
WHO AM I ?

I am Emma Laishram, theatre creator, actor, and singer. I am half Manipuri and half British. I am also Canadian. For those of you who are unfamiliar with Indian geography, Manipur is a small province on the north eastern tip of India. I hold a BA Honours in theatre from Dalhousie University, and a diploma from the National Theatre School of Canada in Montreal, Quebec. 

In the last year of my undergrad, a teacher asked me "What is your dream project?" I pondered. He told me "What ever it is...just do it!" Since then I have wanted to write this play: a solo-show that combines my East Indian heritage and my Canadian upbringing. A collision of two worlds: East and West.

Being first generation, half Manipuri-Canadian and having grown up in Canada all my life, I have always felt underrepresented and somewhat lost when it comes to my own cultural identity. Flipping through magazines, watching television, movies, I have never seen a Manipuri face. Even when I attended Canadian Indian festivals in Toronto with my family, I discovered that I wasn’t Indian enough to pull off the beautiful saris or salwar khameez—I would get asked “why are you wearing that?” or “Oh, I didn’t know you were Indian”. The latter phrase became a common theme upon meeting new people throughout my life. There exists a generation—perhaps multiple—of Canadians, sons and daughters of immigrants who have grown up in this country feeling similarly. We carry with us the traditions and cultures of our parents, but we grow up in a western, Caucasian society. In this context we are recognized as ‘ethnic’ or ‘exotic’. Yet, at the same time we are removed from our heritage, because we were raised apart from it. The current multicultural theatre scene often offers up the immigrant story. Though I am an immigrant, technically speaking, mine is one that is a step beyond this. I want to make theatre that represents a new generation, a story that is told from their mixed, identity confused Canadian children. 

COLLISION - A VISION

 This solo show will explore the separation of the self and one’s country through discovering commonalities and universal truths about who we are as human beings, beyond our culture, beyond our appearance, and beyond our beliefs. What can we still communicate without sharing a common language? What separates us, and what makes us the same? What makes us who we are, our environment or our origins. Or Both? 


WHY MANIPUR AND MONTREAL?

In India, Manipuri and other North Eastern Indian people are being violently attacked, abused and killed based on their race. This has sparked a nationwide protest for the justice of these lives, and a growing concern for the need of anti-racism laws (India Broadcast News, 2014). Case after case of North Eastern people being attacked, raped and/or killed in hate-crime race related attacks is forcing Manipuris to fear for their safety. This violence is profoundly disturbing and it has forced me to take action. What is a Manipuri’s identity if their own country refuses to accept them because of their race? What will happen to their culture if they reject their country, as their country rejects them? Will this lead to separation?

Living in Montreal I have witnessed the passion that many French Canadians have for their culture and it comes to a head at this very word ’separation’. A topic that is both taboo and yet cried out in the form of “Liberté” with banging drums and marching protests through the streets of Montreal. This play does not aim to take a stance on the political interests of separatist supporters. It will, however, provide a platform for discussion on what might happen to the cultural identity of Quebec should they one day achieve separation.

 

COLLABORATORS

 Emma Laishram- Writer / Performer

Emma is an award-winning actress and recent graduate of the English Acting Program at the National Theatre School of Canada. In 2013 she participated in Solo-icious in Halifax, where she performed her vocal mask created at the National Theatre School entitled "Fear" with great success. The past two summers Emma has performed professionally with award winning outdoor Halifax theatre company, Shakespeare By The Sea. With this company she has collectively collaborated to create two musical adaptations: Alice in Wonderland, and Snow White, which was recently nominated for a Merritt Award for outstanding new play, and received two awards for best original score and musical direction. Emma most recently performed with Saskatoon-based theatre company, Ground Cover Theatre, in the premier of their original new work, "Displaced" at the Montreal Fringe Festival. The company was nominated for Best English Production and Best English text in the Montreal Frankie Awards.

Adam Lazarus- Consultant / Collaborator / Director

Adam Lazarus is an award winning actor, director and acting instructor. He is a sessional instructor at the National Theatre School of Canada and the University of Toronto as well as a regular facilitator of workshops, including recent consultations for Soulpepper, Theatre Passe Muraille, VANOC, Apostle of Hustle, Buddies in Bad Times, DanceMakers, The Toronto Film School, CanStage, Tapestry New Opera Works, and Volcano Theatre. 

      Ratan Thiyam- Consultant / Collaborator

      Ratan Thiyam is an Indian playwright and theatre director, and the winner of Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 1987. Also known as Thiyam Nemai, Ratan Thiyam is known for writing and staging plays that use ancient Indian theatre traditions and forms in a contemporary context. A former painter, and proficient in direction, design, script and music, Thiyam is often considered one of leading contemporary theatre gurus. He is also the founder-director of 'Chorus Repertory Theatre', formed on the outskirts of Imphal, Manipur in 1976.


Phase 1 of Collision:

In order to write this play with integrity and authenticity it is absolutely necessary to travel to Manipur and immerse myself in the culture. The first stage of the project will include spending one month in Imphal, Manipur conducting research.

While on location, I will interview people who have personally experienced difficulties due to their ethnicity. I will be taking Classical Manipuri dance lessons, singing lessons, and learn the Manipuri language as I intend to incorporate these elements into my show. 

I will record and document as much as possible, with sound clips, videos, and daily journal entries. When I return to Montreal I will conduct further interviews with more Manipuri-Canadians, and Francophones. 

TIMELINE:

July 7-25  Creation Workshop with Adam Lazarus

Oct 30-Nov 1 Depart Toronto-Brussels-Delhi-Imphal

                                November 4-7 Preparation, networking and research for Collision, interview friends and family members, journalists etc.

                                November 7-28  Master classes waiting for Manipuri classical singing and dance at Progressive Artist Laboratory, meet with Ratan Thiyam

                                November 28 Presentation of work 

Nov 30-Dec 2 Imphal-Delhi-Brussels-Toronto Arrival


The Impact

By donating to this cause you are not just helping a theater artist to create:

  • You are supporting and enriching Canadian culture, art and heritage.
  • You are raising awareness about a culture that is currently underrepresented and oppressed.
  • You are creating an opportunity for important social justice issues to be discussed and challenged, and allowing marginalized voices and stories to be heard both nationally and internationally.
  • With the money you donate, we will be able to pay the skilled artists collaborating on this project, the rehearsal space rentals, and the return trip airfare. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you do not want to donate maybe you know someone who might! 

  • Please share this campaign with your friends. It's not just about the money, it's about raising awareness and creating interest in the project!  
  • Do not forget to share through social media on Twitter, Facebook and Email!

story:
Short Summary

TheatreSouth is a registered Georgia Not For Profit touring theatre company.

We are embarking on a historically significant Multicultural Theatre Production / Broadway play "I HAVE A DREAM" written by Josh Greenfeld, directed by Herman LeVern Jones. The project is a historical production based on the life and times of Civil Right Leader and American Icon Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

I HAVE A DREAM covers the civil rights moment with Dr. King from December 1, 1955 (when Rosa Parks refused to move to the back of the bus) until April 4, 1968 (the day Martin Luther King transitioned). There are 28 songs, 120 projections, a mass choir, and over 20 actors, singers, and dancers in the production. The production will touch on the audience's intellectual, spiritual, and emotional senses. It is a perfect vehicle to entertain, inspire and add perspective to our American history. We need your support in making this project successful.

Project Highlights:

  • 16 Student Matinee Performances at the South Miami-Dade Cultural Arts Center- Students/General Public- January 13 - 23, 2014 

  • Opening performance for General Public,  January 13,2014

  • Promotional Ticket (RAFFLE) Give-A- Way - Dream Vacation to Belise

  • Onsite Door - Prize Give-A-Ways

  • Chanthou Oeur (Cambodian Artist) presentation- Visual Art Exhibit
    Dream of Freedom from the Killing Fields - January 2014

  • African American Theatre Exhibit - Past, Present, Future 1821 – 2014 (showcased in lobby)

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support in making sure 15,376 public school students of all ages and cultural creeds are able to see this wonderful production of "I Have A Dream" The Broadway Musical.  In procuring the funding, 15,376 student tickets will be available for the viewing of matinee performances at the South Miami-Dade Cultural Arts Center for FREE in JANUARY 2014!!!


As a personal donor your name is entered into our DREAM VACATION give away, which includes the following:

- An 8 day/7 night vacation to the beautiful country of Belize and the city of San Perdo on the islands (Included: Private Villa) Airfare Transportation is NOT included. 

- A $500 voucher on the trip to be used for personal chef, snorkeling, scuba diving, provisions (stocking the house with food), island and/or mainland excursions.

For every $20 dollars you donate, your name will be placed in the raffle drawing for the opportunity to win your DREAM VACATION!


The Impact

Like many cultural events around the world, people have the opportunity to learn and cultivate themselves into new experiences.  This production of "I Have A Dream" The Musical has been seen in more than 120 cities worldwide since 1986 through 2012.

This particular presentation has the mission to make youth more aware about the historical events from the Civil Rights era and to expose the future generations to the new but very old concept of enjoying live performance.


History of "I Have A Dream" The Musical

“I Have A Dream” the Musical written by Josh Greenfeld, is a theatrical production that toured for many years around the world both on Broadway and off Broadway.  This work appeared on Broadway at the Ambassador Theatre in New York City from September 1976 until December 1976 starring Billy Dee Williams.  This original work then toured for several years with Broadway Producer and Director Woodie King, Jr.’s National Black Touring Circuit from 1985 to 2002, of which Herman LeVern Jones served as Associate Producer, Actor, and Company Manager.  “I Have A Dream” is a musical production based on the words of international icon Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.  The dynamic musical takes place during the Civil Rights Era in the Southeastern part of the United States from 1955 to 1968.

This timeless production of “I Have A Dream” will again leap into the history books, creating an educational platform for the Miami Dade Public School System.  The initiative of this project falls under the humanitarian arms of Commissioner Dennis Moss, project leader of the South Miami Dade Cultural Arts Center.  Special thanks to all of the students, faculty, staff, and supporters of the entire Miami Metro Area.

“I Have A Dream” will be directed by World Renowned Director Herman LeVern Jones, musically directed by Grammy Award Winning Dr. Gregory McPherson, and choreographed by New York’s Diane Harvey.       

Spread the word!

Thank in advance for your contribution and for supporting the arts and education! 

Please check out the event webpage to learn more about the next steps of the "I Have A Dream" The Musical production and the two year world tour that has been planned to perform and travel to 34 cities on 5 continents, the potential of having Jamie Foxx play the lead role as Martin Luther King, Jr.,  and performing during 2016 Olympic Games.

story:
**FOR LIMITED TIME ONLY**

Hypokrit Pass or higher gets a discounted ticket price at $50 (Regular Ticket Price: $65) AND an Exclusive Invitation to Our Kick-Off Party on January 22, 2015 (Details will be provided at the time of perk fulfillment) 

"Great theatre is about challenging how we think and encouraging us to fantasize about a world we aspire to." William Dafoe

Hypokrit re-imagines Shakespeare the most unexpected way - through a Bollywood lens. By making the verse accessible and showcasing the richness of the Bollywood aesthetic, we bring this timeless love story to new audiences. Creating such a world requires ambition, vision and funding. We have two out of the three and we created this campaign to enlist your help for the third - funding.

Meet our multicultural cast, which reflects our belief in highlighting the rich diversity of talent in New York City. They’ll make you look at Bollywood movies and think about Shakespeare in ways you never have before.

Our show dates and times are as follows:

February 4, 5: 8 pm (previews)

February 6: 8 pm (opening night)

February 7 - 22 

Wednesday - Sunday: 8 pm

Saturday and Sunday matinees: 2 pm

**Second cast performs on Saturday matinees, Sunday evenings and Wednesday February 11, 8 pm. 

Get the Hypokrit Pass at $50 to reserve your ticket at a special early bird rate!

The company's leadership team includes three talented women from different walks of life, with a combined experience of over twenty years in professional theatre. Find out more about them in the first installment of Meeting the Hypokrits, a web series that provides an inside look at the company. 



“All the world’s a stage.” - William Shakespeare

In just the last few months, we premiered Romeo and Juliet’s cinematic trailer at an exclusive launch party at the Empire Hotel Rooftop in New York City, which was attended by over 500 guests, and held an open rehearsal for influential members of the community, while assembling a crew of technical experts to execute intricate fight sequences, create incredible projections and choreograph stunning dances.


One of our main goals is to build and be part of a supportive and inclusive community where organizations, businesses and individuals can develop mutually beneficial relationships to further their respective missions and goals. We were the community partners for Indo-American Arts Council's First Literary Festival as well as Lend-A-Hand Foundation's Fashion for Education charity event. 

Our other community partners include:


Your contribution also allows us to continue building on the work we have already done since our inception in July.

“Theatre is a series of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster.” -Tom Stoppard

We’ve been asked many times why we chose to start a theatre company when there’s no money in theatre. During our first meetings, we faced the daunting task of going out into the world and answering this question. But since we embarked on this journey, we have noticed that passion and tenacity can lead even skeptics to coming on board. We know that taking on Shakespeare’s verse along with the Bollywood tradition is quite a project, but with your help, we feel confident that we can transform Access Theater into a dreamscape. Take a look at our approach to the verse in Meeting the Hypokrits Episode 2. 



As for the answer to the question of why a theatre company now and why Romeo and Juliet now - we're passionate about storytelling, we inspire young artists to re-imagine themselves and their communities, and we ask theatergoers to come together for the shared experience of the familiar and the foreign.

“The theatre is the involuntary reflex of the ideas of the crowd.” - Sarah Bernhardt

Your contribution today will go a long way in helping us mount this production, which has a budget of $35,000 most of which goes into production costs such as set, costume and projections as well as paying our incredible cast and crew. Bollywood films are lavish and cost millions of dollars to make but we’ve found imaginative and creative ways to re-create the magic of a Bollywood movie within the confines of a black box theatre. The $15,000 we raise through this campaign allows us to get closer to our vision, but still leaves us with more than $10,000 to raise.

More importantly, the contribution OFFICIALLY makes you part of the Hypokrit family. Romeo and Juliet, above all, is a labor of love, and our cast and crew have been working tirelessly above the justification of pay or recognition to create an unforgettable experience for you, our patron. Therefore, all our perks are designed to invite you to delve as deeply as you choose into what theatre is - an intimate exchange between the artist and the audience. Your contribution gives us the opportunity to give back to you - whether that be through the play itself, a professional photo shoot as one of the characters or being a part of the acting company. Consider the campaign an invitation to you to participate.

"I think there is no world without theatre." - Edward Bond

Your contribution helps us get closer to our fundraising goal, but your support has the power to extend far beyond the monetary value of a contribution.

While we are grateful for your financial support, your endorsement is just as important to our company and its artists. Please share this campaign with your friends and family, your social network and those in your personal vicinity. Tell them about this cool new take on Romeo and Juliet with not one, but two multicultural casts. Ask them to know, give, build and support. We’ll be working even harder in the upcoming months knowing that you believe in us and our vision.

story:
The Big Muddy Dance Company is St. Louis' only Contemporary Jazz Dance Company, and we need $7,000 dollars to bring Lauri Stallings to our city for three weeks to set a piece on our dancers.  As a rareity in the city we love, we strive to keep providing our audiences with the most entertaining, exciting, and invigorating choreography.  Lauri's new piece will be premiered in June at our biggest event of the year at the Touhill Performing Arts Center.


So why Lauri Stallings?  As the Artistic Director of gloATL in Atlanta, Stallings has choreographed works for American Ballet Theatre, Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Juilliard, and several other really awesome dance institutions.  Her works use a "language of physical gesture as an exploration that comes from inner technologies of the human body." This work will be unlike anything else in The Big Muddy's current repertory, and unlike anything that has been produced in St. Louis thus far!

The Big Muddy Dance Company needs to raise $7,000 to cover travel and daily living expenses (like Lauri's hotel and food), rehearsal and setting costs(to pay our dancers for their time and Lauri for her work and process), and to purchase performing rights to the premiere work for an extended period of time (yep, even dance choreography is copyrighted!). The addition of Ms. Stallings' new work will continue to make the company's repertoire diverse and intriguing, but will also maintain our commitment to high-quality, entertaining performances.   

Give a donation, and let your eyes and mind be rewarded while you just feel good about yourself for contributing to good art in a great city! Donors may receive anything from special recognition on the company's website and in publications, to special perks like a personal performance. One of the coolest perks is a preview night of the new work on April 17th; we'll provide the wine and beer, you just come and be a part of our process. If you live too far or can't make it, we'll send you a private link to a youtube video of the piece in rehearsal.


The Big Muddy Dance Company loves all the support we can get. If you don't feel that making a monetary contribution is right for you, please consider helping us out by spreading the word about this campaign.  We never hesitate to bombard our Facebook friends with posts and messages, you can too!  A donation in the name of someone could be very special as well! 

Inspire, Intrigue, Impact......

The Big Muddy Dance Company:  Invigorating Life through Dance!! (with the help of Lauri Stallings)

story:
Short Summary

For a little over two seasons now, Laugh/Riot Performing Arts Company has brought our unique brand of theatre to a growing audience in Edinboro, PA as a resident theatre company at Edinboro University.  Now we have the chance to take that style on the road as we submit "Bedtime Stories" to four different fringe festivals in Erie, PA (Feb. 2015); Pittsburgh, PA (May 2015); Buffalo, NY (July/Aug. 2015); and Chicago, IL (Aug./Sept. 2015).  What sets Laugh/Riot apart?

  • Our background.  Our Artistic Director earned his M.A. and Ph.D. in theatre; our President earned his M.F.A. in technical theatre; two other members of our board have graduate degrees in theatre. 
  • A willingness to take risks with our content - an Erie theatre blog's 3 most shocking plays of 2013 were all Laugh/Riot shows.

"Bedtime Stories" hits all of the keys that sets us apart.  This devised piece shows 7 sets of people in the most intimate and private space they have. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need to get us on the road:

  • Application and production fees: $275-$575 for the Chicago Fringe Festival (depending on the amount of times we'd like to perform; $200 for Pittsburgh Fringe Festival; none for Buffalo Infringement and Gannon (Erie, PA) Fringe Festival; total $475-775.
  • Travel Expenses: gas/tolls - Chicago $150; Pittsburgh $40; Buffalo $30; none for Erie; total app. $220
  • Lodging - luckily, the festivals offer free housing or we have friends we can stay with!  We would like to provide the actors with a per diem for food each day that we will be out of town.  Total cost - app. $500
  • Total Funds Needed: $1,200 - $1,500

 

Here's what you'll get for helping us get there:

  • The eternal gratitude of our performers.  If that's not enough, how about acknowledgment in our season's programs; a video of our travels; tickets to our performances; and a chance to join us onstage to introduce our production.

We are not asking for help covering all of the expenses; we have other fundraising going to help us as well.  If we don't reach our entire goal, the money raised will still go toward attending the festivals, we may just cut down the amount of performances we can do.  Similarly, if we raise more money than our goal, we will put that money into this project by adding more performances when possible.

The Impact

Why should you donate to this project?  Glad you asked:

  • You get the chance to help these artists gain national exposure.
  • You help bring Laugh/Riot's unique aesthetic to new markets.  Previous productions have all been lauded for their distinctive staging.
  • You can help bring more national attention to northwest PA's growing arts scene.

Risks & Challenges

 How can we guarantee that we'll be able to perform at these festivals?

  • By having the funds to apply during the "early bird" period for Pittsburgh and Chicago, we can guarantee performance opportunities before they are determined by a lottery process. 
  • Buffalo Infringement Festival is committed to accepting all applicants.
  • We are already working with the Gannon Fringe Festival to ensure performance space, either at the festival proper or at a satellite venue.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, there are plenty of ways you can help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!  The more people talking about it, the more likely we'll reach people who support our goal.
  • Indiegogo's share tools make it easy to let people know about this in a variety of ways.

Thanks for all of your support!

story:
One year ago today, November 7, 2013, a new play called Sun and Room premiered at Fort Lewis College’s intimate black box theatre. A few months later, in February 2014, that play was featured at the Regional VIII Kennedy Center American College Theater Festival in Los Angeles. And now, this coming January 2015, that same play - with its original cast and crew - will premiere in NEW YORK CITY. 

THREE WHOLE WEEKS.
SIXTEEN SHOWS.
At the beautiful PARADISE FACTORY THEATRE on 4th Street.
This is the chance of a lifetime.
And we need YOUR HELP to make it happen. 

WHAT IS SUN AND ROOM:

Written by New York playwright Danny Mitarotondo, Sun and Room was composed specifically for the voices of Durango student actors Leah Brewer, Zoë Pike, and Matthew Socci in an attempt to accurately portray today's college-age demographic on the stage.

Sun and Room is about three college kids hanging out on a Friday night. It aims to be a moving painting of that liminal time of life - where identity is in flux, tiny moments have tremendous weight, and magic is found in connection. 

WHO WE ARE: 

We are Leah Brewer, Alicia Laws, Lindsay Macdonald, Zoë Pike, Sydney Sherman, Matthew Socci, and Rhys Williams. We’re college kids with the passion and drive to be professional working artists. Our former visiting professor, New York playwright Danny Mitarotondo, wrote Sun and Room specifically for us. Here's a review by Judith Reynolds at the Durango Herald: 

http://durangoherald.com/article/20131107/ARTS01/131109613

Danny and his longtime collaborator Shannon Fillion have formed a production company called Brontosaurus Haircut Productions. Danny and Shannon believe in this project - and in us - so much that they are putting their company, effort and resources toward making a New York production of Sun and Room possible - one where we can get reviewed, make professional contacts, and touch audiences with this powerful play. But they can't do it alone.

WHAT WE NEED: 

We need to raise $10,000 to cover specific items in our production budget. Here is an itemized list of what we are trying to raise money for, and have already raised through Brontosaurus Haircut Productions:

Sun and Room Production Budget

Item Detail:                                              Cost:        Paid?:                                                    

  • Theatre Rental                                  $12,000    Yes! Courtesy of BHP Shareholders
  • NYC Living Expenses for Colorado Artists 
       Housing for each artist                $5,400      Yes! Courtesy of local NYC artists
       Metrocards ($113 each)              $791           Yes! Courtesy of BHP Shareholders
       Stipends ($100 each)                 $900          Yes! Courtesy of BHP Shareholders
  • Construction Materials                   $1,060       Not yet
  • Music Licensing Costs                    $587           Not yet
  • Additional Artist Stipends             $1,800       Not yet
  • Travel                                                  $4,113        Not yet
  • Publicity & Advertising                   $2,000      Not yet
  • Administrative                                  $440          Not yet

TOTAL WE ARE TRYING TO RAISE:  $10,000

All the money you donate to this campaign will go toward these specific items. You will receive all the appropriate perks (detailed in the right-hand comlumn on this page) for your donation. And, of course, we will update you beat by beat as we make our way to New York!

IF YOU’RE A RISK TAKER: 

Sun and Room is a commercial production, meaning Brontosaurus Haircut Productions has reserved the Paradise Factory Theatre for the possibility of extension! Our passionate goal is to SELL OUT our scheduled 16 performances and EXTEND THE SHOW until February 22nd. In a commercial environment, the goal is not just to break even, but even more so, to make a profit.

All donations of $1000 or more will immediately make you an associate producer of the production. If you are interested in this option, you can either donate to the right, and we will contact you, or you can contact us and we'll tell you more about this option:  brontosaurushaircutproductions@gmail.com

THE LONG VIEW:

Sun and Room is a play we believe in. It’s a play that was a formative experience for us, and has excited those that have seen it. 

This is the chance of a lifetime. New York is the hardest, most competitive place in the world to make theatre. We are making it happen. More than the play, this is a chance for us to experience our dream; to make our dream real.  This is a chance to do with most theatre artists in New York aren't even doing in this moment: acting; stage managing; designing. You can help us make it happen. You can help us take one giant leap forward in our lives - with this show, and beyond.

Thank you for your support. We can’t wait to see you in New York!!

story:
Our Story

Enforced Arch is a dance and performance community of intelligent communicators who use their unique talents to bring life to environmental and social issues. In our spring performance at Manhattan Movement & Arts Center, we will be presenting a collection of past and new works sewn together honoring the 'Alliance' of art and activism.



These performances on April 6th and 7th mark the first presentation of works by the Enforced Arch creative directors, James Koroni & Tracey Katof. After only a year in existence Enforced Arch has traveled to D.C. New York City and Paris to perform. Enforced Arch has "spoken" for issues such as; Childhood Sexual Abuse, Animal Rights, Environmental Awareness, the It Get's Better Project and Domestic Violence.



We will continue to expand upon our already existing platform that keenly fuses Art & Activism but we need your help! In order to produce this show financially, we need all the support we can get. Everything from renting the performance venue, rehearsal space, costumes, etc. all cost a great deal but in the long run will help us spread awareness. Any amount, great or small is put to good use and is very much appreciated!


Thank you for your support!


Best,


James Koroni
Creative Director & Choreographer
JamesKoroni@gmail.com

Tracey Katof
PR Director & Choreographer
TraceyKatof@gmail.com


"Inspiring performers everywhere!"
-The Discerning Brute

"Enforced Arch, a group of performers who are using the power of their movements to create dialogue about big issues like animal welfare and social justice."
-VegNews Magazine
