story:
The Traveling Players

A group of professional actors, the Traveling Players take a family-friendly approach to Shakespeare.  We make Shakespeare's comedies accessible by presenting them in an outdoor setting and carefully cutting them to run in the kid-friendly time frame of about an hour.  Our performances are always free!

As You Like It, The Traveling Players’ 2013 summer production in Hamlin Park, encompasses a style of presentation that emulates Shakespeare’s time as much as possible.  The minimal set design, contemporary costumes, limited amplification, live contemporary music and close proximity to audience members are an attempt to give a modern audience something akin to what Shakespeare’s own audiences may have experienced.  Add to that a healthy dose of irreverence and modern sensibility, and you have The Traveling Players’ brand of theater.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds in order to pay our company members for their hard work and dedication and reimburse them for the money they've spent on props, costumes, and set pieces.

Without ticket sales these professional artists are relying entirely on the generous contributions of those who support our vision of Shakespeare in the Park.  We are committed to paying stipends to all of the artists in our company and those we bring in to work with us.  Help us inspire a younger generation by introducing them to the power of quality live theater!

We are offering four different levels of Perks to our audience members, ranging from a Facebook shout out to a picnic lunch for four during a performance of As You Like It! 

The Impact

Your generous support allows us to realize our goal of sharing Shakespeare with the masses.  Please consider donating and sharing this indiegogo page with your friends and family members.  With your help we hope to have a huge turn out in Hamlin Park this summer, and pave the way for future work by the Traveling Players!

Performances

Saturday, August 17 at 2 & 5 pm

Sunday, August 18 at 1 & 4 pm

Saturday, August 24 at 2 & 5 pm

Sunday, August 25 at 1 & 4 pm

story:
Short Summary

Some say it with sarcasm and anger. Others use it with the utmost affection and pride. And at times, two passionate people will look at each other and wonder how the phrase “Only in America” can take on such a radically different meaning for the other person. True magic happens, however, when different ideas are shared and discussed, and art can provide a common ground on which to do so. The Damsels Dance Company, directed by noted choreographer Katrina Lairsmith, will be presenting ONLY IN AMERICA, an examination of the polarizing events that have become major talking points for the nation. 

What Your Donations Do

The funds we receive from Indiegogo will go toward:

  • Renting the venue (The Avenue Theater is an awesome, well cared-for space that both performers and the audience love!) 
  • Paying the Stage Manager (A man who can run lights, video and sound all by himself while still being totally cool and helpful to super-stressed out dancers deserves to be paid!)
  • Transporting our props (3 ten foot long benches, a podium, an office chair, and suitcases don't all fit in the co-director's Nissan Versa!)
  • The printing cost of posters, programs, and tickets! 

The Impact

Ultimately, The Damsels Dance Company would like to try and get these costs covered so that our ticket sales (and any extra donations we might get, hint hint :D) can go toward our goal of helping young dancers afford a quality dance education. We love dance as a sport, as a lifestyle, and as an art, but the reality is that good dance education is a big financial commitment. If we can lessen the financial burden for some young dancers, we can ensure that dance can enhance and brighten their futures in the same way it has done and continues to do for us as professionals. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If a dance performance in Denver is held, but no one is around to see it, can it really make an impact? Another big way to help us meet our goals is to spread the word! 

'Like' us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/TheDamselsDanceCompany and subscribe to our Youtube account http://www.youtube.com/user/TheDamselsDanceCo

And don't forget to share our videos and pictures with your friends! Help us build an audience and you help us have a voice! The last thing an artist wants is to be alone in the wilderness and unable to make a sound!

story:
Update:

We are thrilled to report that we've received an amazing response from offline donors who have contributed over $15,500 in donations helping us get closer to our goal! Thank you to everyone who has contributed both online and offline!

If you'd like to donate offline please reach out to nconneely@dalailamafellows.org

Short Summary

Dalai Lama Fellows is building a global community of ethical, compassionate and effective social innovators who deepen their capacity and impact by embracing contemplative values and secular ethics. Each Fellow designs and manages an original, mentored compassion-in-action project at the intersection of justice, peace, and ecology. Projects focus on one or more of today’s major global challenges:

  • Enhancing cross-culture and inter-religious understanding and cooperation
  • Diminishing violence and promoting peace
  • Alleviating poverty
  • Protecting the environment
  • Promoting gender equity

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $47,000 in 5 weeks to celebrate each of the 47 Dalai Lama Fellows who are impacting the world through actions rooted in contemplative secular ethics.  

With your help we hope to successfully raise $47,000 from which we will allocate 50% to strengthening our Alumni Programming and 50% to a new initiative that we will launch this year to select At Large Fellows. 

We invite you to join our movement to Celebrate Compassionate Innovators around the world, as we work to empower a new generation of ethical, compassionate leaders.

The Impact

Our mission is to advance a new model of mutualistic, ethics-and-values-based global leadership that works for the good of all, as well as of the individual. 

  • To date 47 Fellows from 20 nations have impacted more than 20,000 individuals through projects in more than three dozen locations on five continents. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute today but would like to help please reach out to Natalie Conneely, Director of Resource Development at nconneely@dalailamafellows.org.

  • You can also help us get the word out by using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
In collaboration with the Florida State University LGBTQ program, PRIDE FSU, I'm delighted to launch my first full-length play April 2015: PURPLE EYES.

THE PROJECT

Purple Eyes is an ancestral auto/biography where I investigate my identity as a gay Chicano amid the lineage of machismo men in my family.  Many generations of Inocéncios originated in Michoacán, a southern Mexican state with strong P’urhépecha connections, before they emigrated to the United States.  And as my cousin Chuy says, “those Michoacán men, tu sabes, are on another level of machismo.”  The title Purple Eyes comes from my dad’s notorious purple sunglasses he wore when I was kid, a remnant of his flashier clothing when he worked as an undercover cop in gay night clubs.  The “purple eyes” also imply the ability of the men in my family to queer the world around them despite their hyper-masculine tendencies.  From strawberry farms to the U.S. military and from welding shops to the police force, the piece interrogates passages of masculinity and how the men in my family have negotiated supremely heterosexual spaces that view queerness as a weakness.  The play is a solo show, so I perform as myself as well as my dad, my grandpa, and my great-grandpa through memories I have collected over the years.  I do not seek to write biographies or historical narratives.  Rather, my performance of these stories are my queer imaginings and interpretations of memories.

Through a storytelling aesthetic inspired by John Leguizamo’s Freak and Luis Alfaro’s Downtown, I have crafted this play to understand how the cultures of the U.S. and Mexico have affected my family.  In an effort to dismantle the racism, sexism, and homophobia that have infiltrated the Inocéncios, I reawaken our indigenous P’urhépecha past throughout the piece as a potential site for revolution.  The play contains four chapters, one on my great-grandpa Jesús, one on my grandpa José, one on my dad Joel, and one on myself—all our names begin with the letter jota, an irony not lost on me—where I perform a myriad of familial histories but focus on specifc incidents where we contest the strictures of machismo.

THE FUNDING REQUIREMENTS

While PRIDE FSU will provide a theatre space and marketing materials, my design collaborators and I will need a minimum of $800 to pay for props and costumes.  These props include, but are not limited to, food (strawberries, tomatoes, tequila, chili peppers), ritual objects (candles, roses, bowls for water, piñata), and basic welding equipment (mask, gloves, rod).  The costumes include, but are not limited to, feathers and clay for an eagle headdress, World War II military uniform, farmworker's hat and clothing, undercover cop outfit, and red high heels. Any contribution is VERY helpful! Thank you all for taking the time to consider this project!

THE TEAM

PLAYWRIGHT/PERFORMER: Josh Inocéncio

DIRECTOR: Jeff Paden

COSTUME DESIGNER: Rainy Edwards

SOUND CONSULTANT: Ian Williams

PRODUCTION MANAGER: Bianca Hooi

DRAMATURG: Shannon Hurst

For more details, visit the PURPLE EYES website: www.thepurpleeyes.com

story:
About the Project

My name is Nicholas J. Goodman and I am a senior Theatre major at SUNY Oswego. As a requirement for graduation, students in our department must do a "Senior Capstone Project." The idea of the project is that it is a culmination of what you have learned and experienced in your time at Oswego. As I am a director, I have decided to direct a student theatre projection of John Cameron Mitchell and Stephen Trask's Hedwig and the Angry Inch. The performances are planned for April 4th and 5th of 2015.

About Hedwig and the Angry Inch

This groundbreaking Obie-winning Off-Broadway smash also won multiple awards for its hit film adaptation. It tells the story of "internationally ignored song stylist" Hedwig Schmidt, a fourth-wall smashing East German rock 'n' roll goddess who also happens to be the victim of a botched sex-change operation, which has left her with just "an angry inch." This outrageous and unexpectedly hilarious story is dazzlingly performed by Hedwig (née Hansel) in the form of a rock gig/stand-up comedy routine backed by the hard-rocking band "The Angry Inch." Using songs and monologues, Hedwig tells her story, which began in the former East Berlin where as Hansel he meets Luther, an American GI who promises to take the young man to the States on the condition that he switch his sex. After the bungled operation, Luther abandons newly named Hedwig in a Kansas trailer park where she turns to music and meets geeky Tommy Speck, whom she takes under her wing and soon falls for. Tommy steals her songs, achieves rock star fame, and Hedwig is once again cast aside. She decides to demand redress and stalks Tommy's world tour, performing in the T.G.I. Friday's that are situated next door to his stadiums. Hedwig describes her life's search for "The Origin of Love" and her other half. It's a rocking ride, funny, touching and ultimately inspiring to anyone who has felt life gave them an inch when they deserved a mile.

-This is the summary from Dramatists Play Service.

Why I Chose Hedwig

I believe that Hedwig is a perfect fit for this project for two reasons;

  1. I grew up in a small town in Central New York. We did not, by any means, have a diverse population, and as a result, I was almost completely unaware of the wide variety of lifestyles there are in the world. Coming to Oswego was a bit of a culture shock, but one I embraced. Coming to college, I had a very limited view of the world, I had very little knowledge of other cultures, regional differences in our own country, and the idea that there was more to gender than just being a man or woman astounded me. I believe that Hedwig is a celebration of that diversity that I found here, in Oswego. 
  2. Going away to college and choosing a major are probably the two biggest decisions I have made in my young life. In a strange way, this is a lot alike Hedwig's decision to get a sex change and come to the US with a guy he barely knew. Though our situations are completely different, we both made life changing decisions and had expectations of what the results would be. Much alike Hedwig, my expectations were way off, but in the end, what we got is better than anything we could have dreamed of.

What We Need

  • Scripts, Rentals & Rights- In order to perform the show, we must buy the scripts, rent the scores and pay royalty fees.
  • Costumes- While there are only two characters in this show, their costumes cannot be plain. There is also an onstage band that must be costumed appropriately as well.
  • Wigs & Makeup- Both characters in this show are cross dressed, so both actors will need wigs. Also, due to the Glam Rock style of this show, the makeup demands are heavy.
  • Scenic- While Hedwig does not require much on the scenic end, we will need projections and some small scenic pieces. 
  • Props- There are not many props required, but Hedwig does use a few things that she made or found in her travels.
  • Lighting & Sound- Because this show is a rock concert, lighting and sound are key to a successful production. We will likely need to purchase so equipment specifically for this show.
In the event that I do not raise all of the money I am looking for I still have a few options open to me. I would either simplify my plans for the production or choose a different, less costly, show and the funds would go toward that.

    Risks & Challenges

    As with any production, there are some challenges that lie ahead;

    1. Scheduling- College students' schedules are incredibly varied, which can make finding rehearsal time difficult. Fortunately the core group of people needed for Hedwig is rather small, which in theory means that there will be less conflicts to work around.
    2. Rehearsal Space- Because this is student theatre, we may not have a permanent rehearsal space, which means getting bounced around from one classroom to another. This is not a big drawback, but it does mean that there will be a little extra chaos throughout the process.
    3. Students- This is a Senior Capstone Project, which means that everything is on the students. The faculty will offer guidance if it is asked for, but otherwise, the entire production is in the hands of the students working on it. This means that there will inevitably be some bumps in the road and times when we are not quite sure what to do. The students who will be working on this with me are all experienced, so I believe that we will be able to smooth out the bumps as we go along. 

    Thank you for your interest in my project!

Students- This is a Senior Capstone Project, which means that everything is on the students. The faculty will offer guidance if it is asked for, but otherwise, the entire production is in the hands of the students working on it. This means that there will inevitably be some bumps in the road and times when we are not quite sure what to do. The students who will be working on this with me are all experienced, so I believe that we will be able to smooth out the bumps as we go along. 

  Thank you for your interest in my project!

story:
Short Summary

Marc Bogaerts, a critically acclaimed Belgian choreographer who has become renowned for his unconventional combinations of physical expression to create dynamic and complex performances. On November 11, 2018 Marc Bogaerts, in partnership with EOS Cultural Events & IESA, will present S.P.O.R.T - Sans Barrière , a showcase highlighting his next piece that aims to bring about greater recognition to societal perceptions and reception of disabled people through the Paralympic Games and explore how dance and art transcend perceptions of ability. This one night only event will bring together specialists and artists working in this sector to begin a dialogue in preparation for the Paris 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

For the past decade, Bogaerts has been in working in close collaboration with Olympic and Paralympic athletes to create new works that bring art and sport together. Through these pieces he is able to meld the physical vocabulary of sport and dance, allowing the viewer to see the athlete as a dancer with their movements taking on new symbolism and grace, and the dancer as an athlete whose full training gets to be on display. This combination of genres combined with their innate ability to build community, make Bogaerts work ideal for the Paris 2024 Games as the Olympic Committee begins to plan accompanying events for the 2024 games in the city. The first step to reaching this larger goal is to begin doing outreach through showcases and workshops like this. 

Bogaert’s S.P.O.R.T. redefines dance and ability. His universally inclusive approach to fostering creative expression and perception empowers all those that experience the work. Join us in igniting this mission, inspiring personal stories that transcend dance and expand our understanding of how we can all collaborate as one.

What We Need 

Producing a large scale project to coincide with the 2024 Paris Olympic and Paralympic Games is a multi-step initiative, with this showcase being a key component as we begin to build a community around this work. Your funds will go to support the following:

  • Stipends for the participants including disabled athletes, professional dancers and expert presenters for their time and efforts in bringing this vision to life
  • A handicap accessible venue for the performance and rehearsal spaces

Ce Dont Nous Avons Besoin

Produire un projet à grande échelle dans la perspective des Jeux Olympiques et Paralympiques de 2024 est la première étape de notre initiative, ce spectacle étant un élément clef alors que nous construisons une communauté autour de ce projet. Votre aide ira tout droit au financement :

  • des indemnités attribuées aux participants à l’évènement : les athlètes paralympiques, les danseurs professionnels et les intervenants experts dans leur discipline qui par leur temps et leur expertise mènent à bien ce projet
  • de la salle de spectacle accessible pour l’évènement et les journées de répétition.

The Impact

Your contribution will go directly to supporting the artists and experts who work tirelessly to create greater recognition for the Paralympic Games, and  bring awareness to how the lack of public engagement in this event as compared to the Olympic Games reflects a greater societal issue on our engagement with disabled or handicapped individuals.

Any additional funds will be donated to the French Paralympic Committee.

L'impact

Votre contribution aidera directement à mener à bien le travail des artistes et des experts qui travaillent inlassablement pour assurer une plus grande visibilité aux Jeux Paralympiques, ainsi que pour sensibiliser le public sur le manque d’engagement lors de cet évènement qui suit les Jeux Olympiques. Ce travail de sensibilisation est un enjeu de société pour lequel nous nous engageons avec les personnes en situation de handicap. Tout fonds supplémentaires seront reversés au profit du Comité paralympique et sportif français.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in these issues we encourage you to support these initiatives and this project by joining us at the showcase on Sunday, November 11th in Paris, France or by supporting your local Paralympic committee and athletes!

Autres Moyens de Nous Aider

Si ces questions vous intéressent, vous touchent et suscitent votre intérêt, encouragez notre initiative et ce projet et vous joignant à nous le 11 novembre 2018 à Paris, ou en soutenant les comités paralympiques et les athlètes!

story:
CUBE Ensemble & Carmen

This is CUBE’s introduction into the public as a company that promotes collaboration. Music and Theater come together in a remarkable way with CUBE's adaptation of Carmen. Here, Carmen is stripped of all excess and left raw to uncover the deep-rooted narrative of a woman's quest for freedom from societal expectations.

As an ensemble, we are dedicated to excellence and creating an experimental space for performers to grow and contribute to their community. We gave this project a long incubation period (started music rehearsals in October) to teach singers viewpoints technique and train in theater to a degree unprecedented in modern opera practice.


What We Need & What You Get

Cost of show: 10,000

Already raised: 4,000

Closing the gap with Indiegogo Goal: $6,000

CUBE's recent fundraiser brought in an incredible amount of support and awareness to La tragedie de Carmen! We are now asking for help from you to close the gap on our fundraising goal of 10,000 dollars!


$100 pays our website fees
$200 pays for 1 performer, we have 10 (4 singers, 5 understudies, 1 actor)
$250 each pays our lighting designer and our set designer.

$300 pays our Stage Manager

$500 Pays a Music and Stage Director, respectively

$1,000 pays for printing and marketing costs

$1,000 pays for rehearsal space.
$3,000 pays for our performance space.

That leaves only $925 as "just in case" budget for any overage costs.

While we are not paying our cast and crew nearly what they deserve for their phenomenal work and steadfast dedication, this is what we could put together for a reasonable budget.

We have some great perks for you when you donate. The Grand Prize being a private performance of our production of Carmen for you and your friends! Look over to the right of your screen and check out what other cool perks we have for you!


How You Make A Difference

Opera does not need to be performed in a grandiose theater nor does it need to cost an arm and a leg. We are striving to make all forms of theatre affordable and accessible for all. We are also striving to pay our artists. Too often, paying artists falls to the wayside.   We do what we do because we love it and have a real passion for it. Admirable as that is, love and passion are not enough to sustain our livelihood. 

With your contributions, you help us in making affordable productions a reality. Your contributions also help pay our young artists for their dedication, art, and most of all the hard work they have put in to this production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about us! After you make a contribution, pass this on to 3 friends and family members and ask them to spare $5 and ask them to pass it on to another 3 people. A little bit goes a loooong way. Also, if we do not reach our goal in 45 days, WE GET NOTHING! So all the help is appreciated!

After you donate:

"Like" our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/cubeensemble

Follow us on Twitter @cubeensemble

Visit our website www.cubeensemble.com

THANK YOU!

story:
The Spot was founded in September of 2014 as a new performing arts studio for the Wood River Valley. Having spent several summers working with theaters in the area, Peter Burke, Kevin Wade, Yanna Lantz, and Brett Moellenberg opened up shop to continue fostering arts education for the youth of the Valley and to create a new venue for all kinds of performance and visual art. 


We've recently learned that the "assembly use" portion of our business, namely shows with audiences (that's you!), are not permitted in the Light Industrial District where we are located. Because of this, The Spot needs to apply for a text amendment and Permitted/Conditional Use Permit to continue bringing our cutting edge style of theatre to the Valley. 

Why We Need You!

The costs associated include an application fee and retainer for the city's lawyers. In addition, once we are able to get the amendment passed, we have a wish-list of items for The Spot (including seating/lighting equipment) that we will implement to truly transform our space into our vision – a community hub for artistic growth and transformation. 

Since closing our groundbreaking and completely sold-out production of "Next to Normal" in January, we have been excited to continue building what will become a destination for artists and audiences across the country. Your contribution is an investment in youthful, vibrant art in your community; and, we are proud to call this place our home.The Future Goal...

More plays, musicals, events, live music shows, dance parties and as many artistic assemblies for the community as possible! 

Since we had already secured rights to mount the Tony Award winning comedy "25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee," July 29-August 9 2015, prior to news of our current permitted use as stated in the city's bylaws, we have been granted permission by the city to continue production. We would love to see you in the audience. 
MEET THE SPELLERS: 
*Check back throughout the week for new videos!*
MARCY

OLIVE

LOGAINNE

Many of our perks for this campaign are directly associated with the upcoming production – take a look! We would love to have your support. 
Thank you for your time and consideration. 
With hope,                                                          
The Spot Founders 
-Peter, Brett, Kevin & Yanna

story:
Hello!

We are a Winnipeg-based theatre company with a simple goal:
To produce theatre we love and want Winnipeggers to love too.

You might remember us from several of our past productions, including: the Winnipeg premiere of Avenue Q, Into the Woods and The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs.

We are seeking your support to help us continue to produce more exciting theatre events. We have two weeks to meet our annual fundraising goal, and we hope you can help us out!


Here is the truth:

We depend on the kindness of strangers who buy tickets and support us through fundraising initiatives. We love what we do and we want to do it in Winnipeg. With your support, we can continue to produce the work we love.

Right now we are working on two exciting projects that we need your help with:


MR. BURNS, A POST-ELECTRIC PLAY
April 28 - May 7, 2016 - Rachel Browne Theatre
www.mrburnswinnipeg.com

The highly-anticipated play that has surprised, thrilled, confused and divided audiences. In a world where the electrical grid has fallen and society has crumbled, a group of survivors band together to try to recount an episode of The Simpsons. This dark comedy propels into an unlikely post-catastrophe, post-electricity future where the pop culture of one era has evolved into the mythology of another. Part pop operetta, part chilling contemporary allegory, and part Simpsons celebration, Mr. Burns, a post-electric play is an unapologetically wild and inventive exploration of storytelling, live theatre, and the resilience of Bart Simpson through the ages.


SING OUT, LOUISE!

A gathering for showtune fans and allies. Once a month we provide a theme, a microphone, an accompanist, and a safe space for professional and amateur performers alike to come sing and make memories with other musical theatre artists and fans. Featuring a different theme every month, this free event provides the opportunity to come see Winnipeg’s best sing!


Where does the money go?

District Theatre employs professional actors, directors, designers, and production managers and believe in properly compensating artists for their work. Sing Out, Louise! is a free event designed to create a safe space for the musical theatre community to perform. Ticket sales only cover about half the costs of putting on a play or musical. We depend on grants, corporate sponsorships and generous donations to pay for sets, costumes, props, royalties, and to compensate artists.


Who we are

District Theatre is a project-based company that produces plays, musicals and theatrical events that excite us. By not programming a season of productions or selling subscriptions, we are able to produce what we want, when we want. We like to choose productions that not only push the boundaries and provoke discussion, but that are injected with heart and humour. With the success of our past productions, we have cultivated an audience that is engaged, responsive and sometimes a bit wild. Founded by Connie Manfredi and Ryan Segal, we harness the talents of Winnipeg actors, singers, directors, designers, stage managers and production staff.

story:
Who we are

We are Flying High Theatre Company. We are a group of young people aged 15-19 who have a real passion for theatre and the arts. Being a part of Flying High has provided us with the opportunity to perform in productions at theatres and venues around the UK, such as Sheffield Crucible, Derby Theatre, Nottingham Playhouse, Edinburgh Fringe Festival and the celebrated National Theatre in London.

What we are doing

This year we will be performing an adaptation with songs of J.M Barrie's Peter Pan at the fringe from the 5th-13th of August and with this being our 9th year at the festival, we want to have as great an experience as the previous years.

Peter Pan

theSpace @ Niddry Street

Aug 5-13

12:15pm (50 mins) (Sunday's at 3:30pm)

This adaptation of Peter Pan begins in the nursery and will transport the audience to the home of the lost boys, marooner's Rock I n the mermaids lagoon and the notorious Jolly Roger Pirate Ship. In addition, the songs and moments of comedic physical theatre sequences will delight children and families alike. In 2013 Flying High's adaptation was awarded 4 stars from both BroadwayBaby.com and ThreeWeeks.

Previous Shows

Forty-Five Minutes                                                     Jungle Book

  Alice by Heart                                                  Peter Pan

 

"An energetic young cast deliver a slick performance capturing the kookiness and humour that is asynonymous with Carroll's Wonderland tales.” – **** Three Weeks (2012)

“Flying High Theatre Company is aptly named; that is exactly what this group of lively youngsters do throughout this performance.” – **** Broadway Baby (2014)

“The acting as a whole was largely impressive… a recommendable adaptation for both those who are new to the material and those who know it well.” – *** Broadway Baby (2014)

What we're hoping for

We are looking to raise £2,000 to help the company of 18 with costumes and living cost whilst at the festival. With your contributions you will not only be helping us with dressing and feeding the company but also providing us with the chance to see pieces of theatre that will inspire and motivate us in our passion for theatre. 

We are a young peoples company and so anything you can contribute will be very much appreciated, as you will helping to provide us with a great experience as part of one the world's largest arts festivals, for which some of the company members is their first time.

What you will receive

As a thank you for your donations you will receive something in return, for example for a £10 donation you will receive a a signed copy of the shows poster or a £50  donation will provide you with 2 free tickets to either our Nottingham previews on the 2nd August or to any of our shows in Edinburgh.

Thank you in advance for your consideration and we hope you can find something to contribute. If not, thank you anyway and help us to raise our funds by spreading the word either via our twitter: @FlyingHighCo or via Facebook Flying High Theatre Company.

Thank you again and happy donating

Flying High Theatre Company

story:
A HOTEL IN EDEN, both as a play and as a production, is a story of individuals from vastly different backgrounds uniting for a common quest. 


In the play, two individuals are thrown together in impossible circumstances, and are tasked with the unreal responsibility of rebuilding humanity. In life, this production started as a conversation between two coworkers on break. Now, the production has grown from an idea to a world premier production at one of the well known theatre festivals in New York City. As the day of opening approaches, our production company humbly asks friends, family and colleagues for assistance in seeing this play come to life onstage in October. First, we would like to tell you a bit more about ourselves, and the play itself. 


We believe it is important to produce this play because it examines the world we have created for ourselves, and the way we live our lives today. It is an investigation into what we hold dear, how we interact with those we meet and who we are when nobody is looking. The  play speaks to the spirit of society today, and addresses the society we are creating for tomorrow. 


CAST OF CHARACTERS


Jackson K. Hanks (Playwright) - Jackson K. Hanks was born in Moscow, Idaho and raised in Kingman, Arizona. He began his life in theatre in a humble production of A Hillbilly Christmas Carol - a simple western parody of the famous story that was only fitting for a simple western town. He continued all throughout high school and eventually left Arizona to attend the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York City, where he has been ever since. Though he is trained for acting, he is excited to make his debut as a writer. 


Nathaniel P. Claridad (Director) - Nathaniel is a Manhattan based director and actor. NYC: The Trojan Women (Oppressed in Heels), Man. Kind (Working Theater), The Breasts of Tiresias (Peculiar Works Project); with Wagon Wheel Arts: Triassic Parq, Dustin Lance Black's "8" featuring Jose Llana and Gavin Creel (Co-producer/Assistant Director, Playmakers Repertory Company, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill); the annual event Broadway Twisted, benefitting North Carolina AIDS Action Network & BC/EFA (Co-producer/Director). Regionally: Our Town (Assistant Director, Two River Theater), It's a Wonderful Life (Assistant Director, Playmakers Reportory Company). For UNC: Eurydice, Tender Napalm, Shakespeare's R & J. As actor: Off-Broadway/NYC include: Here Lies Love (The Public Theater), The Awesome 80's Prom, Titus Andronicus (New York Shakespeare Exchange), as well as NYMF, PS1222, and National Asian Artists Project. National Tour: Alice (The Kennedy Center); Regional includes the Kennedy Center, PlayMakers Repertory Company, Folger Theatre, Shakespeare Theatre Company of DC, Cape Fear Regional, Imagination Stage, Hangar Theatre, and Barrington Stage Company. Other: Drama League Artist-in-Residence 2015/2016; The Civilians' Field Research Team 2014/2015. MFA: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. 


Sean Hinckle (Producer) - Sean Hinckle is a Kansas City native and New York transplant. He has worked as both an actor and teaching artist in Chicago, Kansas City, Oklahoma, Florida and now New York. Most recently seen in the New York Shakespeare Exchange production of Shakespeare's, Hamlet. 



THE STORY 

Jackson had been writing throughout school, and decided to steer his efforts and energy completely toward writing after graduation. Jackson's world collided with Sean's, when they worked together at a little wine bar in Murray Hill. After realizing their common interest in new plays, they began to discuss Jackson's work. Soon after reading A Hotel in Eden, the two decided to  produce it. 


Almost as soon as the decision to produce this new play was made, it was selected as a participant in the upcoming Thespis Festival. Thespis Festival is a wonderful opportunity for new works to see the stage for the first time, and hopefully launch to larger venues. Needless to say, Sean and Jackson leapt at the opportunity to participate. What seemed like moments later, Nathaniel P. Claridad was attached as the director. Thus, the triumvirate was born. 


Since its inception, A Hotel in Eden  has been in development in preparation for the festival performance dates. It saw a staged reading at Shetler Studios in June, and has been reworked and refined since. Now, the development is picking up momentum as the company inches ever nearer the first rehearsal date, and eventual opening. 


THE FESTIVAL

Thespis Festival is a long-running independent New York theatre festival that has been the birthplace of many incredible new plays and musicals. The festival itself draws thousands of spectators from many different mediums of live performance. A Hotel in Eden will be presented as part of the festival on October 3rd and 5th at 9PM, and on October 8th at 3:30PM. All performances will take place at the Hudson Guild Theatre at 441 W. 26th Street. 

Tickets can be purchased through Brown Paper Tickets at: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2582682 


We are seeking $1,000 for our production fund, so this play can be introduced to the public in the proper way. As a team, we are devoted to paying our artists for their efforts. This is the majority of our production cost. Outside of that, paying for rehearsal spaces in New York is a challenge we continue to face. Finally, the funds will be used to promote the show and the festival to the people of New York City.
story_txt: A HOTEL IN EDEN, both as a play and as a production, is a story of individuals from vastly different backgrounds uniting for a common quest. In the play, two individuals are thrown together in impossible circumstances, and are tasked with the unreal responsibility of rebuilding humanity. In life, this production started as a conversation between two coworkers on break. Now, the production has grown from an idea to a world premier production at one of the well known theatre festivals in New York City. As the day of opening approaches, our production company humbly asks friends, family and colleagues for assistance in seeing this play come to life onstage in October. First, we would like to tell you a bit more about ourselves, and the play itself. We believe it is important to produce this play because it examines the world we have created for ourselves, and the way we live our lives today. It is an investigation into what we hold dear, how we interact with those we meet and who we are when nobody is looking. The  play speaks to the spirit of society today, and addresses the society we are creating for tomorrow. CAST OF CHARACTERSJackson K. Hanks (Playwright) - Jackson K. Hanks was born in Moscow, Idaho and raised in Kingman, Arizona. He began his life in theatre in a humble production of A Hillbilly Christmas Carol - a simple western parody of the famous story that was only fitting for a simple western town. He continued all throughout high school and eventually left Arizona to attend the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in New York City, where he has been ever since. Though he is trained for acting, he is excited to make his debut as a writer. Nathaniel P. Claridad (Director) - Nathaniel is a Manhattan based director and actor. NYC: The Trojan Women (Oppressed in Heels), Man. Kind (Working Theater), The Breasts of Tiresias (Peculiar Works Project); with Wagon Wheel Arts: Triassic Parq, Dustin Lance Black's "8" featuring Jose Llana and Gavin Creel (Co-producer/Assistant Director, Playmakers Repertory Company, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill); the annual event Broadway Twisted, benefitting North Carolina AIDS Action Network & BC/EFA (Co-producer/Director). Regionally: Our Town (Assistant Director, Two River Theater), It's a Wonderful Life (Assistant Director, Playmakers Reportory Company). For UNC: Eurydice, Tender Napalm, Shakespeare's R & J. story:
CHELSEA&MAGDA

Have been making original dance/theater duets since they met at the Headlong Performance Institute in 2012.  

A year ago they became completely excited about shame in performance.  Through Swim Pony's Cross Pollination Residency they met photographer Jaime Alvarez and began taking Shame Portraits of local performers. Then they went to Martha's Vineyard through a DancetheYard Residency and created many of their improvisational and pedagogical structures for performing shame.  They have been teaching at UArts and rehearsing their brains out.  The Shame Symposium is the first opportunity to present and explosively perform that research.
More info and tickets are here.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising $4500 to cover some of the costs of this show, like: a sound designer, a costume designer, a production manager, a good video of the thing, a stipend for several performers and printing the photographs.
  • There are good gift options- the best one is "Chelsea's Performance Panties."

The Fantasy/Vision

The idea is that if we invest in this show now, we can take it anywhere.  We want to tour it internationally and see how it interacts with the shame of other cultures.  By making it as excellent as possible now, we are hoping that we can move it move it move it.  Japan is first on our list.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whenever we do a show we have trouble eating.  We don't have the energy to cook for ourselves.  We don't crave anything.  We walk around pumped up on adrenaline and mumble notes to each other.  If you can't give money but you want to leave food on our doorstep, please contact us through our website at www.everybodygetinthecar.com.  (And if you know anyone in Japan.)

story:
(ENGLISH TEXT BELOW)

Hallo lieve mensen,

Voor ons afstuderen gaan wij, Judith en Maud, naar Zuid-Afrika om daar onderzoek te doen voor onze opleiding creatieve therapie dans en beweging. Dans- en bewegingstherapie is een vorm van non-verbale therapie waarbij je jezelf uitdrukt door middel van dans en bewegen. Bij deze therapie vorm is het niet per se nodig om te praten, je mag ervaren! Dans- en bewegingstherapie richt zich primair op het door middel van experimenteren met beweging nieuwe gevoelens en zijnswijze te exploreren en toegang te krijgen tot gevoelens die moeilijk toegankelijk zijn (Van Keulen, 2007). De American Dance Movement Therapy Association (www.adta.org) vertelt over dans- en bewegingstherapie dat cognitieve, sociale, emotionele en fysieke processen met elkaar geïntegreerd worden.  In Zuid-Afrika leeft de dans en beweging in de cultuur. Vanuit een eerder onderzoek van muziektherapiestudenten werd dans en beweging dan ook aanbevolen aan de stichting The Pebbles Project (www.pebblesproject.co.za).

Ons onderzoek vindt plaats in Stellenbosch, een wijnstreek in de buurt van Kaapstad. We gaan daar werken met kinderen van het personeel op wijnboerderijen met een leeftijd variërend van 2 tot 5 jaar. Deze kinderen verblijven overdag in een crèche die opgezet is door de stichting The Pebbles Project.

Deze kinderen zijn onderontwikkeld door verschillende oorzaken. Een mogelijke oorzaak is het gebruik van alcohol door de ouders, ook tijdens de zwangerschap, verwaarlozing en leerachterstand.

Wij gaan onderzoeken hoe we de kinderen met dans en beweging kunnen helpen. Daarbij betrekken we de leerkrachten om hun intrinsieke motivatie te stimuleren zodat zij het door kunnen zetten op het moment dat wij weer vertrekken. Om het voor hun makkelijker te maken laten wij een draaiboek achter waar de leerkrachten mee kunnen werken.

Wij willen graag voor ons onderzoek geld inzamelen. Het geld dat wij inzamelen dient voor:

- Het kopen van materialen voor het onderzoek. Deze materialen laten we daar achter op het moment dat wij vertrekken. We willen deze materialen in Zuid-Afrika zelf kopen om de economie daar te steunen. Onder materialen verstaan wij ballonnen, sjaaltjes, doeken, cd’s, etc. Deze gebruiken we in de sessies met de kinderen. Op het moment zelf kijken we wat werkt en bruikbaar is om de therapie te geven en over te dragen. Daarnaast laten we een draaiboek achter met de werkvormen die wij hebben onderzocht. Dit draaiboek wordt ook van deze donaties bekostigd om een kwalitatief goed boek achter te laten waar ze langere periode iets aan hebben.

- Om een deel van onze reis en het onderzoek te bekostigen. Vanuit het project zelf krijgen wij geen vergoeding maar wel de mogelijkheid om ons onderzoek daar te kunnen verrichten. Dans- en bewegingstherapie wordt via het lichaam overgedragen. Wij nemen dus geen extra materialen mee, zoals schoolboeken. Wij zijn zelf het materiaal dat ingezet wordt om dit onderzoek te laten plaatsvinden. Hierdoor proberen wij de samenleving/ontwikkeling in Zuid-Afrika op de wijnboerderijen te helpen op de best mogelijke manier.

We houden jullie op de hoogte van de vorderingen van het onderzoek zodat jullie weten waar het geld naar toe gaat. We hopen dat u ons kunt helpen. Zo niet met geld, kunnen jullie ons altijd helpen met het verspreiden van dit project! Deel ons verhaal zodat meer mensen het leren kennen!

Interesse in meer? Als jullie ons helpen, bieden wij jullie ook iets aan! Het draaiboek dat we gaan maken, kunnen we delen en wordt geschreven in het Engels en Afrikaans. De presentatie voor onze scriptie kan worden bijgewoond en de scriptie zelf kunnen we opsturen als deze af en beoordeeld is!

Alvast bedankt voor de steun die we van jullie mogen ontvangen. Dat waarderen wij met ons hele hart!

Lieve groetjes,

Judith & Maud

ps. we houden ook een apart blog bij: danstherapieinzuidafrika.blog.com

--------------------------------------------------------------

Hello dear people,

In the context of our bachelor thesis, we - Judith and Maud - are going to South Africa to do research related to our study: Dance Movement Therapy. According to the American Dance Movement Therapy Association (www.adta.org) Dance/Movement Therapy uses movement to "further the emotional, cognitive, physical and social integration of the individual."  Through movement, Dance Movement Therapy can help individuals with a wide range of psychological disorders achieve greater self-expression. Within Dance Movement Therapy, different ways of working with and through the body are explored and utilized. Dance and movement is a big part of the South-African culture and it has therefore been advised by previous research carried out by music therapists, to be explored as an alternative, innovative way of working with The Pebbles Project (www.pebblesproject.co.za).

Our research will be taking place in Stellenbosch, a wine region near Capetown. Here, we will be working with children of the staff from the winefarms between the ages of 2 and 5 years old. During the day, these children stay in a nursery, which was established by The Pebbles Project.

These children are underdeveloped because of different factors. Possible causes are the use of alcohol by the parents, also during pregnancy, neglect and learning deficits.

We will be exploring in what ways dance and movement can positively benefit these children. In order to ensure the work we are going to be doing with the children, will be an ongoing event in the future, we are going to involve the teachers into this process to stimulate their intrinsic motivation. To make the process more comprehensible, a script will be made and left behind for the teachers.

For this research, we would love to collect some money. The money raised will be spent on:
- Buying materials for the research. Everything we buy, will stay in South Africa when we leave. To support the South African economy, we are going to buy all of these materials in South Africa. When we say materials, we mean: balloons, scarfs, bandanas/rags, CDs, etc. These are going to be used in the therapy sessions. Which materials will be used in which session is a decision we are going to make accordingly, taking into account the unique factors of that moment. In addition: a script containing practicalities, written methods and such will be put together by us. Through funding it with the raised money, we would like to leave an endurable, quality script behind.

-To partially finance our trip and research project. The project itself (Pebbles) will not financially reimburse our trip. They are, however, making it possible for us to conduct our research. Because dance movement therapy is transferred through the body and with the body, in essence no other products are necessary. Therefore we will not be bringing along any school books, for example. We, ourselves, are the material which will be used to conduct this research project. With this, we will try our best to help these South African wineries’ society and development.

We will keep you posted on the progress of the research, so you know what is happening to the raised money! We hope you can help us, if not with money maybe you can help us with spreading our words. Share this story so more people get to know it!

If you are interested in the script which assists you in dance & movement with children, which will be in English & Afrikaans. So we can send it to you! Check out the perks. 

Thank you in advance for the support we are lucky to receive, for that we are grateful with all of our hearts!

Love, 

Judith & Maud

story:
Always Love Lucy Theatre is back! It's time to learn "All About Eve"! 

We had a stellar beginning with our multicultural "Death of a Salesman" in June 2014, and we cannot thank our audience enough for coming out and seeing what Miller had to say through a brand-new lens. We cast the Lomans as South Asians and all other roles went to the best audition, resulting in a multicultural cast that ended up bring the kind of friends that are family off-stage.

Let's bring them back with Mary Orr's classic play-about-putting-on-a-play!

All About Eve was released as a film in 1950 -- it is the first of only two films to receive 14 Academy Award nominations (and win 6), including Best Picture. (The other in 1997's Titanic.) It is still the only movie where all 4 female leads were nominated for an Oscar.

We want more actresses in these roles, and will put the show up in 2015.

story:
I'm Shayne Anderson, and I am producing and acting in Robert Anderson's "I Never Sang For My Father." Theater has always been my first love.  For me there is nothing quite like the sense of communion an actor gets with a live audience. A great artist once said, people don't to the theater to see other people, they go to see themselves.

The main reason I wanted to mount this play is a deep personal connection with the material. The father and son relationship at the center of this play is both touching and heartbreaking. The themes are ageless and universal. Who among us hasn't at one time or another had a challenging relationship with a parent or child? 

Most people are aware of how costly it is to produce theater. The exorbitant prices of the venue, marketing, rehearsal space, and set construction/tech have made it necessary to seek funding assistance from people like you who believe the arts need to be supported in these tempestuous times. Any contribution to this project will have an enormous impact on our ability to present this timeless classic which I believe has the ability to help heal and illuminate the family dynamic of the human condition. 

With your help and contributions we can bring this play to life. This play is as relevant today as when it was first performed in 1968. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $8,500. This will cover production costs associated with our six week run from March 27-May 3. 

There are some amazing perks that we'll be able to share with supporters, including signed show posters, front row seats to opening or closing night.  Hey, you can even be a producer and get your name in the program. Woo! Hoo! 

If we don't make our goal, the funds that we raise will still go directly to the production, whether it be for theater rental, set construction, costumes, or marketing. 

The Impact

Your contribution will be immediately used for the following necessities:

$5,000 for theatre rental costs;
$1,200 for designer stipends;
$1,300 for set design and construction;
$1,000 for costume/lighting design.

Whatever you can contribute will will help to keep independent theater alive and thriving. 

Risks & Challenges

We understand the risks that we are taking on with this project. The costs that accrue for LA theater can be staggering. We understand that theater is sometimes best when scaled down and simplified, and we will adjust accordingly to whatever budget we find ourselves with. While we prefer to have all the elements of the production that we envision now, we are no strangers to small budgets and DIY production.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand the fact that some of you simply can't support the piece by contributing money. That's cool! There are other ways you can support us: Get the word out by sharing this campaign with the people in your circle. Show us you understand the plight of the independent artist by sharing this on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, or any other social site that can help us get the word out. Thank you!
story_txt:
I'm Shayne Anderson, and I am producing and acting in Robert Anderson's "I Never Sang For My Father." Theater has always been my first love.  For me there is nothing quite like the sense of communion an actor gets with a live audience. A great artist once said, people don't to the theater to see other people, they go to see themselves.
The main reason I wanted to mount this play is a deep personal connection with the material. The father and son relationship at the center of this play is both touching and heartbreaking. The themes are ageless and universal. Who among us hasn't at one time or another had a challenging relationship with a parent or child? 
Most people are aware of how costly it is to produce theater. The exorbitant prices of the venue, marketing, rehearsal space, and set construction/tech have made it necessary to seek funding assistance from people like you who believe the arts need to be supported in these tempestuous times. Any contribution to this project will have an enormous impact on our ability to present this timeless classic which I believe has the ability to help heal and illuminate the family dynamic of the human condition. 
With your help and contributions we can bring this play to life. This play is as relevant today as when it was first performed in 1968. 

What We Need & What You Get
We are looking to raise $8,500. This will cover production costs associated with our six week run from March 27-May 3. 
There are some amazing perks that we'll be able to share with supporters, including signed show posters, front row seats to opening or closing night.  Hey, you can even be a producer and get your name in the program. Woo! Hoo! 
If we don't make our goal, the funds that we raise will still go directly to the production, whether it be for theater rental, set construction, costumes, or marketing.

$5,000 for theatre rental costs;$1,200 for designer stipends;$1,300 for set design and construction;$1,000 for costume/lighting design.
Whatever you can contribute will will help to keep independent theater alive and thriving. 

Risks & Challenges
We understand the risks that we are taking on with this project. The costs that accrue for LA theater can be staggering. We understand that theater is sometimes best when scaled down and simplified, and we will adjust accordingly to whatever budget we find ourselves with. While we prefer to have all the elements of the production that we envision now, we are no strangers to small budgets and DIY production.

story:
Help us create positive change in the world by supporting a special project for the 2014-15 school year in Fort Worth.  

Your tax-deductible donation will support:

  • Jessica Thomas' work as a teaching artist in the schools
  • A pilot project after-school dance program at South Hills Elementary School, along with daytime creative movement classes
  • Contemporary Dance/Fort Worth's "Dance Delivered" Educational Programming in area public schools


Jessica Thomas is already a recognized arts educator, performer, and choreographer in the North Texas area. Her work as a "Dance Delivered" teaching artist began in 2010 after joining Contemporary Dance/Fort Worth in 2009. Since then, she has frequently contributed her choreography to the company's group collaborations and continues to perform her own solo works throughout the community. 
The "Dance Delivered" outreach program at South Hills Elementary School will allow Jessica to share the numerous benefits of dance to an even greater number of children throughout Fort Worth, while providing South Hills students with an in-depth performing arts experience which is not usually a part of the curriculum.
"Dance is my passion! I am so excited to share its endless benefits with the kids at South Hills Elementary School!" - Jessica Thomas


Benefits:
  • Enhance body awareness (control, balance, coordination)
  • Improve teamwork and cooperation
  • Deepen self-esteem and self-discipline
  • Improve motor skills to dance freely with creativity
  • Develop new neural pathways leading to increased learning in other subjects areas (Reading, Science, Math)
  • Encourage attention and focus in the present moment
  • Exercise creative problem-solving skills
  • Increase willingness to share and explore new ideas
  • Foster joy in self-expression and connecting with others
South Hills Elementary School:
  • Student population of approx. 885 students
  • 87.8% Economically Disadvantaged
  • 59.5% English Language Learners
  • 65.1% At-Risk
  • Students in this neighborhood do not have access to a community center for after-school programs.
  • The majority of South Hills students cannot afford to participate in extra-curricular classes or training outside of school.
  • South Hills administrators and PTA representatives welcome the opportunity to provide after-school dance classes on campus, and will work with CD/FW to create a "pilot project" model for consideration on other school campuses in future years.
"Dancing together, we experience the magic of creative expression and connecting with others. We are liberated into new feelings of joy, inspiration, and personal transformation." - Jessica Thomas

A study of Missouri Public Schools in 2010 found that greater arts education led to fewer disciplinary infractions and higher graduation rates and test scores.  Read more about this study by the Missouri Alliance for Arts Education here.




Jessica Thomas' Personal Goals and Philosophies

"I hope to continue my own creative research and exploration by attending graduate school or an artist residency during the Fall of 2015. Taking this year to focus on expanding Contemporary Dance/Fort Worth's  'Dance Delivered' outreach program will certainly help to widen my own dance education/performance experiences to carry into the future."

"Dance is the platform from which all of my other creative inquires spring. It's how I connect fully with myself and the world. In this place, my head is clear and my heart is alive."
"To be immersed in this endless exploration is a beautiful gift and something I will always yearn to experience and share with others."
Resources Needed:
  • $40,000 to contract Jessica to direct and execute special dance programming at South Hills Elementary School, including the implementation of a pilot program for after-school dance classes and a series of daytime creative movement master classes during the regular school day.  As time allows, she will also visit other Fort Worth ISD schools during the 2014-2015 School Year and assist with "Dance Delivered" programs on other campuses.  
  • $10,000 to help cover expenses for college intern teaching assistants, supplies, and general overhead related to the program.  The TCU School for Classical & Contemporary Dance has expressed interest in helping to recruit student interns among university dance majors who are also pursuing teaching certificates in dance so they can gain "real world" experience working with young people in public school settings.
  •  Your donation will not only help others to dance...  We've put together some very unique perks to encourage YOU and your family to dance at home!  Be sure to check out the diversity of options from the Isadora "Prima Diva" Dance Pack to the Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly options, or dance kits for young children.   With just a $10 donation you can even receive a bookmark just like we give to students at all of our "Dance Delivered" classes and lecture-performances.
  • If we do not reach our goal, the funds raised will still be dedicated to "Dance Delivered" educational outreach programs in FWISD schools, Jessica will be the primary teacher and administrator for the programs supported by those funds, and Jessica will still serve South Hills Elementary as a teaching artist on their campus, providing a series of creative movement master classes for a variety of grade levels.


The Impact

  • Dance changes lives!
  • CD/FW has presenting educational outreach programs in area schools since the company's inception in 1990.   The organization is supported in part by the Arts Council of Fort Worth and their Neighborhood Arts Program in collaboration with the City of Fort Worth and the Texas Commission on the Arts with the National Endowment for the Arts.


Risks & Challenges

While outreach work always has many risks and challenges, we are particularly excited about this project because representatives from South Hills Elementary School first approached CD/FW to investigate ways we could work together to provide dance experiences for their students.  So we are entering this project with a group of partners fully invested in the concept, and open to trying something new.

CD/FW has been presenting a diversity of educational outreach programs in FWISD schools for many years, but has never attempted to start an after-school program on a school campus.  We will be taking our accumulated knowledge and applying it to a new formula for offering dance experiences for kids.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Be our dancing partner!  Help spread the word about our fund raising campaign to support Jessica Thomas' work as a teaching artist and CD/FW's "Dance Delivered" educational outreach programs.  Like/Share this project with friends, family, and colleagues.  Help us share the joy of dance with kids throughout our community!
  • Don't forget you can use Indiegogo share tools to make it even easier to share the news with all of your social media networks.

Be our dancing partner!  Help spread the word about our fund raising campaign to support Jessica Thomas' work as a teaching artist and CD/FW's "Dance Delivered" educational outreach programs.  Like/Share this project with friends, family, and colleagues.  Help us share the joy of dance with kids throughout our community!

story:
The Vintage Theatre Company, LLC is a community of West Virginia actors and artists who come together to share their talents, time, and resources to improve the cultural capitol of the mountain state. 

Three years ago, West Virginia was one of the only states without a Shakespeare festival or company dedicated to performing his works. There is no playwright in the English language with more far reaching and prolific language than William Shakespeare so to say that we West Virginians were missing out, would be an understatement. 

Then in July 2013, The Vintage Theatre Company founded The Rustic Mechanicals. 

That first summer, we performed one show with seven actors in four tour locations. Only two short years later we produce three full length shows a year and have grown to include over seventeen cast members and have performed in over twenty different locations around the state. We’ve played on some of the largest and smallest stages in the state, bringing the magic, power, and poetry of Shakespeare’s wordcraft to all West Virginians. 

Your generous contribution will go to help not only The Rustic Mechanicals spread the gospel of Shakespeare, but to The Fearless Fools, our improv comedy team, Montanti Cantani, our Opera troupe, Comedy for a Cause, our murder mystery dinner theatre troupe, and the Vintage Theatre’s educational partner's The Performing Arts Conservatory at Notre Dame High School. 

Because we love Shakespeare language so much, we’re offering you a truly special thank you! Donate only $15 to the cause and we will, in true Shakespearean high style, have one of our trained Shakespearean actors insult you or flatter you on the social media outlet of your choice. We also have many other great perks so don’t miss out on this opportunity to have your name immortalized by the Bard himself. 

Thank you for taking the time to check out our Box Trailer campaign. Remember, even if you cannot be financially involved in helping us reach our goal, you can always share this campaign with friends, family, and anyone interested in helping us bring the great work of West Virginia artists to the great communities and people of West Virginia.

story:
What is Funhouse?

The Funhouse team are a bunch of lovable weirdos, here to fill your late-night holes with some brand new theater, fresh out of the oven.

Our goal is to entertain our audiences and accommodate artists with affordable, home-grown, high-quality, late night entertainment for Seattle. And that’s where YOU come in!
 

What We Need & What You Get

  • As a brand spankin' new theatre company, we're looking for some start-up money to create a sustainable business model. Between the proceeds from this Indiegogo and ticket sales, we hope to bring you many Funhouses to come!
  • When you donate, you become a part of our Family (not a cult) and we'll love you forever. There's also gifts!
     

Where does the money go? What does the money do?

  • Space! This is one of our biggest expenses. The more you donate, the less we need to worry about keeping the lights on.
  • Stipends! Artists deserve to be paid for their work! The more you donate, the more we can pay them. Actors are more exciting to watch when they’ve been fed. 
  • Sets! The more you donate, the more we build. We're here to thrill, chill, and fulfill you! Is there a director whose set you'd like to sponsor? Is there a set piece you'd like to commission? WRITE US A BIG ENOUGH CHECK AND WE’LL BUILD YOU A DAMN WATER SLIDE. SEE IF WE DON’T DO IT.
  • Costumes, Hair & Make-Up! The more you donate, the higher the fashion. And blood. There will be so much fabulous blood and hair. Hair and blood. Delicious.
  • Props! What if we need a thing that can't be found in the dumpsters behind TPS? What if Goodwill doesn't have the right ouija board? A little goes a long way!
  • Food! We get hungry. Especially being stuck in Seattle traffic when there’s no time to eat between soul-sucking day job and revitalizing artistic pursuit. See above re: feeding actors. They're much better when they're fed.
     

Risks & Challenges

We're a new company in town, and we understand that it may not be evident why exactly we deserve your hard-earned money. If you came to the first Funhouse Anthology at the Eclectic Theater this summer, you know that every person who attended was going in blind - and had a blast anyway.

We know we're not the only company promising Bold New Work, or Emerging Artists, or Local Stories, or Weird Shit On-Stage. We also know that our particular brand of weird? No one else is nailing it quite like we do. We wouldn't be here if it wasn't important.

Take a chance on a brand new theatre company. Let us entertain you.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If money is as tight for you as it is for us, fret not! You can still help us reach our goals:

  • Like us on Facebook and Instagram
  • Watch for FUNHOUSE II tickets, coming soon! We're performing at The Slate, October 19-21.
  • Share this page with your like-minded weirdo friends!
