story:
The Fight for Freedom

The Bond of Friendship

A Courage to Love

The Navigator is an ensemble piece of musical theatre, highlighting the vital role that Bomber Command played in the Second World War by focusing on the crew of one Avro Lancaster.

Overview

The Second World War is about to enter its fifth year and 19-year-old Max, seeking adventure and to escape his father’s brutality, joins the Royal Air Force. A flying accident dashes his hopes of becoming a pilot but he seizes the opportunity to become a navigator and put in to practice his passion for astronomy and the stars. Forming a strong bond with his pilot Pip, their air gunner Jamie, wireless operator Don, and the rest of the crew, they thrill at the wonder of flying and seize every opportunity to live life to the full at the local pubs and at parties.

Romance blossoms, although not everyone’s relationship flourishes amidst the context of war. WAAF Marion, nurse Annie, and Land Girl Helen have to decide if they will risk agonising heartache and sorrow and love someone who may go missing in action any day.

 When Max and the crew, flying Lancasters, begin bombing operations over Germany they are forced to confront fear, death, and the harsh realities of war, putting a strain on the crew bond and their personal romantic relationships. Eventually the crew fail to return from a raid and while they fight for survival, having ditched in the North Sea, the wives and girlfriends wait anxiously for news.

'The Navigator' is a story of the human spirit – ambition, hope, youthfulness, friendship, romance and love – fighting to survive the maelstrom of total war.

Crowdfunding Outline

With the script and lyrics written, and the music composed, The Navigator creative team of Michael Vivian (co-writer, lyricist and director), Glenn Tollett (composer, lyricist and arranger), and Steve Darlow (co-writer and historian) are thrilled to have been given the opportunity to put on two concert presentations of The Navigator. The first, on 19th November 2017 will be staged in Letchworth, Hertfordshire, and give us an opportunity to gauge the reaction of an audience. The second presentation at a London venue, in the following week, will be to theatre professionals, with a view to establishing a partnership with a producer and achieve our goal of a full touring production.

To stage these presentations, we need your help. In particular we are asking for your support to fund certain elements, namely:

Rehearsal Space Rental. An estimated cost of £1,500 to carry out the rehearsals with our cast of 13 actors.

Musical Arrangements. We are budgeting for around £2,500 to cover the cost of musical arrangements, utilising copyists, and bringing on board a Musical Director.

Sound Design. The sounds of The Navigator will be a major part of the audience experience, so we are looking to enlist a sound designer and hire the required equipment, budgeting £1,500.

Lighting. To capture the mood of the period we will need special lighting equipment – budget £1,500.

Staffing. £3,124 has been budgeted for the employment of staff at each of our presentation venues, along with a Production Manager and Deputy Stage Manager.

Image Sourcing and Filming. £1,000 will allow us to source images to support the show and cover the cost of filming and then editing the presentations.

Marketing. £2,200 will enable us to spread the word about The Navigator, and produce the music demos.

Note: Reaching our Target of £13,324 will only cover just under one half of our total budget for The Navigator.

With your donation you can receive acknowledgement of your support to this historic project, a copy of the song demos recorded with West End performers, a signed letter of thanks from the creative team and a Bomber Command veteran, sheet music signed by the composer, lyricist and performer, a veteran signed copy of a hardback Bomber Command book, and two tickets to the Letchworth presentation and an invitation to the subsequent champagne reception.

We have great belief in the theatrical, indeed historical, potential of The Navigator. – a story of a few of the young men who risked their lives in the cause of freedom. It is to those gallant men that The Navigator is dedicated and we thank you for taking time to consider the project.

Inspiration behind the Story

The Navigator is based on inspiring true-life accounts and events. Bomber Command was operational throughout the duration of the Second World War.  Of the 125,000 aircrew who served, 55,573 paid the ultimate sacrifice. These were not seasoned military campaigners, they were young volunteers, with an average age of 22 and a life expectancy of just 6 weeks.

The Navigator seeks to tell the emotional truth of the Bomber Command experience during the Second World War. In addition to composer Glenn Tollett’s father’s Bomber Command career, the production draws on Steve Darlow’s extensive published and unpublished collection of first-hand accounts, and numerous veterans have been consulted during the writing process. The following list names former aircrew whose stories have been of particular value.

Gordon Mellor – navigator, shot down and evaded capture, George Dunn DFC – pilot, Jo Lancaster DFC – pilot, Dave Fellowes – air gunner, Hal Gardner – navigator, Steve Bethell – air gunner, Harry Irons DFC – air gunner, Charles Clarke OBE – bomb aimer and POW, John Bell MBE DFC – bomb aimer, Gerry Norwood – air gunner, Johnny Johnson DFM – bomb aimer (and dambuster), Arthur Darlow – pilot and POW, Calton Younger – Australian navigator and POW, Tony Iveson DFC – pilot, Arthur Smith – flight engineer, John Banfield MBE – wireless operator and POW, Desmond Pelly DFC – pilot and POW, Tiny Cooling – pilot, Reg Wilson – navigator and POW, Reg Barker – pilot and POW, Richard Pinkham DFC – pilot, Alec Nethery – Canadian bomb aimer and evader, Trevor Utton – air gunner and POW, Allan Burrell – wireless operator and POW, Joe Petrie Andrews DFC DFM – pilot, Benny Goodman DFC – pilot, Harry Hughes DFC DFM – navigator, Henry Wagner – navigator and POW, Philip Richards – flight engineer and evader, John de Hoop – wireless operator, Frank Tilley – flight engineer, Don Street DFC – pilot, Geoff Gilbert DFM – air gunner, Jack Watts DSO, DFC and Bar (Canadian) – pilot, Eileen Richards (WAAF), Igraine Hamilton (WAAF), Jamie Dunlop – pilot, KIA, Teddy Burrell – air gunner, KIA.

Other sources are numerous letters written by aircrew and other wartime family correspondence, which has been sourced from Steve Darlow’s archive.
story_txt: The Fight for FreedomThe Bond of FriendshipA Courage to LoveThe Navigator is an ensemble piece of musical theatre, highlighting the vital role that Bomber Command played in the Second World War by focusing on the crew of one Avro Lancaster.OverviewThe Second World War is about to enter its fifth year and 19-year-old Max, seeking adventure and to escape his father’s brutality, joins the Royal Air Force. A flying accident dashes his hopes of becoming a pilot but he seizes the opportunity to become a navigator and put in to practice his passion for astronomy and the stars. Forming a strong bond with his pilot Pip, their air gunner Jamie, wireless operator Don, and the rest of the crew, they thrill at the wonder of flying and seize every opportunity to live life to the full at the local pubs and at parties.Romance blossoms, although not everyone’s relationship flourishes amidst the context of war. WAAF Marion, nurse Annie, and Land Girl Helen have to decide if they will risk agonising heartache and sorrow and love someone who may go missing in action any day. When Max and the crew, flying Lancasters, begin bombing operations over Germany they are forced to confront fear, death, and the harsh realities of war, putting a strain on the crew bond and their personal romantic relationships. Eventually the crew fail to return from a raid and while they fight for survival, having ditched in the North Sea, the wives and girlfriends wait anxiously for news.'The Navigator' is a story of the human spirit – ambition, hope, youthfulness, friendship, romance and love – fighting to survive the maelstrom of total war.Crowdfunding OutlineWith the script and lyrics written, and the music composed, The Navigator creative team of Michael Vivian (co-writer, lyricist and director), Glenn Tollett (composer, lyricist and arranger), and Steve Darlow (co-writer and historian) are thrilled to have been given the opportunity to put on two concert presentations of The Navigator. The first, on 19th November 2017 will be staged in Letchworth, Hertfordshire, and give us an opportunity to gauge the reaction of an audience. The second presentation at a London venue, in the following week, will be to theatre professionals, with a view to establishing a partnership with a producer and achieve our goal of a full touring production.To stage these presentations, we need your help. In particular we are asking for your support to fund certain elements, namely:Rehearsal Space Rental. An estimated cost of £1,500 to carry out the rehearsals with our cast of 13 actors.Musical Arrangements. We are budgeting for around £2,500 to cover the cost of musical arrangements, utilising copyists, and bringing on board a Musical Director.Sound Design. The sounds of The Navigator will be a major part of the audience experience, so we are looking to enlist a sound designer and hire the required equipment, budgeting £1,500.Lighting. To capture the mood of the period we will need special lighting equipment – budget £1,500.Staffing. £3,124 has been budgeted for the employment of staff at each of our presentation venues, along with a Production Manager and Deputy Stage Manager.Image Sourcing and Filming. £1,000 will allow us to source images to support the show and cover the cost of filming and then editing the presentations.Marketing. £2,200 will enable us to spread the word about The Navigator, and produce the music demos.Note: Reaching our Target of £13,324 will only cover just under one half of our total budget for The Navigator.With your donation you can receive acknowledgement of your support to this historic project, a copy of the song demos recorded with West End performers, a signed letter of thanks from the creative team and a Bomber Command veteran, sheet music signed by the composer, lyricist and performer, a veteran signed copy of a hardback Bomber Command book, and two tickets to the Letchworth presentation and an invitation to the subsequent champagne reception.We have great belief in the theatrical, indeed historical, potential of The Navigator. – a story of a few of the young men who risked their lives in the cause of freedom. It is to those gallant men that The Navigator is dedicated and we thank you for taking time to consider the project.Inspiration behind the StoryThe Navigator is based on inspiring true-life accounts and events. Bomber Command was operational throughout the duration of the Second World War.  Of the 125,000 aircrew who served, 55,573 paid the ultimate sacrifice. These were not seasoned military campaigners, they were young volunteers, with an average age of 22 and a life expectancy of just 6 weeks.The Navigator seeks to tell the emotional truth of the Bomber Command experience during the Second World War. In addition to composer Glenn Tollett’s father’s Bomber Command career, the production draws on Steve Darlow’s extensive published and unpublished collection of first-hand accounts, and numerous veterans have been consulted during the writing process. The following list names former aircrew whose stories have been of particular value.Gordon Mellor – navigator, shot down and evaded capture, George Dunn DFC – pilot, Jo Lancaster DFC – pilot, Dave Fellowes – air gunner, Hal Gardner – navigator, Steve Bethell – air gunner, Harry Irons DFC – air gunner, Charles Clarke OBE – bomb aimer and POW, John Bell MBE DFC – bomb aimer, Gerry Norwood – air gunner, Johnny Johnson DFM – bomb aimer (and dambuster), Arthur Darlow – pilot and POW, Calton Younger – Australian navigator and POW, Tony Iveson DFC – pilot, Arthur Smith – flight engineer, John Banfield MBE – wireless operator and POW, Desmond Pelly DFC – pilot and POW, Tiny Cooling – pilot, Reg Wilson – navigator and POW, Reg Barker – pilot and POW, Richard Pinkham DFC – pilot, Alec Nethery – Canadian bomb aimer and evader, Trevor Utton – air gunner and POW, Allan Burrell – wireless operator and POW, Joe Petrie Andrews DFC DFM – pilot, Benny Goodman DFC – pilot, Harry Hughes DFC DFM – navigator, Henry Wagner – navigator and POW, Philip Richards – flight engineer and evader, John de Hoop – wireless operator, Frank Tilley – flight engineer, Don Street DFC – pilot, Geoff Gilbert DFM – air gunner, Jack Watts DSO, DFC and Bar (Canadian) – pilot, Eileen Richards (WAAF), Igraine Hamilton (WAAF), Jamie Dunlop – pilot, KIA, Teddy Burrell – air gunner, KIA.Other sources are numerous letters written by aircrew and other wartime family correspondence, which has been sourced from Steve Darlow’s archive.

story:
Who we are
We are a theatre company who have trained in performing improvisation, puppetry, and narrative for many years and decided to put it all together in one very unique theatre experience.


Using tabletop Bunraku style puppetry, we improvise a brand new adventurous, action-packed and often emotional story from scratch at every performance. No two shows are the same and each is completely improvised.


Edinburgh
The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the world largest arts festival with over three thousand shows performing. For the first time ever we’re extremely excited to be part of the festival.

What We Need & What You Get
Taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is no small thing, it’s a huge undertaking and we need some help. We’re looking to raise £3000, which will go towards:

Transportation
Venue Hire (this on its own is £2000)
Accommodation
Fringe Registration
Flyers & posters, etc.  


We have gifts and perks for you, including: personalised videos featuring the puppets, tickets to see the show, and homemade puppets for you to keep! Your own Glitch puppet! Hand made by us, no two are the same. See the perks at side for more information.


If you attend the festival this year we’d love to meet you in person. The show is running August 5th -20th 4.05 p.m. at theSpace @ Surgeons Hall.


Thank you in advance for your support and if you would like to keep up to date with the project check out the links below:

Twitter: https://twitter.com/Glitchimprov
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Glitchimprov
Website: http://www.glitchimprov.com
Fringe tickets: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/glitch-the-improvised-puppet-show

story:
Endangered Artist Sanctuary (EAS)

EAS was founded by Artistic Director and Co-producer Kelly Barrett-Gibson, Co-producers Wende O’Reilly, Carl Gibson, and a core group of actors in 2012. The inaugural season was focused on the classics, featuring productions of The Cherry Orchard by Anton Chekhov, Lady Windermere's Fan by Oscar Wilde, as well as The Merry Wives of Windsor and The Tempest by Shakespeare. In season two, EAS went contemporary, starting with a production of John Patrick Shanley's Savage in Limbo and continuing with the work-shopping of the original piece Reading Between the Lies written by Ms. Barrett-Gibson with dramaturgy by Ms. O'Reilly.  Last year, Reading Between the Lies was a huge success at the New York International Fringe Festival.

Our Project

For the second year in a row, EAS has a play in the New York International Fringe Festival!  This year's entry is The Sutherby Triplets, by Kelly Barrett-Gibson.  A wonderfully sill farce, Triplets tells the story of classical actress Susie, musical theater star Sally and data entry clerk Sammie (or Bob, as he prefers to be called).  When their mother, former television royalty, decides that it is time for them reconnect she invents an occasion to get them all home.  With all of these egos under one roof for the weekend, only one thing is sure: everyone wants to be in the spotlight!

What we need

We are looking for help in bringing The Sutherby Triplets to the FringeNYC stage. Expenses include rehearsal space, costuming, props, insurance, stipends for the artists contributing to the show, marketing campaigns and the festival entrance fee. 

If we fail to meet our goal, we will use monies raised to fund as much of the production as possible, beginning with insurance and stipends for the artists involved. 

The Impact

EAS is creatively driven in large part by women in their 40s. In the summer of 2013 we began looking for a comedy to showcase these vibrant, talented actresses. To our dismay, we discovered that the majority of material called for ingénues, grandmothers and maids, but very few strong women. Then and there it was decided that the shows we write would include roles to give our leading ladies material to sink their teeth into.

Other Ways to Help

We understand that some people cannot contribute, but we could still use everyone's help and support.

  • Share this campaign with your social network! 
  • Like EAS on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and visit our website at endangeredartistsanctuary.com.
  • Come see the show!!!

Thank you!

story:
What is Bay Area Zeta Players?

Bay Area Zeta Players is a completely student run theatre company based in Oakland. We started in 2014 as Nerdology Musical Theatre to produce Buffy the Vampire Slayer: Once More with Feeling and last year returned with Zombie Prom. We have since expanded to include a student-written Ten Minute Play Festival in addition to our Nerdology Program and thus became BAZP. 
We pride ourselves on selecting material that speaks to the teenage experience and is rarely seen on stage. Heathers the Musical revamps the 1989 cult classic bringing the dark comedy of teen angst to the next generation. Who better to put on a play about high schoolers than theatre company designed for high school participants?

We need you!

BAZP is funded almost entirely by donations. We want to give all participants a professional experience and a product with high production value, and for that we need you! The proceeds from this campaign will pay for sets, props, costumes, theater space, and printing; all the things that make a good show a great show!

Thanks to our fiscal sponsor Media Alliance all of your donations are tax deductible. You also have access to amazing perks such as tickets to the shows and merchendise signed by our cast!

The Impact

BAZP offers professional theatre experiences for all participants 100% free of charge. We are a diverse group of students from a wide variety of backgrounds and we make it a priority for our company to give all students access to an inclusive ensemble that explores all aspects of theatre. Being a student run company creates an equal ground for anyone to share their ideas and everyone to feel supported and heard. First and foremost, BAZP strives to support high school students to use their passion for the arts to enrich the community.

Thanks to your donations, Heathers will run at Live Oak Theatre on July 8th, 9th, 15th, and 16th at 8:00pm.

story:
Our Story

Mission:  We strive to examine the beautiful human struggle for meaning through all its awkward, broken, obscene and ugly fragments.

Crashbox Theater Company was born from the hearts and minds of eighteen individuals who traveled from all corners of the world to train in NYC at Atlantic Acting School Conservatory.  Inspired by the bravery and work of past and present theater artists and playwrights, we hope to become a vibrant part of the theater world and contribute to its growth.  Under the guidance and allowed budget of Atlantic, we were given artistic freedom to launch our first production as a company, “Orange Flower Water” by Craig Wright.  Freshly graduated and with that priceless learning experience under our belts, we are ready to step out from under the Atlantic umbrella and launch our first independent production this fall.

 

The Project

We are extremely happy to announce that our fall production will be two short plays by award-winning dramatist Kyle John Schmidt. 

 “Saint Matilde’s Malady” – written entirely in trochaic verse- humorously explores the romantic entanglements of Prostitutes and Pirates; poses questions on socially acceptable relationships and the existence of true love. 

 “The Last Hat:  a Tragedy” is the winner of the Actors Theatre 2010 Heideman Award.  It tells a tragic tale of the troubles that come from letting trivial illusions take on greater importance than bravely speaking the truth.

 

The Impact

As a company, we look to build a platform that will be a collaboration of artists and playwrights who are passionate about keeping the art of storytelling alive and progressive.  Our first production out in the “real world” certainly won’t be our last.  However, we are a young company and the contributions you make here will have an extremely positive effect on how far we are able to go with this first step.   A successful fall production will help us cultivate an audience and provide funds for a winter and/or spring production. 


 

What We Need

Space.  The majority of funds raised here will go towards rental space for rehearsals and performances.  Modest theater spaces with adequate equipment in New York run aprox. $2,500.00/month.

Additional funds will be put towards the production in the following areas:

-Design Budget

                -Props

                -Set

                -Costumes

                -Lighting

                -Sound

-Marketing

                -Posters

                -Programs

-Healthy snacks and hydration for cast and crew during the run of performances.

 

What you Get

Besides our eternal love and admiration, we have provided perks for contributions made.  We understand that financial times are tough and wish our perks could be more lush.  Although modest, the perks are given with loads of gratitude for anything you're able to contribute.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

-Become our “Friend”and “Follow” us!  Find Crashbox Theater Company on Facebook and Twitter to stay posted on current and future happenings.

-Get the word out!  If you like what we’re doing, kindly let people know where to find us.

-Volunteer!   We are always looking for help in everything from designing (props, lights, sound, costumes, set) to fundraising to box office.  Even if you’re just dying to take a paint brush to a stage set, let us know!  (Please send an email to meridith_jones1@hotmail.com if you’re interested in volunteering.)

-Submit!  We are always accepting new plays, so if you have them, send them!  (Please send submissions to thomas.muccioli@yahoo.com )

 

Crashbox Theater Company Members

Milee Bang, Marianna Barry, Emily Davison, Ivan Dolido, Jessika Doyel, JoAnn Eubanks, Jolenta Greenberg, Meridith Jones, Vanina Kondova, Camille Lowman, Thomas Muccioli, Caroline O'Meara, Nila Sawyer, Rebecca Schoffer, Griffin Sherbert, Erica Smith, Jordan Douglas Smith and Alexandra Vincent.

story:
NEW SHOW WEBSITE: www.laurenrayner.com/mendacity


‘MENDACITY; or feel GOOD SO f??ked’ has been in the making for years and it’s time to bring this piece to fruition! Written & directed by Lauren Rayner, MENDACITY takes you deep inside the mind of a splintering personality, peppered with dark humor and wrought with self-loathing and denial over two sexual assaults. Join us in a journey of fragmented transcendence and the offering of hope.


WE ARE SO PLEASED to announce that after moving from readings in Los Angeles to New York, the next step in the evolution of MENDACITY is the world premier production in the FRIGID FESTIVAL NYC in March 2011!


THE PREMIER PRODUCTION OF MENDACITY will integrate dynamic multi-media techniques, including mind-blowing video projections by JAY KILACHAND, an original soundscape designed by JAKE HULL (of the band MOMENTARY PROPHETS) with intense/precise choreography by SHILOH GOODIN. The piece will be performed by the lovely ALI KRESCH.


AUDIENCE REACTIONS FROM READINGS:

"It's disturbing, yet at the same time, it's entertaining – this piece is interesting in how it veers into both those territories. A splintering personality and all of the noise inside; there's a lot of self-loathing involved and then at the end there's this transcendence. The writing has captured it all in this lascivious, hipster that causes us mental anguish. It's off-putting, it's strange, it's the unknowable. Is this a mind-fuck or is this piece more than that?" –Johnny Riney & Joan Wiest (of International Creative Management)


"MENDACITY is a kaleidoscope of vibrant voices with reflections constantly revolving and morphing around the issue sexual assault. For someone to take something so personal and heartbreaking and transform it into something so transcendent and gut-wrenchingly honest is magnificent, awe-inspiring and inspirational." -Ashley Steed (Writer, LA Stage Times)


"The first time I heard MENDACITY I was blown away. It was so different form Lauren's other work, it was so personal and poetic. The nontraditional structure and syntax completely fits the disjointed feel of a human being splintered by emotional and physical trauma. It is a bold piece of work and I felt privileged to be a part of the early drafts." -Sarah Newswanger (Choreographer/Actress)


"There were so many significant moments and images that stood out to me. When he asks 'do I kiss like him?' a note was struck in me so deep because I had a partner who was sexually abused and our relationship was constantly confronted with this issue and the past returning to haunt her. I thought the piece was lovely and this story needs to be heard!" –Sarah Hartley (Roots and Wings Theatrical, Member of the Board of Directors)


WHY WE NEED FUNDS TO MAKE THIS PROJECT HAPPEN

We seek your generous support to help with the following expenses:

-Printing publicity materials and expand outreach to the community

-Covering the rental of technical equipment to realize elaborate sound and video design

-Renting a camera to film, edit and run video during performances

-Theatre rental and rehearsal space fees

-Design materials to realize ambitious set, video, costume, and lighting design

-Administrative costs (festival fees, contracts with AEA, insurance)


HOW TO MAKE AN IMPACT

Lauren Rayner Productions has been fundraising for MENDACITY through fiscal sponsorship since 2008. We need one FINAL PUSH to make this project happen. Our current goal is to raise $2,500 by the time our show opens in February 2011. Please give any amount you can. Giving just $5 will have a tremendous impact on our production!


Donations are being accepted here through IndieGoGo and since Lauren Rayner is a fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas, your donation will be tax deductible! If you would like to make a donation by check instead of online with a credit card, please make checks payable to ‘Fractured Atlas’ with ‘In Behalf of Lauren Rayner’ in the subject line. Send all checks to Lauren Rayner Productions, 56 Morton St. #3R New York, NY 10014


Questions? Feel free to contact > lauren@laurenrayner.com


For more info on the show, check out the official website: www.laurenrayner.com/mendacity

To watch our creative collaborators reel: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4RNl7EkVJeQ

To learn more about the FRIGID Festival NYC: www.frigidnewyork.info


THE CREATIVE & PRODUCTION TEAM

Lauren Rayner (producer/director/writer)
Rachel Kerry (producer)
Benjamin Mack (producer)
Shiloh Goodin (choreographer)
Jake Hull (sound designer)
Luke Kanter (sound engineer/electrician)
Jay Kilachand (video designer)
Ali Kresch (solo-performer)
Tony Lepore (lighting designer)
Jim Rayner (set designer)
Grace Folsom (creative collaborator)
Sarah Newswanger (creative collaborator)
Ryan Scoble (creative collaborator)
Joseph Samuel Wright (creative collaborator)
story_txt:
NEW SHOW WEBSITE: www.laurenrayner.com/mendacity‘MENDACITY; or feel GOOD SO f??ked’ has been in the making for years and it’s time to bring this piece to fruition! Written & directed by Lauren Rayner, MENDACITY takes you deep inside the mind of a splintering personality, peppered with dark humor and wrought with self-loathing and denial over two sexual assaults. Join us in a journey of fragmented transcendence and the offering of hope.WE ARE SO PLEASED to announce that after moving from readings in Los Angeles to New York, the next step in the evolution of MENDACITY is the world premier production in the FRIGID FESTIVAL NYC in March 2011! THE PREMIER PRODUCTION OF MENDACITY will integrate dynamic multi-media techniques, including mind-blowing video projections by JAY KILACHAND, an original soundscape designed by JAKE HULL (of the band MOMENTARY PROPHETS) with intense/precise choreography by SHILOH GOODIN. The piece will be performed by the lovely ALI KRESCH.AUDIENCE REACTIONS FROM READINGS:"It's disturbing, yet at the same time, it's entertaining – this piece is interesting in how it veers into both those territories. A splintering personality and all of the noise inside; there's a lot of self-loathing involved and then at the end there's this transcendence. The writing has captured it all in this lascivious, hipster that causes us mental anguish. It's off-putting, it's strange, it's the unknowable. Is this a mind-fuck or is this piece more than that?" –Johnny Riney & Joan Wiest (of International Creative Management)"MENDACITY is a kaleidoscope of vibrant voices with reflections constantly revolving and morphing around the issue sexual assault. For someone to take something so personal and heartbreaking and transform it into something so transcendent and gut-wrenchingly honest is magnificent, awe-inspiring and inspirational." -Ashley Steed (Writer, LA Stage Times) "The first time I heard MENDACITY I was blown away. It was so different form Lauren's other work, it was so personal and poetic. The nontraditional structure and syntax completely fits the disjointed feel of a human being splintered by emotional and physical trauma. It is a bold piece of work and I felt privileged to be a part of the early drafts." -Sarah Newswanger (Choreographer/Actress)"There were so many significant moments and images that stood out to me. When he asks 'do I kiss like him?' a note was struck in me so deep because I had a partner who was sexually abused and our relationship was constantly confronted with this issue and the past returning to haunt her. I thought the piece was lovely and this story needs to be heard!" –Sarah Hartley (Roots and Wings Theatrical, Member of the Board of Directors)WHY WE NEED FUNDS TO MAKE THIS PROJECT HAPPEN We seek your generous support to help with the following expenses:-Printing publicity materials and expand outreach to the community-Covering the rental of technical equipment to realize elaborate sound and video design-Renting a camera to film, edit and run video during performances-Theatre rental and rehearsal space fees-Design materials to realize ambitious set, video, costume, and lighting design-Administrative costs (festival fees, contracts with AEA, insurance)HOW TO MAKE AN IMPACTLauren Rayner Productions has been fundraising for MENDACITY through 
fiscal sponsorship since 2008. We need one FINAL PUSH to make this 
project happen. Our current goal is to raise $2,500 by the time our show opens in February 2011. Please give any 
amount you can. Giving just $5 will have a tremendous impact on our production!Donations are being accepted here through IndieGoGo and since Lauren Rayner is a fiscally sponsored project with Fractured Atlas, your donation will be tax deductible! If you would like to make a donation by check instead of online with a credit card, please make checks payable to ‘Fractured Atlas’ with ‘In Behalf of Lauren Rayner’ in the subject line. Send all checks to Lauren Rayner Productions, 56 Morton St. #3R New York, NY 10014 Questions? Feel free to contact > lauren@laurenrayner.comFor more info on the show, check out the official website: www.laurenrayner.com/mendacityTo watch our creative collaborators reel: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4RNl7EkVJeQTo learn more about the FRIGID Festival NYC: www.frigidnewyork.infoTHE CREATIVE & PRODUCTION TEAM
Lauren Rayner (producer/director/writer) Rachel Kerry (producer)Benjamin Mack (producer)Shiloh Goodin (choreographer) Jake Hull (sound designer) Luke Kanter (sound engineer/electrician) Jay Kilachand (video designer)Ali Kresch (solo-performer) Tony Lepore (lighting designer)Jim Rayner (set designer)Grace Folsom (creative collaborator) Sarah Newswanger (creative collaborator) Ryan Scoble (creative collaborator)Joseph Samuel Wright (creative collaborator)

story:
HELP US FUND THE WORLD PREMIERE OF SPILL

SPILL is a multimedia play inspired by the 2010 British Petroleum (BP) oil spill, the largest environmental disaster in U.S. history. The project is the co-creation of playwright/director Leigh Fondakowski (The Laramie Project, The People's Temple, Laramie: Ten Years Later) and visual artist Reeva Wortel and is based on interviews, photographs, and court documents collected in the aftermath of the spill. 

THE WORLD PREMIERE

The world premiere of SPILL will take place at Swine Palace in Baton Rouge, LA, March 12-30, 2014. Our theater company, The Study Group, has agreed to co-produce this world premiere event and we need your help.

AN URGENT NEED: In order for this production to happen, we have to raise $25,000 by January 15, 2014. 

THE PROJECT

SPILL tells the dramatic story of the 2010 explosion on board the oil rig Deepwater Horizon, and the devastating impact of the 87-day spill on the coastal communities and marine life of Louisiana.

Within months of the disaster, the artists began speaking with a broad array of Louisiana citizens, including fishermen, political figures, cleanup workers, scientists, oil industry workers, and the families of those lost in the explosion. As they collected over 200 hours of stories and interviews, Wortel painted portraits of each interviewee. The play will premiere in conjunction with an art installation of these portraits.

SPILL explores the rich culture of Louisiana and the resilient nature of its inhabitants in the face of natural destruction and tragedy. Expressing the fundamental story of man versus nature, at the core of SPILL is the question: What is the true human and environmental cost of oil?

The artists are dedicated to premiering the play and installation in Louisiana, in the place where the interview material was drawn. The BP oil disaster was one of the most significant events of our generation and SPILL captures the true legacy of this crisis in the voices of the people who lived it.

THE ARTISTS

Leigh Fondakowski was the Head Writer of The Laramie Project and has been a member of Tectonic Theater Project since 1995. She is an Emmy nominated co-screenwriter for the adaptation of The Laramie Project for HBO.

Reeva Wortel is an interdisciplinary artist who creates portrait-based projects that combine interview, social commentary, performance and large-scale installation. Wortel has been the recipient of several grants as a muralist, choreographer and installation artist.

Kelli Simpkins is an actor and dramaturg and a proud member of The Study Group. She is an artistic associate of About Face Theater. She is a company member of Tectonic Theater Project and one of the original creator / performers of The Laramie Project (Off-Broadway, Denver Center, Berkeley Rep, LaJolla Playhouse, and the movie adaptation of the play to HBO). 

ABOUT THE STUDY GROUP

Co-founded by Leigh Fondakowski and Reeva Wortel, The Study Group is a production company dedicated to exploring the relationship of theater, performance, and real life events. We investigate pivotal moments in human history through in-depth research, interviews, and theatrical exploration. Study Group members have participated in the creation of I Think I Like Girls, The Laramie Project, Laramie: Ten Years Later, The People's Temple, Casa Cushman, Gerda's Lieutenant, Yaghistan, Gray, and SPILL. We believe that artists play a unique role in telling the important stories of our time. 

ABOUT SWINE PALACE

Founded in 1992, Swine Palace operates with a dual mission to provide South Louisiana with high-quality, professional productions of classical and contemporary theatre with an emphasis on plays exploring issues of social equity while also serving as a training ground for students in Louisiana State University’s M.F.A. Professional Actor and Technical/Design Training Programs.

WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?

Every dollar will be used to pay production expenses: sets, lights, costumes, sound, projections, art installation materials, actors, director, and designers. We will also pay transportation costs for our interviewees who live far away to attend opening night.

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of Staffordshire University students who are all very passionate about musical theatre. As part of a project we are putting on a musical, In Touch, a musical about the impact of social media on society. We need your help to help us put on this show, any funds are appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

We need £1000, well that's our goal. We need to be able to buy props, costumes and hire out a theatre for 1-2 nights so we need to start fundraising. If you live in the area you'll be able to come and see the show and see just how your money has helped us.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate don't worry, you can follow us on Twitter and like us Facebook and spread the word and hopefully other people will be able to donate.

story:
RDT: Embrace the Unexpected

There’s an old saying that the best way to keep a trail alive is to walk it, because every time you walk it, you create it again.  

Repertory Dance Theatre believes dancing that trail is even better.

It was radical when, in 1966, Utah dancers beat out the big city stalwarts to receive a Rockefeller grant establishing RDT as the nation’s first repertory dance company.  RDT’s job? To preserve the art form—not just the work of one choreographer--while pushing the boundaries of modern dance by acquiring new work. Whether they are contemporary classics, historical masterpieces, or new commissions, RDT has collected over 375 diverse and notable dance works.

RDT is launching a new crowdfunding campaign to help cover some of the costs associated with acquiring 7 new works. You can dance the trail of history with us as we launch our exciting 2015-2016 season.

WHAT WE NEED...

RDT: Embrace the Unexpected is designed to raise $7,500 to fund new dances we’ll will be acquiring this year.  These include: 

  • Energizer by the incomparable Molissa Fenley, 
  • the historical masterpiece Mazurkas by José Limón, 
  • and a brand new commission by Company alum William “Bill” Evans. 
In all, RDT will be acquiring 7 new dance works this year alone.

While RDT’s mission includes the preservation of historical modern dance, a full 80% of what we perform is made up of our ever-expanding collection by living choreographers.

...AND WHAT YOU GET (Perks):

We wouldn't be able to do this without your support and we want to thank you properly for your generosity by offering a wide range of perks to anyone who donates.

Perks include name recognition throughout the season, a signed 50th anniversary photograph, lunch with the dancers, invitations to special showings, summertime concerts performed by our visiting artists (August 1 and August 22), workshop scholarships, RDT Dance Center punch cards . . . even season tickets!

THE IMPACT:

RDT: Embrace the Unexpected is about making meaning for our audiences and the community we call home. It’s what makes us revolutionary even after 50 years of "dancing the trail."  Unlike other companies, the diverse nature of our dance collection allows us to pair what's happening now with what happened then in ways you won’t see coming.

Repertory Dance Theatre is about grace and athleticism, beauty and power.  We are about ART: art in motion, expressed through our bodies as dance. Art that in its immediacy and intimacy can be both thrilling and profound.

We were hugely successful in raising over $7,500 last summer to help fund the commission of “By The Snake," created just for RDT by Noa Zuk and Ohad Fishof.  This work went on to be lauded by the Salt Lake Tribune as one of the highlights of the 2014 season.

We need your help to continue our mission to acquire new work.  $7,500 represents just a fraction of the costs associated with bringing these works to you.  When you donate to RDT: Embrace the Unexpected you become a valued partner alongside the... 

  • National Endowment for the Arts, 
  • Salt Lake and Utah Arts Councils, 
  • George & Dolores Dore Eccles Foundation,
  •  Sorenson Legacy Foundation

. . . to name just a few – who have confidence in the mission RDT has fulfilled for 50 years: the preservation and appreciation of modern dance.

RISKS & CHALLENGES:

Modern dance can be misunderstood.  Like modern visual art, we don’t necessarily tell a story with a linear plot. We  comment on the world through abstraction.  We allow our artistic vision to take shape in mysterious forms and figures.  We think this mystery is very exciting but we can’t offer you a black- and-white description of what you'll see.  What we CAN offer you is art that is visceral; art that moves you on a deeper level; art that raises questions, provokes and inspires. 

Our 2015-2016 season is an ambitious one.  With 7 new dance works being added to our collection, we are doing more than ever before. We are pushing ourselves to acquire new choreography that will stand alongside work we already have to help us tell a unique and powerful story.  

We need your help to make sure this story is told--our collective story.

We will direct whatever funds we raise toward the acquisition of these works.   Reaching our goal will inspire RDT and our stakeholders to ensure the future of the Company. Your donation in any amount will help.  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

If you can't contribute, there are still many ways you can help:

  • Share this link with your friends right now. Help others learn about this project and share the excitement.  The more people who know and learn about this project the better!
  • Follow along as RDT acquires new works this summer.  We will be posting videos, interviews, and pictures right here on our Indiegogo page.
  • Attend for a sneak-peaks of some of our new works this summer.  Be sure to check the RDT website and Facebook page for more information.
Join us for the 2015-2016 season as we premiere these new works through the year as a part of our 50th anniversary celebration.

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Distilled Theatre Company provides the best opportunity for playwirghts to develop and showcase innovate new work. By fostering artistic communities, we create quality productions that are accessible to a 21st Century audience.

We are excited to announce our 2013 Mainstage, "Long Distance Drunk" by Corey Pajka. This play was chosen by audience vote at our second annual Playoffs. Want to know more? Click here!

Synopsis: 

Two young people who forge a relationship in college based around music, books, and beer.  Years later, as their relationship cracks, and their addictions deepen, they go their separate ways and create new lives for themselves.  After overcoming their dependencies, they discover the only thing they were ever addicted to was each other.  Closeness drove them apart, but distance may bring them back together.      

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this play the best it can be, we need YOUR help! We have taken this production to the next level by hiring a team of incredibly talented artists and providing them with all the materials they need to excel and be creative (space, set, costumes, etc). 

One Dollar is Actually Two! 

Because of some EXTREMELY GENEROUS donors, every dollar you contribute will be matched. Donations will go toward:

- Artist Stipends

- Set pieces

- Rehearsal Space 

- Props (aka Lots of Beer)  

- Costumes

- Programs 

The Impact

Distilled Theatre Company is committed to being a sustainable theatre company. Not only will your donation support this incredible new play, but you will help us be a financially viable company so we can keep creating art and fostering new work for years to come! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the buzz out! Even if you can't contribute, follow Distilled Theatre Company on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Support our show and come see "Long Distance Drunk" on November 21st-23rd!!!!!! Can't wait to see you there!
